1	nasa has announced that an asteroid designated as 2004 bl86 will be passing closer to earth than any other space rock in recent years, at approximately 3 times the distance of earth to the moon on january 26, 2015. though it poses no threat to earth for the foreseeable future, the asteroid's proximity offers a unique opportunity for observation and learning. scientists plan to observe it with microwaves, aiming to obtain radar-generated images of the celestial body. while its closest approach poses no risk to earth, don't panic – nasa aims to study this opportunity to better understand asteroids and uncover valuable resources.
2	a u.s. soldier's desecration of the quran has led iraq's most powerful sunni arab political party to advocate harsh punishment, denouncing the action as a "blatant assault on the sanctities of muslims all over the world." a us soldier involved in the incident was apologized to and had his military record penalized; however, the iraqi islamic party called for "the severest of punishments" due to their past experiences with similar crimes including the destruction of mosques and defacing of the quran by us soldiers. 
3	english footballer andy carroll, after a series of injury-ravaged seasons with liverpool and west ham, shared an understandably gloomy selfie prepping for ankle surgery on instagram. his ankle injury on a tour of new zealand ruled him out for up to four months, meaning he'll likely not return to action until december at the earliest, missing the crucial start of west ham's campaign.
4	european singers and aspiring pop stars such as estonia's kerli, italy's marco bosco, t.a.t.u.'s lena katina from russia, slovakia's twiins and austria's fawni are now moving to los angeles to make their way into the u.s. market. these artists are taking advantage of the increasing globalization of pop music and are using places like youtube to compete with the established music industry. kerli, who has pushed a unique sound called "bubblegoth," and her label believe her second album, following her 2008 release "love is dead," may do better in the u.s. market than her debut.
5	the olympic games opening ceremony in london featured a billion global viewers, including attendees at the olympic stadium and those watching on tv. the event, dubbed "isles of wonder," showcased diverse acts, including references to british history and pop music, and culminated in the torch being carried by steve redgrave and lit by seven promising young athletes before culminating in the large cauldron.
6	canadian counterterrorism officials arrested and charged a man on monday, accusing him of being involved in a terror plot with two twin brothers, aged 24. suliman mohamed, 21, has been charged with participating in the activities of a terrorist group and conspiracy to participate in terrorist activity, as police claim he conspired with the accused brothers. the arrest follows an investigation dating back to august 2014 into alleged terrorist groups in canada.
7	the sister of a man suspected in the shooting of pakistani teenager malala yousufzai expressed her apologies to malala in an interview with cnn. rehana haleem said she hopes malala recovers soon and returns to a normal life, and the family don't consider her brother as a family member anymore. pakistani authorities are still searching for malala's attacker, one of whom has been allegedly in hiding for pursuing a master's degree in chemistry. malala is recovering in a hospital in england, and pakistani authorities are planning to honor the injured girls.
8	zimbabwe's prime minister morgan tsvangirai said he believes his wife's fatal car crash was caused by an accident, not foul play. the accident occurred when the couple was traveling and their car was left overturned off the highway. tsvangirai, who previously served as an opposition figure, had joined a coalition government with president robert mugabe last month, which seemed to resolve a political impasse. his political party has called for an independent inquiry into the crash, and the prime minister returned home from neighboring botswana after recovering from his injuries.
9	a russian newspaper reports that the espionage post in cuba, which was shut down in 2001, may reopen. the lourdes signals intelligence facility would be part of a deal between russian and cuban leaders, vladimir putin and raul castro. if the facility reopens, its operational capacity and financial arrangements are yet to be determined.
10	stewart parnell, former owner of the peanut corporation of america, was found guilty in a georgia federal court regarding conspiracy and other charges related to a 2008-2009 salmonella outbreak that caused 714 illnesses and was linked to nine deaths. parnell, along with his brother and a quality assurance manager, faces severe sentences for 71 total charges.
11	world renowned sprinter usain bolt enjoyed a night out in london with two companions, leaving the mahiki nightclub at 3am and later heading to raffles. he was spotted in clapham, south-west london, later that morning, appearing in good spirits throughout, and was even seen in a dentist's surgery.
12	gary o'donnell, an army bomb disposal expert, lost his life in afghanistan. in an effort to support their four children, his wife toni has decided to sell his george medal, which is an exceptional act of bravery, for £60,000. o'donnell previously received the george medal twice in recognition of his heroic actions in iraq and afghanistan.
13	some older women with breast cancer can safely avoid radiotherapy without harming their chances of survival, according to researchers. older patients who receive breast-conserving surgery and hormone therapy gain only "modest" survival benefits from radiotherapy treatment. the findings suggest that at-risk patients who are aged 65 or over and have hormone-sensitive early-stage breast cancer could avoid the health risks and side effects associated with radiotherapy, such as fatigue and heart damage.
14	petite firearms officers victoria wheatley and rachael giles are set to receive payouts of £35,000 each after winning a sex discrimination case; they won on the grounds that their guns were too big to handle and their reputations were damaged due to lower marks in firing range tests as compared to men. the officers claimed that their protective gear and the wooden barricade used for resting their arms were too large for them due to their small stature. the uk civil nuclear constabulary, the employer, was found guilty of discrimination against the officers, despite claims of victimisation being unanimously dismissed.
15	surveillance footage reveals suge knight's pickup truck may have run over two men, killing one, in compton, california, on thursday night. suge knight's attorney had previously claimed he was innocent of homicide. however, the night's cctv camera footage was not working, and no security cameras in the area captured the bloody scene. investigators are still reviewing the case and seeking footage from cellphones that could provide evidence.
16	singer noel harrison, who gained fame for his hit song "the windmills of your mind," has passed away at the age of 79. the son of actor rex harrison, noel originally performed the song on the soundtrack for the film "the thomas crown affair," and won best song at the 1968 oscars for his work. he lived a successful career in both singing and acting, representing britain in ski-racing and appearing in tv series "the girl from uncle" during the british invasion of america.
17	an interactive map shows the world's most dangerous highways, with the north yungas road in bolivia as the most dangerous route. the map is based on the world health organization's global status report on road safety and other data sets, and features interactive explanations of each road's dangers. factors considered include altitude, safety precautions, local driving techniques, vehicle condition, road surfaces, and weather conditions. users can explore different deadly routes with accompanying facts about the countries' road rules and scary statistics. while the highways may appear terrifying, they do offer the opportunity for adventurous driving experiences.
18	everton's phil jagielka admits frustration over frequent speculation about john terry's possible return to the england squad. although jagielka has recovered from a hamstring injury, he and gary cahill, who worked well together at club level, are likely to be given first-choice positions at the world cup.
19	staten island district attorney daniel donovan, who handled the case of a white police officer being cleared in the chokehold death of eric garner, has announced his candidacy for congress. donovan announced seeking the endorsements of the republican, conservative, and independence parties, and has expressed his enthusiasm for his candidacy has broadened and intensified since his initial interest. the special election for congress follows the resignation of michael grimm, the previous congressman, after pleading guilty to a felony charge of tax evasion. donovan faces potential opponents from both the democratic and republican parties during the election.
20	on september 23, 2012, at least nine climbers were killed and six reported missing after an avalanche on mount manaslu, the world's eighth-highest mountain in the himalayas of northern nepal. the victims included french and german climbers struggling with the slopes before the rescue helicopters discovered the situation. of the surviving climbers, a frenchman named claude belmas, 52, and a belgian called armand manel, 42, rescued in wheelchairs and airlifted to a clinic in katmandu, nepal. although weather conditions were improving, the death toll continued to rise as more bodies were found.
21	actor harry potter star daniel radcliffe cried at the funeral of his friend and fellow actor richard griffiths, who passed away at the age of 65. the funeral service was held at holy trinity church in stratford-upon-avon, where shakespeare was buried. other celebrity guests included downton abbey creator lord fellowes and actor nigel haves. a wreath was sent by richard e. grant, who co-starred with griffiths in the 1987 film withnail and i. 
22	roy hodgson, the england manager, chose barcelona player javier mascherano as his first choice vote for the ballon d'or award, instead of cristiano ronaldo, the 2014 winner. ronaldo received a vote from wayne rooney, england's captain. manuel neuer, another top contender, was third. hodgson also favored germany's philipp lahm and manuel neuer for the award. mascherano, who played with hodgson at liverpool, was also picked by belarus head coach alyaksandr khatskevich.
23	tel aviv, a city in israel, is a modern and increasingly popular destination for culture lovers. it offers attractions like modernist architecture, galleries, museums, theaters, music, and bars for tourists seeking sun, nightlife, and artistic experiences. visitors can explore the white city, a unesco world heritage site, and enjoy clement weather, tolerance, and a variety of food and accommodation options.
24	nike has removed tattoo-style leggings called pro tattoo tech tights from its collection due to criticism from australia and new zealand residents who accused the sports brand of exploiting and offending pacific cultures. the design is too similar to samoan pe'a male tattoos, causing controversy among communities. nike withdrew the leggings and released a statement apologising for any insensitivity. some online users disagree with the opinion and find the leggings to be offensive, while others believe it's important to share cultures for understanding.
25	a senior conservative mp, eleanor laing, has been criticized for spending £2,270 of taxpayers' money on black dresses for work as a deputy house of commons speaker. other politicians must purchase their own clothes, and her bill was nearly double that spent on costumes for the associate serjeant-at-arms, £1,282.50. commons spokesperson defenses that the items are expected to last for a number of years.
26	a new strain of highly contagious bird flu has emerged in china, causing 11 deaths and 4 more likely fatalities. the h7n9 bird flu has affected 11 people so far and previously showed no symptoms in humans. this new strain has the potential to turn into a pandemic, but the chinese government is working on controlling the outbreak's spread. vietnam has banned imported chinese poultry, and hong kong and japan are implementing safety precautions. health authorities worldwide have monitored and analyzed samples related to this case to determine if the virus could transmit between humans.
27	this weekend, motorcycle enthusiasts from all over the country will flock to daytona beach, florida, marking the largest motorcycle event in the country during the "bike week." despite the economic recession, bikers still enjoy soaking up sunshine and revving up their engines for the ten-day event. daytona beach's special events generate about $1.3 billion every year, with the two biker events alone contributing $650 million. bike week and biketoberfest have managed to draw in nearby communities, giving participants more events to attend and places to go. despite possible tensions from the 1% of gang problems in 1988, the event has become a successful and family-friendly event that caters to a wide demographic of people.
28	talented photographer danny beath won a national award for a stunning image of a lightning strike, but tragically collapsed and died of a heart attack three weeks before receiving the news. despite never winning the prestigious travel photo contest before, his incredible photo of a storm over poppy fields in blackstone nature reserve in the severn valley took first prize in this year's contest.
29	the liberal democrat conference was hit by high winds and increasing tension within the party. supporters demanded a power-sharing deal with labour after the next election, while party leader nick clegg hinted he would prefer a coalition with the tories. clegg argued that if the main parties remained in control alone, it would risk a recovery that is neither fair nor sustainable. he stated "we should finish the job, but finish it fairly," suggesting more coalitions in the future. clegg also called for higher taxes on the wealthy to help pay for the ongoing deficit reduction, although this was criticized by former mp chris huhne's ex-wife, vicky pryce.
30	the former headmaster of durand academy in london earned £390,000 and a leisure centre was run from his school. sir greg martin, alongside being the school's executive head, directed a dating website from the site and received various high salaries. parliamentarians criticized his role in operating multiple businesses and running a leisure centre. the head master pointed out that this infrastructure positively impacted the students' experiences at the school.
31	a woman with google glass was pulled over by police in san diego and was fined for using it while driving. she has been cited for 'driving with monitor visible to driver (google glass)'. google glass is a wearable display that can produce information, but currently, the law prohibits drivers from operating vehicles while a similar display is visible to the driver.
32	at a young age, manchester united is bringing in talented players who may become the future legends of old trafford. this club has always trusted young players dating back to the days of matt busby. in the past, sir alex ferguson has also followed in these footsteps, allowing young talent to shine on the first team. however, it will be under the responsibility of louis van gaal, who has a history of developing young players. despite having a reputation of being arrogant, demanding, and a disciplinarian, van gaal may be a better fit for the teenagers chosen by gareth gigs in his last home game as interim manager. van gaal is known for his track record of nurturing young talent, which he has demonstrated in previous clubs such as barcelona and bayern munich. this philosophy suggests that he will give many young players an opportunity to showcase their skills at the highest level. the potential for greatness has emerged in manchester united's roster, and it will be exciting to see these players grow and become integral contributors to the club's future success.
33	maria sharapova defeated eugenie bouchard in a three-set match to secure her third consecutive french open final appearance, securing another victory in an 18th consecutive deciding set on clay. bouchard, 20, demonstrated her impressive mental strength and improved aggressive gameplay, striking first with the break to lead 2-1, but sharapova fought back to level the set and subsequently the match. with a stronghold on her serve, sharapova clinched the set with another display of her prowess in deciding and pivotal points, moving forward and sealing a french open final appearance for the third time in a row.
34	florida osteopath dr. daniel mcbath, accused of drugging and sexually assaulting at least three female patients, has died of a heart attack two months after being banned from treating female patients. mcbath's license was restricted following the allegations. he is survived by his wife, two daughters, and a son. although no arrests were made, mcbath was prevented from treating patients due to the allegations.
35	according to a study by aston university's pharmacy school, nearly one-third of patients are not taking their medication properly, potentially putting their health and the nhs at risk. fears about side effects and poor understanding of doctor instructions were found to be the main reasons for non-adherence. the aston medication adherence study analyzed over one million prescriptions and found that certain ethnic groups, those aged over 60, and those living in poor inner-city areas face difficulties with medication adherence. the study also recommends that healthcare systems take individual patient's first language into account when offering advice on medication for long-term conditions.
36	the us air force conducted an unmanned drone test flight with an f-16 fighter jet, which had been retrofitted by boeing into the qf-16 full-scale aerial target. this technology allows for realistic training situations against a more contemporary and high-performing aircraft, as opposed to an older model used prior. with a pilot-less test flight, the qf-16 will now be utilized for live-fire testing at holloman air force base in new mexico, and will also be utilized for general aerial training, as boeing has modified six f-16s into the qf-16 drone configuration.
37	a second person in vermont, scott sgorbati, has died from eastern equine encephalitis (eee), a rare but deadly brain infection transmitted through mosquitoes. eee is fatal in humans in a third of cases, and deaths occur after mosquitoes carry the virus into the human body. the state of vermont has reported only six cases per year on average. dr. harry chen, vermont's health commissioner, emphasizes that the disease remains extremely rare. avoidance of mosquitoes, the use of long sleeves and bug repellants, and being cautious around mosquito-infested areas at dawn and dusk can help protect against the disease.
38	prince william and harry are highly competitive on the polo field but when they win, prince william goes home to his family while prince harry wants to celebrate with drinks. australian polo player, alec white, who shares a close friendship with the royal family after playing with the princes at ascot, described prince harry as more fierce while on the polo field.
39	the miami dolphins cheerleaders released a video of themselves miming taylor swift's '22' song in bikinis during a photo-shoot for their annual calendar. the team followed last year's success, in which the cheerleaders mimed carly rae jepsen's 'call me maybe'. the cheerleaders from new orleans saints also participated in the miming and bikini trend, creating a competition among nfl cheerleaders about creativity and humor in their video covers. nfl.com pronounced the saints cheerleaders as winners for their video's creativity, camera shots, and organization.
40	new york city officials are fighting against a rat infestation with the help of a group of dog owners who participate in rat hunts to control the population. the ryders alley trencher-fed society (r.a.t.s.) comprises dog owners who use their pets to catch and kill rats in the city streets. members of the group venture out at night to allow their dogs to hunt and kill vermin. the number of rats in new york could be double that of its population of 8.4 million people. to control the rodent infestation, inspectors will use traps and poison, along with community outreach.
41	england football manager roy hodgson looks to the skill and potential of raheem sterling in a crucial match against switzerland, which holds strategic importance in their ongoing preparations for euro 2016. captain wayne rooney likens sterling to the former dutch midfielder marc overmars as they attempt to rebuild their team's confidence after the disappointments of the world cup in brazil. switzerland has an impressive record against england, having won 9 of their last 10 games, albeit with just one loss in their last 13 international matches home and away.
42	new orleans mayor ray nagin visited cuba on a mission to learn how to better prepare for storms, after the city of new orleans faced significant damage from hurricane katrina in 2005. new orleans has since made adjustments to its disaster response, and many believe that the communist nation's exceptional disaster management could offer valuable lessons in dealing with similar events. this marks the first official visit from a new orleans mayor to cuba in 50 years, and the trip was sanctioned by the state department.
43	ashton kutcher and demi moore, founders of the demi & ashton foundation (dna), discuss in a first-ever joint prime time interview the plight of approximately 100,000 to 300,000 child sex slaves in the us today. the pair stress the need for people to confront the issue and to take action against traffickers who prey on vulnerable girls and young women. they encourage the use of social media to mobilize support for ending child sex trafficking.
44	former australian prime minister julia gillard, speaking with diane rehm radio show, revealed she has discussed the sexism faced by female leaders including hillary clinton. she acknowledged the struggles female leaders face, such as being judged on appearance and often the only woman in the room. she also touched upon the initial approach for men to become a leader while, for women, it starts with if she can lead.
45	after a day of negotiations involving the united states, egyptian president mohamed morsy, and palestinian officials, a cease-fire was declared on wednesday, halting violence between israel and palestinians along israel's border with gaza. according to egypt's state news agency, the agreement calls for a complete and total cessation of all hostile activity initiated in the gaza strip, allowing for the opening of border crossings and eased movement of people and goods. as of now, both the palestinians and the israelis have agreed to a truce, and israel has promised to provide humanitarian aid to gaza. prime minister benjamin netanyahu has stated that israel will exhaust this opportunity to obtain a long-term ceasefire, while hamas has stated it will hold israel responsible for any attacks from gaza, whether conducted by them or by others.
46	the white house was placed on lockdown after a man attempted to jump the fence carrying two large bags. secret service apprehended the suspect, and the first daughters were not at the residence at the time. the secret service confirmed they were not concerned about the bags and followed standard protocol, which included the involvement of washington's metro police department's explosive ordinance division. despite the events, president obama was not in danger as he had already left for a trip to michigan, where he signed the new farm bill.
47	the united states believes north korea is supplying iran with long-range missiles, suggesting iran has strike capabilities stronger than discussed in public. however, russia expressed doubt on the us concern, as there was lack of evidence. the us wanted to offer further evidence at future meetings and believed iran wanted the missiles for its missile technology. despite disagreements, the us and russia continued discussing ballistic missile threats.
48	manchester united midfielder adnan januzaj has been given ryan giggs' famous number 11 shirt for next season, but louis van gaal fuelled speculation of more summer signings by leaving three first-team numbers unfilled. 
49	james rodriguez and radamel falcao, members of colombia's national football team, have an unprecedented connection that stems from their fathers having played together in their youth for a professional colombian team called deportes tolima. this unique bloodline partnership might explain why they work so well together on the field, especially during their successful 2014 world cup performance and last season's partnership under monaco. their shared heritage makes forging a lethal partnership at international level for colombia less daunting, despite james rodriguez now playing for real madrid in the champions league and falcao at manchester united on loan.
50	cockroaches, known for their resilience, could be transformed into biobots to help find survivors in disaster situations like earthquakes. scientists have equipped the roaches with electrical backpacks containing microphones, allowing them to detect and follow faint sounds, like human voices calling for help. the technology could also allow biobots to create an "invisible fence" to keep them within a specified area and serve as a mobile wireless network for communication.
51	in china, while seven of the world's top 10 wealthiest self-made women are chinese, women face pressure, under-representation, and threats. abortion policies led to a surplus of men, and women struggle to gain equal rights in economics, politics, and single life. feminist activists, government officials, and extraordinary individuals are fighting for the development of gender equality across china. the success of chinese women may be extraordinary, but their voices need to be amplified to support women nationwide.
52	yaya sanogo scores his first arsenal goal after 18 months, 19 appearances, and 73 seconds. alexis sanchez follows with a goal before the match is secured. arsenal defeats borussia dortmund with a 2-0 score, marking a turning point for the team's group position in the champions league.
53	a southern california woman allegedly drugged her husband, cut off his penis, and threw it into the garbage disposal in a violent fit of anger related to their ongoing divorce, leading to her arrest. she has been charged with aggravated mayhem, false imprisonment, assault with a deadly weapon, administering a drug with intent to commit a felony, poisoning, and spousal abuse.
54	hillary clinton said she "misspoke" about her arrival in bosnia, as she recounted seeing sniper fire, after video footage contradicted her assertion that her group "ran with our heads down" from the plane to avoid sniper fire. during an editorial board meeting, clinton was responding to a question about video footage of the event. obama's campaign later used the claim as an example of her exaggerating her role in foreign and domestic policymaking. 
55	more than a month after the airliner they were traveling on was shot out of the skies above eastern ukraine, the bodies of 20 malaysian passengers arrived back in kuala lumpur as malaysia observed a national day of mourning. the victims' families gathered at the kuala lumpur international airport for the repatriation ceremony with prime minister najib razak and the king of malaysia, as specialized malaysian airlines personnel unloaded the caskets from the flight's arrival into waiting white hearses. malaysian armed forces members carried the caskets from the planes, and the country observed a moment of silence for the victims.
56	the video shows two reckless drivers on the m5 exchanging drinks while driving at speeds of around 60mph. the dangerous stunt has been condemned by road safety campaigners who believe that it could have led to a near-collision. police are currently examining the footage and will be contacting the registered keepers of the vehicles about the matter.
57	arizona's strict immigration law, which mandates carrying alien registration documents and requires police to question people suspected of being in the country illegally, has passed both houses of state legislature. the legislation has drawn both support and criticism, with aclu and immigrant advocates worried about racial profiling, while supporters expect republican governor jan brewer will sign the measure.
58	newly obtained materials from osama bin laden's compound in pakistan have confirmed that the al qaeda leader was in communication with the yemen-based group al qaeda in the arabian peninsula. it is unclear whether the messages were received or acted upon. the united states is still determining whether american-born yemeni cleric anwar al-awlaki, leader of al qaeda in the arabian peninsula, was in direct contact with bin laden or played a role in the group's plotting of attacks on the u.s. and europe.
59	professor les ebden emphasizes admitting undergraduates based on "academic potential" rather than solely considering gcses and a-levels when recruiting. the head of office for fair access (offa) has intervened at 26 universities with the intention of raising targets for recruiting underprivileged students.
60	hillary clinton called for obtaining economic equality for women to become a political movement during a roundtable at the center for american progress and emphasized making these issues an integral part of political debates, particularly for the upcoming midterm elections. this strategy comes as clinton considers running for president in 2016, focusing attention on the importance of women's involvement in politics and creating a unified movement for change.
61	severe flooding in bangkok, thailand, threatened the capital's central areas on saturday. after months of flooding, over 1 million residents had left the city by then. runoff from the north was entering the city via its many canals, and high tide posed additional threats. health concerns arose as floodwater entered homes, leading to panic buying, shortages of food, and medicines. the government had set up emergency centers and evacuated elderly residents, transferring patients to upcountry hospitals. the floods caused by heavy monsoon rains had killed 373 people nationwide and affected more than 9.5 million others. the government estimated the overall damage from the floods could exceed $6 billion.
62	two naked women, one blonde and one brunette, attended different university halloween parties and their photographs were posted on twitter, leading to widespread public debate. the photographs were first posted on the unofficial asu confessions account and later re-tweeted by one user to @amandajanson4, who posted the picture first. while some appreciated their boldness, others criticized the photos as inappropriate and questioned why the offense was not considered public indecency.
63	a group of american graduate students endured seasickness, hypothermia, and strong currents in a 16-hour swim across the english channel to raise money for veterans. they swam approximately 23 miles wearing speedos and swim caps covering most of their skin, slathered with petroleum jelly, against temperatures nearing 55 degrees fahrenheit and swells reaching 6-7 feet. the group, consisting of two rhodes scholars and three naval academy graduates who will enter seal training after school, successfully completed their journey to raise $5,000 for the nonprofit mission continues, which enables wounded and disabled veterans to pursue service and leadership roles in their communities after returning from combat.
64	a fight between two female traffic wardens broke out in tangshan, china, during rush hour as they were supposed to be directing traffic. the officers slapped, punched, and grabbed each other's hair while on a pedestrian crossing, before another female officer intervened to stop the assault. the women were fired due to their unprofessional behavior, as they were part-time employees assisting the police with traffic direction.
65	hannah bowness-major, a 13-year-old from cheshire, suffers from a rare condition called addison's disease. this rare condition affects her adrenal glands, which makes it difficult for her to regulate her cortisol levels. as a result, if her cortisol levels drop too low, she is at risk of fainting or collapsing due to an adrenal crisis. in addition to taking daily medication to help manage her condition, hannah is allergic to various foods and antibiotics which can make her very ill. as her condition can be life-threatening, her family is raising funds to help her have a hydrocortisone pump fitted to provide her with the constant supply of cortisol she needs.
66	jordan spieth is a 20-year-old golfer who made a quick start to his pga career, winning the rookie of the year award in 2013. he is being mentioned in the same breath as tiger woods due to his multiple wins in college golf and his u.s. junior amateur championships. in 2014, spieth became one of cnn's "five players to watch." he is considered highly talented and will continue to be an influential force in the golf world.
67	researchers from greece have developed a robotic octopus, which can travel at speeds of up to 25mph in water, inspired by the natural movements of real octopuses. it uses webbed arms and a streamlined head for propulsion. early experiments using thinner, silicon arms were less efficient, so the scientists added webs to increase speed. the robot crawls through the water in a tank, and could be used to monitor fish numbers and marine environments.
68	barry lewis, a father of two who became a youtube sensation by filming himself as he taught himself to cook, has been announced as the new face of a sainsbury's campaign. lewis, 32, from weston-super-mare, somerset, did not know how to poach an egg five years ago and started filming himself in his kitchen as he taught himself to cook with his daughter phoebe, now six. now, the married father of two has over 10 million views, 150,000 subscribers, a bestselling cookbook, and has featured on jamie oliver's food tube channel. the former quantity surveyor is now aiming to quit his full-time job as a quantity surveyor to pursue his newfound career full-time. 
69	thomas hare, a young british actor, also known by the stage name tommy vine, was found dead in a river in cambodia. he was 25 years old and had been last seen swimming in the mekong river in kampot province. hare was originally from bristol and lived in london, where he studied at the arts educational theatre school. he had appeared in television series and stage productions. friends and colleagues shared their tributes to his talent and personality online.
70	a massachusetts couple is facing manslaughter charges for reportedly giving their 5-month-old daughter a bottle of formula containing heroin, resulting in her death in september 2011. ryan barry, 30, and ashley cyr, 26, both of quincy, were arrested and pleaded not guilty. mya barry, their daughter, died when the family lived in marshfield. investigators found heroin and syringes in the room where the couple and their three children slept. barry claimed heroin may have entered the formula when someone cleaned a syringe in the water bottle, while cyr allegedly used heroin during pregnancy.
71	janelle monae is a unique and innovative artist blending the past and future in her creativity. she is a synthesis of her own identity and character, cindi mayweather, an android traveler searching for love and inspiration in her journey through space and time. as she captures the spotlight and makes music that defies conventional descriptions, her performances incorporate dance moves from the future, paying homage to those who have come before her. with the aid of sean "diddy" combs and partnerships with notable brands like coca-cola and appearances on shows like "american idol" finale and "stargate universe," monae's star is rising, and she's sure to create a lasting impression on the world of music.
72	u.s. student amanda knox and her former italian boyfriend raffaele sollecito are awaiting a verdict from an italian court for the 2007 murder of british student meredith kercher. knox has been back home in seattle since being acquitted in 2011. if found guilty, italy may request her extradition from the united states.
73	anthony, the son of a kayaker who drowned in the river tyne, almost lost his life two years ago in the same river. two kayakers and their cousin died when their kayaking trip on swollen tyne turned disastrous in dangerous conditions prompting the local canoe club to postpone an excursion due to safety concerns. the trio last saw each other at a spot called "devil's water" on sunday night. their kayaks, "sit on" styles commonly used by leisure trippers, were recovered as part of an investigation.
74	a uk tory mp is being sued by the expenses watchdog for not paying £54,000 over an alleged increase in value of his taxpayer-funded second home. stewart jackson, mp for peterborough, is the sole member of a group of 29 mps who have refused this demand by the independent parliamentary standards authority. in a case related to capital gain, mps faced criticism, as over 70 mps have agreed to repay a total of £484,828, for profits made in selling their second homes with taxpayer-funded mortgage subsidies. stewart jackson argues his constituency home’s value has fallen, and has refused to pay.
75	over the past two decades, uk rail fares have nearly trebled, with some open return tickets costing more than the price of a family vacation. the study found that between 1995 and 2015, fares on popular routes rose by between 141% and 246%, while inflation increased by 77%. this has led to driving or flying being cheaper options for trips, even for solo journeys.
76	after the sandy hook elementary school tragedy in 2012, the surviving children are now returning to school in monroe, connecticut, at a former middle school building known as chalk hill, renovated shortly after the shootings in newtown. the school's design for the new building will be funded with a $750,000 grant from the state of connecticut, and the referendum will allow voters to decide whether or not to approve plans for the remaining $50 million for the construction of the new school. they aim for it to be open by september 2016.
77	actor victor spinetti, known for his roles in all three beatles films and a string of acclaimed movies, has died at the age of 82. spinetti also appeared as an actor and director in various stage productions and tv series. his work with joan littlewood on stage, such as 'fings ain't wot they used t'be,' transferred to new york, winning a tony award for his role.
78	on july 17, 2014, malaysia airlines flight 17 crashed, resulting in the death of 298 people. the crash occurred due to the downing of the aircraft, and it has sparked a political tension between ukraine and russia, both claiming responsibility for the attack. as the international community mourns the loss, immediate, thorough, competent, and independent investigations should be handled by the dutch safety board, headed by tjibbe joustra, a former career politician and current national coordinator for security and counterterrorism. the safety, security, and transparency of the event's investigation site needs to be ensured to secure evidence and properly determine the cause and who is responsible behind the attack. this event raises a concern about global aviation safety, and the world is called to support a transparent and independent investigation to ensure the safety of commercial airlines and global commerce.
79	harold knapke and his wife ruth, who were married for 66 years, passed away just 11 hours apart at the age of 91 and 89, respectively. they spent their lives deeply devoted to one another as husband and wife, and their children described their final act of love as a touching conclusion to their long, enduring relationship. ruth and harold originally met when they were young students in the same elementary school in ohio, separated only by a distance when harold's family moved to another town. following world war ii, the two were reunited when ruth's brother-in-law suggested that harold write to her, and their lifelong romance began from there.
80	a study released by the vision council revealed that nearly 70% of american adults suffer from eye strain caused by computers, tablets, and smartphones. half of adults are unaware they can reduce digital eye strain discomfort. the strain can cause headaches, blurred vision, and back pain after only two hours of use. research suggests that exposure to digital screen light may lead to cataracts and macular degeneration. ways to reduce digital eye strain include positioning screens at arm's length, holding handheld devices below eye-level, and taking short breaks from screens. the optical industry has made strides in developing lens technologies that best address the causes of digital eye strain.
81	mark cavendish, a british sprint cyclist, is renowned as "the fastest man on two wheels" and has won 25 tour de france stages. to succeed in sprint cycling, cavendish emphasizes competitiveness, embracing uniqueness, training the brain, trusting his team, having a photographic memory, and being inspired by naysayers.
82	in october 2013, a woman was shocked when she was told she looked like michelle mcmanus, an overweight pop idol singer. this motivated her to lose weight, and she and her sister agreed to join a weight loss program. the sisters lost 12 stone between them and have never been happier with their appearances.
83	a woman was caught on cctv removing charity donations from a bin in an oxfordshire village and replaced them with her own rubbish, intending to make room for the donated clothing. the brazen act was perpetrated during the season of goodwill and the stolen clothes were intended for a good cause. parish councillors hope clear photos will help identify the woman, who they believe could cost the county's air ambulance service significant funds by continuing to misuse collection bins for charity donations.
84	several uk members of parliament have launched a bid to have 'black friday' discounts scrapped, as they believe the discounts are linked to chaotic scenes of disorder during the shopping event. the initiative is supported by three mps who, in a commons motion, cite police officers and shoppers suffering injuries from these incidents. the mps are calling on uk retailers to not mark 'black friday' in 2015 or beyond.
85	residents of a rural village are opposing plans to build the uk's largest muslim cemetery on 11 acres of land in catherine-de-barnes, west midlands. the site would include 11,000 burial plots, more than doubling the current capacity at the uk's largest muslim-only cemetery in ilford. the proposed cemetery would adhere to islamic law, with a separate section for each follower and compliance with traditional islamic practices. the cemetery, which would also include 95 parking spaces, faced 160 objections and 180 representations of support at its initial application stage, and will be reviewed by local planning officials.
86	the piece discusses the 2005 presidential election in egypt, which was won by ousted president hosni mubarak amid allegations of fraud. scenario in 2011 sees more political options but still limited to the status quo or islamist candidates, with ex-foreign minister and arab league secretary general amre moussa or ex-civil aviation minister ahmed shafik representing the former, and muslim brotherhood candidates mohamed morsi or abdelmonen abdul fotoh representing the latter. the article also highlights concerns over the potential takeover of the military by the brotherhood and its potential consequences on the future of egypt.
87	one of america's most wanted terrorists, omar hammami, along with a british bomb-maker, habib ghani, were killed in a gun battle in somalia, according to reports. hammami, 29, was known for his jihadi rap videos posted on youtube and was on the fbi's most wanted terror list. ghani, also known as osama al-britani, was a key ally of samantha lewthwaite, who married one of the london 7/7 bombers, and has british citizenship. both terrorists were on the run with the widow of a london 7/7 bomber and had fallen out with their militant group, al-shabab.
88	health secretary kathleen sebelius stated that "definitely on track" to fix the problem-plagued obamacare website; there have been improvements and fixes are being done to the site. while there were issues at the beginning of the website's launch, the goal is to have a vastly improved user experience by the end of the month, as promised.
89	martin middleton, aged 26, pleaded guilty to causing an explosion at bolton crown court and will be sentenced later in the year. a man lost several fingers after a home-made pipe bomb exploded, requiring 40 homes to be evacuated. middleton will be sentenced under the explosive substances act 1883.
90	rihanna, known for her constantly changing looks and sparking trends, recently used a chin-length blonde wig and a bowler hat in the music video for her single "you da one," which appears to have been inspired by a clockwork orange. the singer also received four grammy award nominations for her work, including best rap/sung performance, album of the year, song of the year, and best pop vocal album.
91	two officers from the uk's national crime agency (nca) are accused of unlawfully obtaining sensitive information by using their positions; sheila roberts and brian adair, have been arrested and charged with data protection crimes. the nca was established last year to combat serious and organised crime in the uk and reportedly has a £450 million budget.
92	rabbit-owning best friends megan hull and jessica brown found their pets helped them battle post-natal depression. the tiny lionhead and mini lop rabbit breeds have become the unlikely saviours for the mothers-of-three, who bonded over their love of animals and decided to start breeding rabbits as a hobby. at around $250 each, these bunnies bring joy to families across the uk, as well as helping the pair grow stronger connections with one another and improving their mental health.
93	this article features a photo series from a coursing event in ireland, where greyhounds chased hares through the course. despite the dogs' speed and determination, the hares escaped, showcasing their quick wits and agility. the event took place at the jp mcmanus irish cup coursing event, with the first-place prize being 80,000 euros.
94	the u.s. justice department is reviewing a request from 13 states on how to acquire an execution drug that's no longer being made in the u.s. and whether the federal government will share its supplies. the sole u.s. producer of sodium thiopental, an anesthetic used in executions, announced it would stop making the drug, raising concerns over the country's death penalty procedures.
95	actress gwyneth paltrow is among a growing list of celebrities spotted with chanel’s graffiti-inspired handbags. valued at $3,800 for the tote version and $3,400 for a smaller backpack, the bag’s distressed, handmade appearance has received mixed reviews. despite criticism from some consumers, fans of the style, such as miley cyrus, kristen stewart and diane kruger, showcase the backpack in various styling options.
96	babycastles in brooklyn is a vibrant independent video game arcade and gallery that is dedicated to pushing the limits of gaming and technology. the arcade features games designed by young developers from around the world, sometimes made on aging computers, which are played on old-school cabinets in a colorful setting that often transcends gaming. babycastles is not only a unique venue but also aims to provide an economy for independent game developers outside the large studios, similar to what supports indie musicians.
97	a new card called "marriage: it's your choice" is being distributed to schools, airports, and gps surgeries in the uk to help prevent teenagers from being taken abroad during summer holidays and forced into marriage against their will. the government has had more than 400 cases of forced marriage reported between june and august last year, while 1,485 cases were reported for the entire year. crime prevention minister jeremy browne hopes this new program can prevent an abuse of human rights and is working on legislation that would make forced marriage illegal next year.
98	uk prime minister david cameron and his wife samantha visited a children's center in washington dc to show support and talk with staff and their patients. the center provides services for children and adults with developmental disabilities and was chosen for the visit because of their experience with caring for their late son, ivan, who passed away aged six due to rare conditions. cameron and samantha were impressed with the work of the center and spent time with the patients.
99	notorious australian pest peter hore has been banned from attending the g20 summit in brisbane after creating disruptions at public events for years. he has a long history of interruptions and protesting, even storming a corruption hearing recently. hore revealed he had planned to walk naked across the brisbane gateway bridge while holding cats on leashes when world leaders descended on the event; however, his plan was thwarted by police, who handed him a letter signed by queensland's commissioner of police telling him not to attend.
100	former north korean spy won jeong-hwa, now in her 40s, lives in a small south korean town after finishing a five-year espionage sentence. although she had been stealing sex secrets for kim jong-il, she is now struggling to find work in her new country. employers have fired her after discovering her past career due to stigma surrounding the sexual nature of her crimes. won had been attempting to conceal her past but has found it difficult to find work related to her previous career or in an ordinary job.
101	a group of 47 republican senators voted against a measure that would have allowed the paycheck fairness act to go to a full vote in the senate. terri kelly, a married mother of three boys in memphis, emphasized that the paycheck fairness act should not be a partisan issue and supports its potential benefits for fair and transparent pay practices in the workplace.
102	scientists found radon gas from nearby soviet-era uranium mines seeping up to the surface and poisoning residents in a kazakhstan village called "sleepy hollow." radon is thought to cause lung cancer and has affected around 20% of the village's population. local government officials are considering plans to move the whole village due to the risk but some residents remain skeptical about the cause.
103	heavy rains have subsided in parts of northwestern pakistan, allowing aid to reach millions of people affected by the flooding, which has killed more than 1,500 people and displaced 3 million. the floodwaters have destroyed thousands of homes, crushed many bridges, and left people without electricity, further hindering relief efforts. the pakistani prime minister is calling on citizens to contribute to relief efforts and avoid festive spending during ramadan and independence day celebrations.
104	a scottish cancer patient, maureen fleming, and her husband are considering relocating to england in hopes of gaining access to life-extending cancer drugs. fleming has been denied the drug cetuximab in scotland due to its high nhs price tag. in england, the drug is available through the nhs at no charge.
105	this amazing 400-year-old medieval castle in rural australia, dubbed 'castambul castle,' was completed in 2008, offering its modern-day inhabitants a unique blend of medieval and contemporary living. with seven bedrooms, ornate chandeliers, suits of armor, and stunning ceiling paintings, the castle has captured the imaginations of people from around the world with its elegant, fairy tale touches, gorgeous design, and its luxurious features. located just a 35-minute drive from adelaide's cbd, the stunning property is currently available for the first time, offering its future owner an extraordinary lifestyle experience, a business opportunity, or a unique destination for weddings and wine-tasting events.
106	the uk has been experiencing its largest cherry harvest ever, with trees bending beneath the weight of their deep red fruit. farmers are currently harvesting at daylight hours in kent and herefordshire, due in part to an initiative to revive british cherry farming. as a result of good weather conditions and the revival, the cherry-growing season is expected to be worth £20 million, nearly triple that of 2012, and last much longer than usual. the harvest has generated significant interest from consumers and supermarkets, particularly since a renewed emphasis on locally grown food.

108	a poignant image of a mother cuddling her three-year-old son with cancer has gained much attention on social media, as the boy has since recovered from cancer and turned five years old. the now five-year-old boy, aiden, had cancer that developed in his kidneys while he was still in the womb. after the tumor was discovered, aiden had surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy, following which he made a full recovery and turned five years old. aiden's mother, ariane grabill, has become increasingly aware of inspiring other mothers who may be going through similar situations, and is now a board member for the ask childhood cancer foundation.

119	marine veteran jon hammar, 27, has been held captive in mexico’s most infamous prison for four months. a photo of the shackled hammar has been released to the public, showing him in his solitary cell with a red blanket on his thin mattress. he was arrested and thrown into the northeastern mexico prison back in august, when he was subjected to death threats. hammar and a friend were arrested after crossing the mexican border with surfboards and camping gear; the shotgun they were carrying did not belong to them. hammar’s attorneys are working to get the charges downgraded, and he could face 12 years in prison.
120	nancy lanza, the mother of adam lanza, was a friendly and outgoing person. she was known for her affinity for guns and was a responsible gun owner, having taken her son to the shooting range to teach him proper gun safety. however, when adam lanza committed a massacre at sandy hook elementary school in newtown, connecticut, resulting in the deaths of 20 children and six adults, his family and neighbors were left wondering how this tragedy could have occurred despite nancy's seemingly loving and affectionate nature towards her son.
121	on the 45th anniversary of the lunar landing, the astronaut neil armstrong shared his experiences walking on the moon, stating the importance of human unity and future exploration, particularly focusing on space missions beyond discovery and developing re-usability. armstrong suggests that the us should focus on permanent human presence on mars instead of returning to the moon, using this as a way to maintain their leadership role in deep space exploration.
122	ray rodda, a 61-year-old father with throat cancer, is set to undergo a 13-hour surgery that will remove his voice box, tongue, and glands in his throat. having already gone through chemotherapy and radiotherapy, he will be unable to make sounds upon recovery from the operation. to avoid losing his voice completely, ray has recorded numerous messages on an ipad to communicate with his family, including his beloved dog, daisy. these commands are meant to keep his canine companion and family close even after the surgery when ray will be speaking through his ipad as a text-to-speech computer voice. 
123	a judge sentenced self-help expert james arthur ray to two years in prison for his role in the deaths of three people in a 2009 sweat lodge ceremony in the arizona desert. the judge imposed three two-year terms to be served concurrently, after prosecutors had sought consecutive three-year sentences for negligent homicide. ray's attorneys asked for probation, but the judge stated the evidence showed "extreme negligence" on ray's part. during the trial, prosecutors argued that ray's recklessness caused the deaths of three participants in the sweat lodge ceremony, causing serious harm to at least 15 others. the lodge was heated to a high temperature, contributing to dehydration and heatstroke among those involved.
124	tennessee law requires whiskey to be made from mash of at least 51% corn, aged in new charred oak barrels, filtered through maple charcoal, and bottled at a minimum of 80 proof. state lawmakers are considering modifying the law to make it easier for craft distilleries to label their spirits as tennessee whiskey, a move opposed by jack daniel's and brown-forman. jack daniel's asserts that the hand of diageo, the british conglomerate that owns george dickel, another tennessee whiskey made nearby, could be at play in the proposal.
125	a tennessee woman, 37-year-old catherine goins, has been charged with murder for allegedly luring a 30-year-old mother named natalia roberts from georgia to her death in a twisted plot to kidnap her two children and claim them as her own. law enforcement officials held a press conference, charging goins and stating that she murdered the young mother and shot her in the back of the head. goins has been accused of lying about being pregnant and calling the police, claiming she shot an intruder. however, her home invasion story was later discovered to be false, as goins allegedly murdered the victim.
126	labour party has stated that in a vote on amendments to the government's welfare reform bill, they will support a proposed £500 weekly limit on welfare benefits as long as there are safeguards to prevent homelessness from happening. if these conditions are not met, the labour party could vote against the government in the parliament. opposition leader david cameron defended the government's policy, arguing that it's "basic issue of fairness" and that people should not receive more benefits than they can earn through work. the church of england bishops and liberal rebels are threatening to derail the government's plans in its flagship welfare reform bill.

132	a council in lincolnshire has spent £42,000 of taxpayers' money on shuttling workers to a nearby call centre, covering a 524ft distance, and spent an additional £7,000 each year for six years in taxis. the council justifies the expense, maintaining that its duty of care includes safety concerns raised by employees. the issue has highlighted concerns about how other public authorities spend taxpayers' money.
133	the church of england has voted to allow women to become bishops, ending 14 years of debate and controversy within the institution. the decision was reached by an overwhelming majority at the church of england’s general synod meeting in york, and was warmly welcomed by the archbishop of canterbury, justin welby. the move resolves a longstanding issue that has divided the church of england, with many traditionalists opposed to the idea of female priests and bishops and fearing interference from politicians. while there are still opponents to the decision, the church of england now anticipates the appointment of its first female bishop early in the new year.

135	children in america face educational detriment during the summer due to summer slide and the increased achievement gap between poor and wealthy students. providing students with more days in school, particularly in low-income areas, helps maintain learning gains while closing the achievement gap.

140	a magnitude 7.4 earthquake struck off the coast of el salvador, near the southeast of the capital, san salvador, leading to a tsunami warning. the quake took place nearly 33 miles underground and caused minor shaking but no reports of destruction or injuries. el salvador is known as the "ring of fire", an area susceptible to frequent earthquakes and volcanic eruptions.

142	a dramatic video showcases the rebirth of israel's zin river after a period of drought, where a flash flood sends powerful gushing water over the edge of a cliff, delighting spectators who gathered to watch and snap photos. the flood is believed to occur when heavy rain falls in nearby mountainous regions and is mentioned in the old testament of the bible. the river's source is located upon the slopes of the ramon crater, one of three negev craters known for geological formations, and it eventually flows into the dead sea.

144	a judge has ruled that a mother serving life in prison for murder must be allowed to visit her children regularly, even though the father opposes this move and wants to leave the country with them. the judge has ordered the father to take his children from california to iowa to visit the mother while she remains in prison for executing her neighbour 11 years ago. the judge claims that the children hold a "long, positive history" with their mother and believe visiting her will "bring closure to the traumatic events of the past year," during which the mother was arrested and convicted of the killing.
145	the $1.012 trillion spending bill reached by republicans and democrats in washington aims to roll back some spending cuts, raise federal worker pay and will have a significant impact on everyday lives of americans. the measure sets a priority for national and international spending, with federal workers and military personnel receiving a 1% pay raise. the deal includes a $1 billion increase in head start funding and funding increases for mental health programs. additionally, republicans were pleased with funding cuts to the irs and the epa, while democrats appreciated the increase in head start funding. details of the $1 trillion spending bill include changes at airports for faster security screenings and an end to the gradual phase-out of incandescent light bulbs.

147	comedian stephen colbert's attempt to influence wikipedia pages on possible mitt romney vice presidential candidates backfired when the site locked the majority of those pages, allowing only experienced users to make changes. editors noticed a correlation between the number of edits to candidates' pages and their likelihood of being chosen as romney's running mate, leading to colbert encouraging his viewers to edit the pages in an attempt to sway the outcome.
148	wealthy buyers have snapped up almost all the luxury 220 apartments in a $250 million steel and glass development block in sydney in just a few hours on the day they went on sale. the properties, including four penthouses, went on the market in sydney, jakarta, and singapore. 95% of one, two, and three-bedroom apartments were sold within four hours, and the 27th-floor penthouses sold out within one hour. the development will be complete by december 2017 and will be located in the heart of sydney's city center, with residents enjoying rooftop entertainment areas, indoor swimming pools, fitness centers, and shops and restaurants at ground level.
149	a 24-year-old texas man named enrique arochi was arrested and faces an aggravated kidnapping charge in connection with the disappearance of a 23-year-old woman, christina morris. morris was last seen with arochi in a parking garage on august 30, and dna evidence linked to arochi's vehicle was towed as part of the investigation. the specific details about morris' fate remain unclear, but authorities believe there is evidence indicating arochi's involvement. arochi's bail has been set at $1 million and he previously expressed disbelief over the situation, claiming that authorities should focus their investigation on another person instead.
150	a family of five siblings was born on february 20 with different years, and as a joke, their parents celebrate this day every year with lots of cakes. in 1977, the family's unique situation led to their guinness world records recognition as the only verified record of a family with five children sharing the same birthdate. although they haven't celebrated together in years, they still make an effort to celebrate each other during their birthday.
151	on cbs's "the bold and the beautiful," ronn moss, who plays the role of ridge forrester, will be temporarily written out of the show. after his last episode, the character will not be "dead" but "not in the picture." moss will return to the show later.
152	the chicago bears, 25 years after their initial post-super bowl visit to the white house was canceled because of the space shuttle challenger disaster, have been invited by president barack obama to make up for the missed visit. the team was regarded as one of the most colorful nfl teams and will visit the white house on october 7, with the 1985 team expected to include coaches mike ditka and ron rivera along with players walter "sweetness" payton and william "the fridge" perry.
153	graco and century-branded strollers are being recalled because reports of 10 full or partial fingertip amputations and one laceration were received. 11 models of strollers have a folding hinge on the side that "can pinch a child's finger, posing a laceration or amputation hazard." caregivers are advised to immediately remove the child from a stroller that begins to fold to keep their fingers from the side hinge area.
154	australian aid worker tony kirwan, 43, founded charity destiny rescue in 1999, which aims to rescue children from sex slavery. after 10 years, kirwan has rescued more than 2,000 children and aims to increase this number to 800 per year. his teams in cambodia, laos, thailand, and india help with the arrest of brothel owners, the recovery of released children, and the restoration of their lives.
155	on april 17, russian president vladimir putin expressed opposition to ukraine and the west while russian foreign minister sergey lavrov signed a conciliatory agreement in geneva with the united states, the european union, and ukraine. the geneva statement represents a major stand down by russia. however, lavrov's statement signed in geneva is ultimately nothing more than a piece of paper that could be discarded whenever the kremlin deems fit. putin continues to assert his stance in ukraine, claiming the pro-russian terrorists in the country have a right to interfere and support the fight in ukraine. putin's remarks aim to challenge ukraine's sovereignty by suggesting that ukrainians are more closely tied to russia. the document signed in geneva is important, representing a standard against which any reduction in terrorist activities in eastern ukraine and russia's behavior toward them can be measured.
156	boxing champion floyd mayweather jr. was confronted by a female customer at a south london barbershop, who did not recognize him. despite mayweather's attempts to convince the woman that he was the top name in boxing, she remained unconvinced and claimed to be familiar with mike tyson instead. the incident took place as mayweather retained his welterweight title last month by beating marcos maidana in a rematch.
157	a bomb blast occurred near a mosque in batna, algeria, killing at least 14 people and injuring 60 others, as they were waiting to see the president. the detonation occurred just before the expected arrival of president abdel-aziz bouteflika. no group has taken responsibility for the attack. algeria has faced an ongoing islamic insurgency.

159	the recent cricket test between england and sri lanka at lord's provided a thrilling game, almost resulting in a win for england. while there were moments of captain alastair cook's leadership coming under scrutiny, it cannot be denied that they nearly won and displayed excellent teamwork and skill. although england has some ways to go to revive test cricket, there were many positives throughout the match, including excellent performances by stuart broad and moeen ali. cook remains a determined leader and is hopeful for future games. as test cricket faces some challenges, the top performances in the lord's test are a step in the right direction for the sport's future.

161	a 57-year-old muslim man was attacked and stabbed outside his queens, ny mosque by a man shouting anti-muslim slurs. the assailant also bit the victim's nose and is described as a hispanic male in his 40s. ahmad bashir, the victim, was taken to a nearby hospital and treated for numerous injuries, though none life-threatening. authorities are currently investigating the incident as a hate crime, and the attacker is at large.
162	james van doren, one of the co-founders of vans, died on october 12 at his fullerton, california home, surrounded by his loved ones. he was 72 and had been suffering from cancer. van doren and his older brother paul started the vans brand of shoes in the 1960s out of their family rubber company. vans canvas shoes became very popular with the skateboarding community in southern california due to their non-slip design, and the brand rose in prominence when sean penn wore a checkered pair of vans in the 1982 film "fast times at ridgemont high." today, vans continues to be a favorite of celebrities, and despite bumps along the road, it remains a dominant force in the footwear and sports apparel industry.
163	debenhams becomes the first high-street retailer to introduce permanently size 16 mannequins, marking a significant step forward in promoting body confidence. the uk fashion store trialled the mannequins three years ago, and these new mannequins will be used at its shop in oxford street, london before being rolled out. the size 16 mannequins will appear alongside standard size 10 mannequins. debenhams believes that the move will help people feel more comfortable with their bodies and hopes other retailers will follow their lead.
164	u.s. army staff sergeant don nicholas, a vietnam war veteran and former marine rifleman, will turn 60 this summer and remains on active duty in afghanistan. he is fighting to re-enlist so that he can remain a soldier as long as he's physically and mentally able to fulfill his duties. nicholas has served his country for 59 years and has completed three tours: two in vietnam, and one in saigon as the north vietnam forces entered the capital. he left active duty in 1978 but joined the army reserves in 2004 and later deployed to afghanistan and iraq. despite his fear of retiring, he will be required to retire in july due to age restrictions, where he hopes to receive a commission or be commissioned to complete another tour in afghanistan.

166	a group of loyal customers and co-workers, calling themselves 'shirley's fan club,' purchased a 1992 buick lesabre for shirley ratliff, a bagel shop worker, to ease her burden of walking several miles to work every day. ratliff, diagnosed with cervical cancer, had tried to save money for a car but experienced a financial setback. shirley was moved by the gift and the gesture showed loyalty and appreciation. the group bought the car for $1,500 and donations from customers and co-workers helped contribute to the cost.

175	a stray cat in varna, bulgaria, has caught attention due to its emerald-green hue. local speculation initially claimed vandalism, but it has been later revealed that the cat sleeps on a heap of synthetic green paint. despite the cat being harmless, locals initially formed a facebook group called "punishment to the perpetrator of this criminal act," before learning the true cause. experts warn that dyeing or painting pets might bring potentially fatal consequences.

192	a mother of an asperger's sufferer killed with a single punch from lewis gill, was critical of the "soft touch" justice system in the uk after judges upheld a four-year sentence for the attacker. mrs. pamela young's son, andrew young, died after being punched in the face by gill and the sentence prompted public anger. the case is now undergoing a review, with the uk justice secretary chris grayling announcing a full review and requesting the sentencing council to look into the matter to determine whether further guidance is necessary.
193	emotional eating is a common issue for many people, with seventy percent turning to comfort food for emotional reasons. over 90% of diets fail due to slipping back into emotional eating habits. if you recognize yourself using emotional eating behaviors that comfort or treat emotional upsets, it is essential to work on changing them. food can be an easy source of emotional relief while causing further problems, leading to guilt and the feeling of being controlled by emotions. to change the patterns, one must focus on understanding the triggers and learn to control emotional eating instead of allowing the situation to continue. dr. pam spurr's book "the emotional eater's diet" is a great resource for learning to cope with emotional eating and change behaviors.
194	tory ministers plan to water down penalties for refusing to pay the £145.50 tv licence fee, considering it a 'civil matter.' this move could become a leverage in negotiations with the bbc over its charter renewal, as the broadcaster has already faced a real-terms funding cut, and the bbc has argued any further cuts may lead to programmes being lost. some 70 people a year go to prison and 180,000 people last year faced fines due to tv licence evasion.

202	burglar martin gilbert, 48, has returned to prison just six months after promising to leave his 30-year life of crime, blaming alcohol and drug addiction for his actions. before christmas, he stole jewelry and valuables from five houses and a church in his hometown newcastle, with some victims being in their 80s. he was caught on camera numerous times and was offered a "restorative justice" course during rehabilitation. this enabled victims to meet him and witness the impact of his crimes.

204	mexican police discovered almost 50 kilos of cannabis hidden in a shipment of sombreros heading to chicago, rolled into coils and concealed in the hats' crowns. the raid occurred at a courier warehouse in tlaquepaque, jalisco, where 100 packets of the drug were found. the drug traffickers had employed coffee grounds and cinnamon to mask the smell from sniffer dogs, but their plan was thwarted when border guards noticed the packages were heavy. the mexican and us authorities are investigating the sender and recipient of the drugs.

212	texas a&m demolished a section of kyle field stadium using explosives to construct additional seats for the 100,000-seat football field. the west side of the stadium will be reconstructed by the off-season, and the demolition process was completed to make way for renovation by november 27. the estimated cost of the renovations is 450 million dollars, and it will involve additional suites, premium areas, a hall of champions, and an upgraded media area. an estimated 5,000 spectators watched the sunday explosion from a nearby parking lot.
213	oklahoma city councilman chris kelley donated his kidney to owasso city councilman paul kropp, whom he had only met a few times. kelley's strong faith inspired him to make the rare organ donation surgery in a life-saving act. kropp credited the donation with saving his life, while kelley was motivation by his desire to help and feeling spiritually led to make the decision. kropp now urges anyone to get a check-up if they can, as it might save their life.
214	protests in thailand that began in march have led to a 0.3-0.5% reduction in the country's gross domestic product so far this year, with an estimated 2% impact on the economy if the situation continues. some 1,700 shops and 10 hotels in the downtown bangkok area have been affected, and the situation is also having an impact on the tourism industry, with several governments having issued travel warnings for thailand. tourism is believed to account for approximately 6% of the thai economy and employs more than 1 million people. the government still predicts thailand's economy will grow by at least 4.5% this year, overshadowing the 7% growth projected by the world bank earlier this year. however, the protests are causing foreign investors to reassess their positions in the country with $584 million in thai shares sold off in the past six sessions.
