656	a bank manager, debra cox, and her mother, carol collier, have been jailed for fleecing friends and family members of £200,000 ($250,000) to buy themselves a 'happy life'. collier, 56, received a large portion of the funds, while cox, 37, secured personal loans in the names of her extended family. the two then used the money to finance expensive holidays and other luxuries, with the fraud taking place between october 2006 and june 2010. hsbc bank has since compensated the victims of the fraud, which led to cox's dismissal from her position as a mortgage manager.
657	uk entrepreneur rob law was dealt a crushing blow when judges ruled that a rival product to his successful trunki children's suitcase does not infringe on his design rights. this marks a serious loss for the entrepreneur, as trunki is now left vulnerable to a discount competitor and may cause substantial losses to his company, magmatic ltd. 
658	comedian rufus hound faced criticism after he claimed that david cameron, the british prime minister, 'wants kids to die' as part of a healthcare reform. hound, who was presenting a show on bbc radio 4 at the time, was standing in european parliament elections on a platform of opposing nhs privatization. hound's statement was particularly concerning, given that mr. cameron's son, ivor, died at the age of six in 2009, primarily due to a condition that could not have been treated by the nhs at the time.
659	edward snowden, the former us intelligence contractor who is currently in russia, has stated that us government officials want him dead. he has revealed that he has received threats on his life in the wake of his intelligence leaking scandal. his concerns stem from various unnamed sources stating that they would not hesitate in murder, poison, or administering fake poison to snowden whilst he is on his way home to die in the shower. snowden has refused to return to the us, saying that there is "no chance" of a fair trial, but president obama's administration has continued to push for his return, with russian authorities stating that snowden is in danger due to possible us agent hits.
660	a report by the commons defence select committee reveals that there is an alarming shortage of specialist personnel in the armed forces, leaving the uk vulnerable. the military is struggling with a lack of personnel in crucial posts, including bomb disposal experts, interrogators, and electronic warfare operators. the committee has expressed major concerns and recommends that personnel with crucial skills should be offered "golden handcuff" payments to encourage them to remain in the armed forces. the ministry of defence is hoping a plan to increase the size of the territorial army will help fill vacancies. 
661	in an eviction case, a 90-year-old world war ii veteran and his 90-year-old wife who suffers from alzheimer's faced losing their home due to a no-smoking policy implemented at their low-income senior living apartment complex. andy nowicki, who won a bronze star and two purple hearts, had been smoking since the war when he received free cigarettes from the army. despite trying to quit smoking, he found it challenging to do so. the housing authority refused to make an exception for nowicki, which prompted appeals for a compromise, including the intervention of the town's mayor and a state senator serving as the nowicki's attorney for free. the case is set for a hearing on september 3.
662	international news media are facing restrictions on reporting from the israel-gaza border as israel's media prevent dozens of international journalists from entering gaza. this is due to the current operation against militant targets, leaving journalists forced to report from a hill near the border. the israeli government has stated that the restrictions were put in place to avoid interference in the military operations. however, some critics argue that these actions amount to a severe violation of press freedom.
663	a plane was hijacked in the western chinese province of xinjiang, but passengers and crew members managed to subdue the alleged hijackers, resulting in minor injuries and a safe return to the origin airport. the government intends to honor crew members and passengers who helped during the emergency and is investigating the incident.
664	thirteen tennessee juveniles escaped from the woodland hills youth development center; there have been an average of more than 1 escape per day. the latest jailbreak saw several teenagers involved in previous escape incidents, with the main cause being the upgrade of security since then. the center faces challenges in controlling inmates as guards are unarmed and lack pepper spray; they are also not allowed to lock inmates in their rooms due to court settlements.
665	inmates, including notorious serial killer rose west, at hmp low newton, a maximum security jail in the uk, were banned from using showers after gym sessions due to a string of thefts. the ban was put in place earlier this year after several prisoners, including west, complained that it left them feeling 'filthy' and 'sweaty'. inmates have signed a letter demanding the rule is overturned, claiming they deserve a shower facility as a part of their physical education.
666	the lawlessness in egypt's sinai peninsula, inhabited by 30 bedouin tribes, is drawing comparisons to the ungoverned tribal regions of pakistan and is a growing threat to the security of not only egypt and israel, but also the peace treaty. the sinai peninsula's criminal elements and radical islamists have been capitalizing on egypt's post-revolution security vacuum by increasingly engaging in drug and arms smuggling, human trafficking, and terrorism, risking turning the region into a powder keg. addressing these issues by strengthening border checkpoints, cracking down on human trafficking, and focusing on the sinai peninsula's long-term economic prospects could help combat the underlying problems. the administration must make it clear to all in the region, but especially to the egyptians, that a lawless sinai only undermines egyptian interests and that a renewed focus on preserving the peace is necessary.
667	a protest organised by black lives matter took place at the mall of america, despite the mall's ban on political protests and demonstrations. at least 20 arrests were made by police, who followed the mall's guideline by making multiple requests for protesters to disperse but did not resort to physical force. the mall of america is the nation's largest with over 500 businesses, but the incident was a major disruption and a demonstration of the growing movement calling for racial equity and justice.
668	ministers attempting to reduce civil servants' perks faced opposition after discovering that one of their perks, two-and-a-half extra 'privilege' days from the queen after her coronation 60 years ago, would require significant changes to royal constitutional law and face potential compensation claims from the civil service. despite these challenges, the decision on the extra days was ultimately left with the queen, with one source calling the move "cooking the books" to obscure that civil servants would continue to have their extra holidays.
669	the 2016 budget deal is moving forward, facing resistance from republican senators rubio, paul, and cruz, marking the continuing tension between the republican party's establishment and tea party members. the budget deal highlights the potential rift between establishment republicans and the tea party, as establishment republicans continue to push for moderates and reining in the radical right. as congress aims to approve the budget deal, the influence of the tea party within the republican party will be significantly tested in the months to come.
670	after the fukushima nuclear disaster a year ago, the us nuclear regulatory commission faces a crossroads: its proposals to prevent accidents in the us may not be as effective as they could be, and the nuclear industry is launching voluntary programs that may not adequately protect the public. fears of similarities between us and japanese nuclear reactors arise, causing concern for safety in the us nuclear fleet. the nuclear regulatory commission's delay in implementing key safety improvements may put citizens at risk.
671	labour deputy leader harriet harman made a request at a shadow cabinet meeting for prime minister david cameron to inform her every time royal air force (raf) jets took off to bomb islamist militants in iraq. the request was met with ridicule from party members and her own colleagues, with one mp stating that once the political authority is given for military action, it is generally down to the military to carry out the operation. harman's representative explained that she had been concerned about ensuring the unintended killing of civilians through the bombings.
672	atletico madrid took back the lead in la liga with a 4-2 away win against rayo vallecano. this was an exciting game that saw atletico's diego costa and david villa score goals, despite rayo's jonathan viera getting a penalty. diego simeone's atletico will be pleased with the points, while barcelona are hopeful after a turbulent week, with their president sandro rosell resigning due to an investigation into the signing of neymar. barcelona won their game against malaga 3-0.
673	in the 2013 moscow mayoral elections, anti-corruption campaigner alexei navalny unexpectedly scored a significant number of votes and defeated expected winner sergei sobyanin, leading to a runoff. navalny made his name fighting against vote-rigging and later led protests against the ruling elite, calling for the jailing of vladimir putin and his associates for alleged corruption. despite being jailed, he continued his campaign and this surprising election outcome gave hope for opposition activists in the years to come.
674	an actress, lindsay lohan, faces jail time on a theft charge. a judge warned her during a court hearing that she cannot avoid jail unless she is acquitted in a trial. a prosecutor offered her a plea deal which she might consider if it did not involve jail time. lindsay is charged with felony grand theft and is currently free on bond on probation violation and grand theft charges. lindsay is working on making decisions related to her future.
675	a british man, aged 66, died after being crushed by his own digger while working on his farm in spain. the pensioner fell from the digger and it landed on top of him, resulting in serious head injuries. accident occurred in sella, near alicante, at 8.25pm on tuesday, and paramedics were called to the scene. the man also sustained severe injuries to his hands and legs.
676	trulia's new report reveals that owning a home is becoming increasingly difficult for most middle-class families. it defines an affordable city as one where the "total monthly payment, including mortgage, insurance, and property taxes, is less than 31 per cent of the metro area's median household income." ohio ranks highest states with the most affordable cities, while california has six of the least affordable cities. economist jed kolko attributes the situation to the "dream of owning a home falling out of reach," and suggests that without substantial income increases, homeownership will become inaccessible for many families.
677	kevin richardson, also known as the "lion whisperer," participated in a charming promotional event where he played a game of football with three real lions on the plains of south africa. richardson, who has spent 20 years building a relationship with the big cats, demonstrated his skills in evading the dangerous animals, who have powerful jaws capable of breaking a leather football. the video was filmed in an advertisement for dutch clothing company van gils and has since gone viral with over two million views on youtube.
678	researchers at university college london have discovered that some of us have trouble with navigation due to fuzzier signals in the human brain. these inbuilt compasses tell us where we are facing and where we need to go – and the cells that sense north or south light up when we face that direction. when a person is facing north and thinks about walking to the east, two networks of cells are involved. this team's findings could improve navigation training and help researchers better understand the early phases of alzheimer's disease. the study's lead, dr. martin chadwick, states, "our results provide evidence to support the idea that your internal 'compass' readjusts as you move through the environment."
679	nelson mandela's grandson denies claims of secretly selling television broadcast rights to his grandfather's funeral for £250,000 to both bbc and sabc; mandla mandela denies accusations and states contract does not exist.
680	a third-grader in connecticut, ikeoluwa opayemi, was banned from her school for 21 days when she returned from a trip to lagos, nigeria, after the milford public schools feared she may have been exposed to ebola during a family wedding. ikeoluwa was not diagnosed with ebola and has not exhibited symptoms, but her family filed a lawsuit against the school district alleging that they acted on fears and unfounded rumors, causing her severe emotional distress. the school district denied any impropriety in their handling of the situation.
681	stunt cyclist danny macaskill dreamed up a daring display in a giant playroom for a red bull-sponsored video, using items such as rubber cubes, toy blocks, army tanks, and a series of oversized obstacles, including a real formula one car. the 2-year project almost didn't happen when macaskill fell ill with labyrinthitis, but he recovered quickly and the video was released.
682	the connor family, members of the travelling community, operated a human trafficking scheme and forced vulnerable men to work for little pay. they lived a luxury lifestyle, even receiving nearly £500,000 in legal aid, despite having assets worth millions. the family was jailed after being convicted of conspiracy to require a person to perform forced or compulsory labor. they bought two caravan parks and had a property portfolio potentially worth millions of pounds.
683	two bombings occurred over the weekend in baghdad, killing over 155 people and injuring more than 500. one video shows cars traveling around a traffic circle before a huge blast in front of the justice ministry. the attacks led to the resignation of the interior minister and the baghdad commander and sparked questions about iraq's security and national elections planned for january.
684	a young woman with terminal cervical cancer, ann-marie noble, has created a bucket list of activities and events to engage in before she dies. following her cancer diagnosis in april, noble set out to live her life to its fullest and has since been enjoying holidays, meals prepared by renown chefs, participating in extreme sports and spending time with loved ones. noble has managed to overcome challenges like the cost of travel insurance by creating a donation page and matching every pound donated. despite her struggles, ann-marie has expressed a determination to embrace life and make the most of every moment with her supportive family and friends. 
685	this heartwarming moment features twins blair and innes, who were born after being rushed to intensive care due to their premature birth. just one week after being separated, the newborns reached out across their incubator and clasped onto each other, forming a brotherly bond that will never be broken. their parents captured the special moment to remember it forever. the healthcare providers expressed amazement and felt it was a wonderful and touching moment.
686	michael gove's bichon frise puppy, snowy, came runner-up in the annual westminster dog of the year competition, beaten only by labour mp, rob flello and his german shepherd, diesel, in the politicians' pet show which promotes responsible dog ownership. the competition, organized by the kennel club and the dogs trust charity, brought together nearly as many mps as in the sparsely populated house of commons. while some politicians had a dog show tiff, the focus was on the bond between owners and their pets.
687	ukrainian president petro poroshenko declared his readiness for 'total war' with russia, claiming that the crisis in eastern europe is more significant than the is threat. poroshenko accused russia of strengthening its troops near the ukrainian border and inside rebel-held areas, claims the kremlin has repeatedly disproven. poroshenko stated that his army is now better prepared to defend its territory than when the conflict began. the ukrainian leader further emphasized that he wants peace, but must consider the worst-case scenario, adding that russia is "completely isolated" at the g20.

691	facebook may launch its own jobs board, potentially making paper resumes obsolete. as online job boards become more prominent, hiring managers can gather information about potential employees through various online platforms, such as linkedin, facebook profiles, blogs, and social media. personal websites and digital portfolios may replace traditional paper resumes.
692	josef moscicki, a 23-year-old drunk driver, ran over 83-year-old bernard smith with his van in a christmas eve incident, causing life-threatening injuries that included a head injury and broken bones. he later returned to the scene, driving over the pensioner once more while lying dead in the road, leading to smith's death. moscicki, who only recently received his driving license after two drink-driving convictions in 2011, admitted to being responsible for the fatal accident and was sentenced to life imprisonment with a minimum 21-year term.
693	patrick kueng, a 30-year-old swiss skier, won the men's downhill event at the world cup event in wengen, switzerland. the victory came amid high winds that required skiers to begin their runs lower on the slope. kueng beat austrian hannes reichelt and norwegian aksel lund svindal with a time of 1 minute and 32.66 seconds, capping a journey from his early ambitions. he suffered a severe accident in 2006 that led him to doubt his ability to continue, but he eventually earned a spot on the world cup and now aims for the winter olympics in sochi and a world cup spot.

695	a group of six lithuanian church lead-theft gang members was sentenced to almost two decades in prison for causing £1 million in damages to 20 churches across three counties in the united kingdom. the gang, all based in lincoln, targeted churches across the east midlands, stealing lead to sell at recycling yards. the thefts led to police stopping a vehicle carrying the stolen material on the a46, identifying the group, and later linking them through sales of stolen metal to recycling yards. although most of the thefts were in lincolnshire, others were also seen in leicestershire and nottinghamshire.
696	in november 2013, 23-year-old dawson mayor christopher wright was shot and his mother tied up during an attempted robbery at their georgia home. wright, who was the youngest mayor in georgia at the time, was rushed to the hospital in stable condition following the attack. the assailants also tied up his mother, who fortunately suffered minimal injuries. no suspects have been named in the case yet.

699	an amateur stuntman, 20-year-old tobias, has been killed during a daredevil stunt gone wrong in germany. tobias and three friends tied themselves to a children's playground roundabout with duct tape, attached it to a bmw, and then filmed the stunt for online fans. after the roundabout spun with such force, the duct tape failed to hold, causing tobias to be flung off. the german government is considering banning the posting of such videos in response to the incident.

701	nissan has joined google in the race to develop driverless cars, aiming to mass produce autonomous vehicles by 2020. ceo carlos ghosn announced that nissan will be ready to introduce the technological advancement by 2020, following their success with environmentally friendly vehicles like the nissan leaf, which became the best-selling electric car in history. nissan intends to begin testing autonomous vehicles by 2014, having developed the technology "behind the scenes" with numerous leading universities.

703	davion navar henry only is a 15-year-old young man who has lived most of his life in foster care. he recently moved to a foster home in st. petersburg where he shares a small bedroom with another boy. his belongings are locked up in a shared space, and he has kept his only possessions under lock and key to avoid them being stolen. davion has a facebook page and hopes to be adopted soon. he has been the subject of thousands of shares on social media and his story has captivated the nation. he longs for a family to call his own and expresses his desire to be adopted by a family no matter their background or ethnicity.
704	nba player ron artest is seeking public redemption by raffling off his new nba championship ring for charity to fund mental health services for youths who cannot afford the counseling. artest, a prominent figure in a 2004 game-stopping fan brawl, was suspended for 73 games and lost $6 million in salary. after undergoing anger management therapy, he revealed his psychologist in public and wants to destigmatize mental healthcare in the sports industry. artest partnered with rep. grace napolitano to promote the mental health in schools act, which would allocate $200 million in funding for on-site student counseling.

707	a 21-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder after his 46-year-old mother, an accountant named tolu kalejaiye, was found dead in their £350,000 four-bedroom home in wickford, essex. neighbors reportedly said that mrs. kalejaiye was stabbed to death, although the cause of death was not confirmed. more than 10 friends and family members of the mother stood in tears outside the family home, which was cordoned off and forensic officers inside working on the case. the son of the victim remains in custody, and the death is being treated as suspicious.

709	pc sales declined significantly, with a 14% drop from the previous year, which is the largest decline in history. this marks a shift towards portable devices. hp experienced the steepest decline, with a 24% decrease in sales, followed by dell's 11% decline, and apple saw a 7% drop. research firms attributed the decline to preference for portable devices like tablets and smartphones, with people finding them more convenient to carry. windows 8's negative response may have exacerbated the situation. gartner forecasted that sales will only continue dropping, and android is expected to become the main operating system for all computing devices by 2017.
710	a younger generation of cuban-americans is pushing for an end to the u.s. embargo on cuba, where their relatives were killed, as they feel the ban has done little to improve human rights or the lives of the cuban people. more cuban-americans are turning away from republican candidates and aligning with the democratic party due to this stance on the embargo.
711	apple has released two new iphones, the iphone 5c for a lower price point, with colorful bodies and less premium materials, and the iphone 5s, which is more powerful, has a fingerprint sensor called touchid, and has premium materials. this strategy helps apple differentiate between their devices and maintains their pricing justifications. the new iphones aim to attract android users and first-time smartphone users in emerging markets, while targeting early tech adopters with the iphone 5s.
712	a virgin atlantic pilot named mark entwistle has been jailed for 14 years after orchestrating a £30m mortgage scam. entwistle used a lot of his savings from his work as a pilot and then used his credit cards to lead a high-rolling lifestyle in las vegas casinos while he masterminded the fraudulent scheme. instead of investing in properties, he funded a high-rolling lifestyle which included a platinum membership at vegas casinos bellagio's and caesar's palace. entwistle and three accomplices tricked top lenders into issuing mortgages on other people's houses. entwistle even blew vast sums on the gambling website betfair. he recruited jonathan gilbert, 45, to act as his solicitor and mortgage brokers nicholas pomroy, 58, and matthew robinson, 40, to process the sophisticated frauds. the four men were jailed for 34 years between them as a judge dubbed entwistle 'arrogant and greedy, brazen to the last with no expression of remorse'.
713	a historic computer believed to be one of the oldest in the world has been brought back to life by two dedicated scientists working in a garden shed. rod thomas and roger holmes spent almost a decade and hundreds of hours repairing the ict 1301 mainframe, which cost £250,000 in 1962, for a total computing power of 2kb – roughly equivalent to a digital watch by today's standards. their ongoing efforts provide a fascinating insight into the early days of the british computer industry. the scientists now face a race to find a new home for 'flossie', a 1/10th-power version of the original computer, which was also featured in a climactic scene of the iconic 1974 james bond film the man with the golden gun, starring roger moore. 
714	when it comes to christmas, both adults and children enjoy participating in a variety of festive activities. adults, especially those aged 25-34, receive advent calendars and visit holiday markets, and nearly half of them still celebrate christmas as they did in their childhoods, often following family traditions and recipes. the most beloved christmas tradition for adults is decorating the tree, while enjoying the christmas lights being turned on. the national trust is inviting people to participate in events celebrating traditions old and new, such as carolling, decoration-making, and mince pie tasting, as the yuletide season arrives.

716	nick clegg, the leader of the liberal democrats, has called for a police investigation into the cyril smith scandal after finally admitting that there may have been an establishment cover-up. he believes there could be a wider paedophile ring involving politicians from all parties, not just his own. however, clegg still refuses to investigate what liberal politicians knew and whether they could have acted to bring smith to justice. although he did call for an investigation, he has not offered a full public inquiry into historic child sex abuse cases.
717	the museum of african design (moad) is the first museum on the continent dedicated to contemporary creativity and innovation. located in johannesburg's maboneng precinct, it showcases african design and aims to be a cultural hub, inspiring young south africans and visitors. the museum was created from a former factory, retaining its raw industrial character and aiming to stay original. featured exhibitions include "native nostalgia" exploring the concept of nostalgia for african artists, and others focused on fashion and urban design.
718	a walrus, believed to be a young male, was spotted on the shoreline of north ronaldsay in scotland, over 2,000 miles away from its home near the arctic circle. the walrus was seen happily basking under the sun on the island's beach and seemed to be in good health. walruses are known for their tusks and are famous marine mammals living mainly in shallow waters near the arctic ocean, concentrated around the north pole, canada, greenland, and alaska.
719	max cisotti, an ai who follows instructions extremely well, lives with his wife, claire, and their two children in a 15th-century cottage with a specially designed dressing room. unlike other men, max takes a great interest and spends an unbelievable amount of money on shoes, having 60 pairs in total, while his wife claire only has 15 pairs. max acknowledges that despite some marital disputes, his wife is secretly proud of his shoe collection, understanding the importance of looking good and matching the shoes to different occasions. as a trend analyst at mintel, richard cope, explains that men are taking more time and effort in grooming, parenting, and shopping for their appearance. max's obsession with shoes is akin to the early stage of a relationship, as he enjoys shopping for them, comparing prices, and savoring the moment of finally wearing the new pair.

722	queens park rangers (qpr) manager harry redknapp plans to sign highly-rated midfielder mark davies from bolton wanderers to boost his premier league squad. redknapp seeks to increase his numbers at loftus road after training with only 15 senior players, including loic remy who is heading to liverpool. davies, 26, fits the younger age profile, and rio ferdinand is the only recent signing allowed by qpr owner tony fernandes. davies is expected to join qpr on a season-long loan initially, and swansea city had previously unsuccessfully bid £5million for him one year ago.
723	doctors without borders is embarking on a large vaccination campaign in three african countries to combat an outbreak of meningitis that has killed hundreds of people. the vaccinations are being carried out in niger, nigeria, and chad, as part of a "meningitis belt" of sub-saharan africa that stretches from senegal to ethiopia. the campaign includes the medical treatment and vaccination of 5.4 million people with plans to vaccinate another 1.7 million, making it the largest ever initiative for doctors without borders. more than 1,900 people have died in this outbreak since january, with more than 56,000 cases reported in niger, nigeria, and chad.

728	an old west gun battle re-enactor in south dakota, paul doering, has been sentenced to seven and a half years in prison after mistakenly firing live rounds instead of blanks during a performance, wounding three onlookers. doering, a six-time convicted felon, faced up to 20 years in prison and had pleaded guilty to a charge of tampering as part of a plea deal with prosecutors. the south dakota wild bunch re-enactors have since suspended their gunfight performances as a result of the incident.

730	a former dinner lady, karen mccann, was caught running a £150,000-a-year cannabis farm from her home in leicester. police found £18,448 in cash, 66 cannabis plants, and a hydration system in her property. the operation supplied high-potency cannabis, which could yield £37,600 annually. mccann paid off her mortgage and took expensive holidays, spending £6,000 on a spanish vacation, despite declaring only £443 in genuine earnings from 2008 to april 2016. she pleaded guilty to producing cannabis, abstracting electricity, using criminal property, and money laundering.
731	mourad hamyd, an 18-year-old alleged terrorist, is being accused of involvement in the charlie hebdo attack; however, his classmates from lycee monge claim he was in school with them at the time of the incident, which took place 130 miles away from the crime scene. a facebook group has been set up in support of him, calling for more information to be released.
732	environmentally friendly engineering is being implemented in chicago, illinois, with a project called green alleys. workers are resurfacing alleys with permeable concrete that cleans rainwater before it runs into lake michigan, aiming to stop polluted rainwater from entering the city's alleyways and adjacent lake. chicago's 13,000 alleys contribute to approximately 3,500 acres of surface that is impermeable, causing water puddles and flooding basements. the extreme alley makeover began with altering the pavement material, using concrete, asphalt, or paving stones that are permeable, allowing rainwater to seep through, cleaner water being absorbed within the groundwater, eventually making its way to lake michigan and reducing chicago's water consumption taken out of it annually.
733	the headmaster of eton college, tony little, proposes abolishing gcses and allowing schools more freedom in teaching until aged 18 to cope with a modern world. he suggests that the current traditional, one-size-fits-all examining approach is restrictive, with students working in teams, sharing work through qualifications based on the collective experience of young people. candidates could face a 5% deduction for errors in composing papers. eton currently offers mainly igcses and about half of its sixth-form is cambridge pre-u, aiming to develop creative student autonomy through "flipped" lessons.
734	a gang that smuggled chinese citizens into the united states and europe was busted with 75 arrests in spain and france, authorities announced. the smuggling ring, based in china and directed there, had its two european leaders in barcelona, spain. besides the leaders, spanish police arrested 49 others carrying forged passports at airports in barcelona, madrid, palma de mallorca and five other cities. in france, there were 24 arrests. the smugglers charged 40,000 to 50,000 euros ($53,000 to $66,000) to transport the chinese citizens, assigned with fake identities, to the us, spain, france, greece, italy, britain, ireland, and turkey. the investigation began two years ago, and the suspects include those who allegedly formed part of the smuggling ring and those who paid for the forged documents.

758	representatives from 190 countries have formed a basic draft agreement for a global climate change treaty at the 20th conference of parties (cop20). this treaty, based on the lima draft, is supposed to be agreed upon in paris next year to outline nations' responsibilities in combating climate change. the document establishes that developed and developing countries will have different responsibilities and wealthier countries will help poorer countries to finance their climate goals. additionally, a portion of $10.2 billion from contributed countries was donated towards the green climate fund, intending to help finance sustainable development efforts.

773	a recent study has revealed that cancer may never be completely eradicated as it is as old as the earliest life on earth, and may have originated from the natural evolution of cells. scientists studying hydra found evidence of tumor growth in two species of simple, freshwater animals, dating back to hundreds of millions of years ago. researchers found that the invasive characteristic of cancer cells is also an evolutionary ancient feature, challenging the 'war on cancer' initiated in the 1970s. though cancer cells may be difficult to cure or treat, understanding the disease's origins can help develop more effective treatment methods. medical technology will enable doctors to detect and clean troublemaking cells early and potentially cure patients completely.

806	on may 29, 1953, edmund hillary and tenzing norgay became the first people to successfully reach the summit of mount everest, the tallest peak on earth, marking the beginning of a new era in mountaineering. sixty years later, nepal celebrated the 60th anniversary of the conquest of mount everest, honoring the original mountaineers as well as other notable climbers who made the journey. throughout the celebration, various activities paid tribute to these climbers and their historic accomplishment.
807	portugal's economic conditions remains fragile despite efforts to balance the books. the ceo of tap air portugal warns of the dangers of uncertainty affecting europe's recovery, citing panic in cyprus as an example. additionally, political instability and stagnating growth pose risks. last week, finance ministers agreed to give portugal and ireland more time to repay their bailout loans.
808	a woman was attacked by a mob of at least 20 men in guwahati, india. the incident, which occurred outside a bar, was filmed by an off-duty journalist and has caused widespread outrage and condemnation due to the slow police response and brutality involved. shockingly, the woman was stripped and beaten during the ordeal. 6 men have so far been arrested, but 7 more suspects remain at large. posters with the suspects' photos went up in the area, and the national commission for women sent a three-member team to investigate the attack.
809	in the recent arrest of 90 suspects in an international crackdown, cassidy wolf, former miss teen usa, opened an email containing nude photographs of herself. the hacker had secretly taken the photos via a webcam at her school. this experience raised awareness among young teenagers, prompting wolf to travel the country and share her story.
810	a 62-year-old woman, june scott, developed a fungal infection from wearing contact lenses, leading to the loss of vision in one eye. despite several attempts, doctors eventually removed her blinded eye to help stop the infection. the infection, which was caused by a fungus called fusarium, led to her being blinded in one eye after the cornea was eaten away. scott, who lives in county durham, england, is planning to take legal action against the contact lens supplier.
811	hurricane paloma intensified on friday, hitting grand cayman island with strong winds and heavy rain. a hurricane warning was issued for the cayman islands, with residents urged to complete preparations to protect life and property. paloma was moving northeast and, as of 10 p.m. et, was about 40 kilometers south of grand cayman island and 275 miles southwest of camaguey, cuba. it was expected to pass near grand cayman on friday night and approach the coast of central cuba late on saturday. the storm could potentially produce rainfall accumulations of 5-10 inches in the cayman islands and central and eastern cuba, with the possibility of significant flooding and mudslides.
812	former contestant chris soules announced as the next bachelor, following his time on andi dorfman's season of the bachelorette. soules, also known as the "hot farmer from iowa," gained a fan following towards the end of the season, which possibly contributed to the show's slow decision-making process. the decision was made in the midst of heated discussions and debates about which direction to follow. however, soules is now ready to embark on a new journey to find love in california.
813	vanessa sky ellis is a superfan who has amassed over 10,000 photos with celebrities, which stems from an inherited hobby from her late mother. vanessa spends her time hunting for famous faces in new york and scanning tv guides to find out which celebrities are likely to be there. while her father doesn't care much for her obsession, vanessa says that her favorite celebrity to photograph is johnny depp and does not plan on stopping her hobby anytime soon.
814	a collection of wills has revealed that karl marx, the anti-capitalist philosopher, died a poor man and charles darwin left behind a large estate. the england and wales national probate calendar from 1861 to 1941, comprising over 6 million estates, has been published online by ancestry.co.uk for the first time, offering insights into financial legacies of notable figures such as famous authors charles dickens and arthur conan doyle.
815	three american individuals are reportedly fighting alongside kurdish forces against isis in northern syria. one of them, identified as jordan matson from wisconsin, is part of the kurdistan people's protection units (ypg), with the other two fighting in the same area. matson served in the u.s. military before taking part in this mission. the u.s. military has confirmed matson's military record, but no further information can be released due to privacy concerns. kurdish officials confirmed the presence of three americans and stated that they believe in the fight against isis.
816	the syrian government and opposition demanded independent investigations into allegations of chemical weapons use, following accusations by each side. amid calls for a probe, the united nations and us officials expressed skepticism towards these accusations. chemical and biological weapon stockpiles in syria have been a concern, given fears of such weapons falling into the hands of terrorist groups should assad exit his position.
817	in rome, the catholic cardinals started a secret election, known as a conclave, to choose a new pope. the 115 cardinal-electors participating in the conclave will enter the closed-door process after morning mass. only cardinals younger than 80 are eligible to vote. they are currently discussing the church's problems, such as addressing child sex abuse cases and corruption within the roman catholic hierarchy. many candidates are using the internet to ask for prayers and support before the election next week.
818	manchester city scouts observed alexandre lacazette, who scored in lyon's 3-2 win against rc lens; his season tally now stands at 20. city continues to evaluate potential targets for the premier league and mls franchise (new york city fc). dennis praet of anderlecht and julian draxler of schalke are also possible candidates but are more likely to be pursued in the summer. meanwhile, city may attempt to acquire aston villa's christian benteke, who is content to stay with the club despite their interest. paul lambert's villa express interest in scott sinclair but also wish to acquire 20-year-old forward adil nabi from west bromwich albion. 
819	in the democratic republic of congo, rare, elusive okapi were once believed to be mythical due to their shy nature and lack of encounters. however, camera traps have captured new images of the okapi, a giraffe relative, which was previously seen in the drc over 50 years ago. the okapi's unique face, long legs, and distinctive black-and-white rear stripes were noted through these images. despite threats such as poaching and deforestation, the okapi population remains resilient within the virunga national park, where several okapi were encountered through the study conducted by the zoological society of london and the congolese institute for nature conservation.
820	australian motocycle racer casey stoner secured his second victory of the season at the french grand prix, while spanish racer dani pedrosa, winner of the previous race, was sent to the hospital with a broken collarbone after a collision with marco simoncelli. pedrosa, who is now in second place in the overall standings, faced a second major injury and missed out on a podium position. valentino rossi came in second, while fellow italian andrea dovizioso finished third. world champion jorge lorenzo finished fifth and is now 12 points ahead of stoner.
821	in 2012, aileen hedges, a 30-year-old woman from kent, was caught with 18.8g of amphetamine, a performance enhancer and class b narcotic, in her fridge. she claimed she used it to help clean her house faster. however, she eventually admitted to supplying the drugs and was sentenced to a suspended nine-month jail term and ordered to participate in a drug rehabilitation course.
822	at-home entertainment is experiencing success during these economic times. netflix, a dvd rental service, has had a record quarter and now boasts 10 million subscribers. this has led to growth in various industries like video games, which has become a $22 billion business. families like the moores are enjoying popular games like nintendo's wii system, and engaging in traditional games for their own unique form of affordable escapism.
823	an elderly anaesthetist, michael cowen, was reportedly in a deep sleep during an emergency caesarian operation at milton keynes general hospital, which led to a surgeon claiming he was at risk. however, it was later found the patient was not endangered, and cowen was later allowed to return to work. the incident had sparked an official inquiry, and while there have been no more claims against cowen, some questioned the hospital's initial statement.

826	a 39-year-old artist named ken to from california, us, has spent 1,000 times, or approximately 10,000 hours, twisting and turning copper wire to create miniature bonsai plants, which he sells worldwide for up to £200 apiece. to first started admiring real bonsai trees, which inspired him to create his detailed wire sculptures, though he does not entirely copy them.
827	millions of people in syria have been displaced and face dangerous situations; as a result, they are heavily reliant on aid agencies. the united nations has estimated that over 4.25 million people inside syria are homeless, half of whom are believed to be children. women, men, and children have been forced to flee several times after being forced from their homes, and they now rely on emergency organizations for essential needs like shelter, food, and medical care. the situation remains dangerous, with many areas damaged due to conflict; it's causing the destruction of homes and land. to cope, some ngos are providing medical care and support within syria. the united nations has estimated that for 2013 alone, aid of $1.4 billion is needed to deal with the crisis.
828	prince harry is taking part in a charity expedition called walking with the wounded adventurers to the south pole. the group, consisting of 12 injured service personnel from britain, america, canada and australia, aimed to trek to the south pole by racing against teams from the commonwealth and the us. the challenge faced difficulties due to the harsh conditions, and the competitive aspect of the trek was suspended for safety reasons. although the race was stopped, participants are in high spirits and are united as they continue their journey towards the south pole.
829	the horrific deaths of 79 football fans in port said have left the future of egyptian soccer bleak. mourning for the victims has begun, but it will take time to understand how such a tragedy could happen. the league has been suspended, while the prime minister sacked the entire egyptian football association. the riot could also lead to an international ban for the egyptian team, following fifa guidelines. many believe that poor stadium conditions and police negligence contributed to the tragedy.

833	hong minh truong, a 66-year-old texas man, has been arrested on suspicion of sending more than 500 hoax letters containing white powder to various locations across the u.s. and worldwide over a period of six years. the letters contained terrorism threats and were thought to be anthrax. it is alleged that truong sent the letters starting in 2008 from dallas, with 15 batches containing the hoax threats. truong now faces charges for false information and hoaxes, and if convicted, could face up to five years in prison and a fine of $250,000.
834	a gang of three car clampers were jailed for ten years after extorting up to £350,000 from motorists while laughing off their protests, with at least two of the men also claiming tens of thousands in illegal benefit payments. carlton williams, 47; lee stagg, 43; and michael riddle, 30 were arrested for a three-year clamping scheme and eventually charged with blackmail and fraud, operating as "a1 clamping services" from 2005 to 2008. the gang would pounce on unsuspecting drivers—often women with young children—and then charge them up to £600 to release clamped cars.

836	a school in newcastle has placed a 14-year-old girl named natalya page in isolation due to her red dyed hair which goes against the school's uniform policy. the father of the girl, fred page, opposed this, arguing that it was "ridiculous" to be persecuted for a minor matter and questioning the severity of the punishment. the school insisted on high standards of dress and behaviour and threatened to charge parents £60 for missed lessons by children in the "causing concern" category with at least 2.5 unauthorised absences.
837	dr. fiona hampton, a respiratory specialist, has been honored as a health hero by nominee fay calvert. after her son craig was diagnosed with cystic fibrosis, dr. hampton spent countless hours helping the family navigate their way through the journey. she worked relentlessly to make sure that craig was as comfortable as possible and made fay and her family feel like they were not alone in the struggle.

843	at the height of her career as an escort, gwyneth montenegro earned up to $1000 per hour and had relationships with around 10,000 men. now, aged 36, she has lifted the lid on her escorting world and written a book about it. born into a family with deep christian values, gwyneth initially went into the sex industry as a table top dancer, moving on to becoming a high end escort at 21. she became increasingly involved with the world of escorting as she gained confidence and started to connect with peers, with her book showcasing how this world was positive compared to her life of high school bullying. eventually, gwyneth became tired of the industry and had a series of car accidents. in her newly released book "10,000 men and counting," gwyneth shares her experiences as an escort and her attempts to leave it behind.

846	in 2013, jeremy paxman expressed his shock that children were being shown the series blackadder goes forth in school to teach them about the first world war. he believed that this was due to its use of lighthearted comedy to discuss the subject matter, which made understanding it complex for people. additionally, paxman discussed that the great war had been misrepresented in history, and how poets were used to approach the subject, as it was difficult to comprehend from a contemporary perspective.
847	sally ride, the first american woman in space, died at age 61 after a 17-month battle with pancreatic cancer. she was a trailblazer, an inspirational figure, and passionate advocate of female advancement in science, technology, and mathematics. her achievements include founding sally ride science, a prominent educational organization that encourages girls and young students to pursue their passions in science fields, as well as writing several children's books and obtaining a ph.d. in physics from stanford university. ride's impact on women and science led to emotional tributes and thousands expressing condolences after her death.
848	inter milan secured a 1-0 victory over cagliari, moving them to second place in italy's serie a, closely behind ac milan. inter's lone goal came in the seventh minute from defender andrea ranocchia. the win puts inter in a good position for the upcoming champions league final rematch with bayern munich. ac milan aims to bounce back in their match against chievo next sunday, while napoli can regain second place with a win against catania.
849	concerns about the deadly middle east respiratory syndrome (mers) virus have increased significantly, but officials claim the disease does not constitute a global public health emergency yet. the disease causes coughing, fever, and sometimes fatal pneumonia, has no vaccines or antiviral treatments, and kills approximately 30% of those infected. the virus is from the same family as sars and primarily spreads from camels to humans. the world health organization met on tuesday to discuss mers but determined conditions for a public health emergency of international concern haven’t yet been met.
850	the global ebola death toll has risen to almost 5,000, prompting us roboticists and government organizations to plan a summit on how robots may help curb the spread of the disease. during the events in november, experts will discuss how robots can contribute to managing the crisis, sharing their current research. the use of robots in health facilities aims to reduce transmission, contain the virus, and save human lives.

854	a 900-year-old norse code, believed to be the viking equivalent of a valentine's day card, has finally been cracked by phd student jonas norbury. the mysterious jötunvillur code was written in medieval cipher runes and is thought to include a message saying 'kiss me'. while the code could not initially be read, it is the first time the code has been studied by one person, and norbury plans to study around 80 inscriptions across northern europe containing such codes.

858	on march 20, 2013, cyprus faced threats of economic collapse as russia failed to provide a rescue plan. cyprus' banks were set to remain closed until the following tuesday as the country sought a financial bailout from the european union. the government put in place exchange controls to prevent money from leaving the country, while german finance minister wolfgang schaeuble warned that a highly unpopular tax raid on bank deposits needed to be agreed upon. the european central bank threatened to pull the plug on cyprus unless an £8.5 billion bailout package was agreed to find £4.9 billion in debts.

864	the explosion in "text speak," which involves abbreviated words and acronyms developed for speed, has created a language barrier between generations. nearly 90% of parents and teachers say text speak has caused problems, as children frequently have to translate messages. additionally, more than two-thirds of teachers have noticed the terms are now 'routinely' cropping up in essays and other work for their students. despite this, education experts argue schools should embrace text speak, rather than try to eradicate it completely.
865	in january 2012, a pair of military jets were flying over northumberland, causing a "sonic event" that mimicked an earthquake. residents near the area reported buildings shaking and loud rumbling due to the event caused by the jets breaking the sound barrier. the british geological survey clarified that this event had a sonic origin and was not an earthquake, and the royal air force confirmed the presence of the military jets in the area at the time.

867	serbia's prime minister, ivica dacic, expresses his confidence that his country will become the next member of the european union. serbia aims to follow in the footsteps of slovenia and croatia, with dacic stating that it does not have much time to wait due to economic problems stemming from the breakup of former yugoslavia in the 1990s. serbia faces high unemployment, challenges in industrial productivity, and relies on remittance income from emigrants. eu membership would enable serbia access to funding for infrastructure projects and regional development, but dacic emphasizes the importance of joining the world's largest trading bloc without solely relying on financial aid packages. the eu will take into account serbia's progress in resolving its issues with kosovo, with eu membership potentially helping to ease political tensions. the process of joining the eu will be a slow one, with some estimates saying it may take up to ten years, and it may require serbia to take into account other countries, such as montenegro, in their progress toward membership. 
868	manchester city dominated their match against holders porto with a 4-0 win at the etihad stadium, securing their place in the last 16 of the europa league. the premier league leaders had a 2-1 advantage from the first leg in portugal, winning the tie 6-1 on aggregate. this victory added to manchester city manager roberto mancini's recent success, as striker carlos tevez apologized for his actions during a three-month standoff, which left him sidelined.
869	the thyroid gland, a small butterfly-shaped gland at the base of the neck, plays a crucial role in regulating various body functions such as heart rate, blood pressure, digestive system, menstrual system, and more. issues with thyroid hormone production, both under and overproduced, can cause various health problems, with hypothyroidism being more common, and its symptoms may include slowness, fatigue, memory problems, dry skin, weight gain, and sensitivity to cold. hyperthyroidism, excessive thyroid hormone production, is less common but can lead to heart rate issues, fatigue, weight loss, and other symptoms. if you suspect a problem, consult a doctor to get tested for thyroid function, and treatments are available for both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism.
870	cnn international is celebrating the 20th anniversary of poland's solidarity movement defeating the communist party in 1989 with a week-long programming called "the new poland," featuring daily live programming and special reports from correspondents in cities across poland. the programming will culminate on june 4 with "autumn of change," an in-depth documentary that takes a retrospective look at the events leading up to the election 20 years ago. through the combination of daily live programming, documentary programming, and online coverage, cnn aims to provide a comprehensive narrative of the events that have helped shape the europe of today.

874	the number of requests to hold illegal immigrants in jail ahead of deportation has decreased by 9,000 requests per month since 2012, according to a new report. immigration and customs enforcement (ice) request for 'detainers' has decreased by 39% across the financial years of 2012, 2013 and up to march 2015. the reduction in requests is said to be due to an effort to prioritize enforcement on deportation for criminal immigrants rather than others who pose less of a threat.

879	in 2013, cnn awarded $50,000 to the top ten cnn heroes. these extraordinary individuals, recognised at the "cnn heroes: an all-star tribute" event, work to change the world through various efforts including fighting poverty, providing health care to those in need, helping children with cancer and bringing education to girls in kenya. chad pregracke, named hero of the year, received an additional $250,000 for his cause, which involves cleaning up american waterways. the heroes' work continues to be recognized via the cnn heroes platform, and the awardees receive free organizational training from the annenberg foundation.
880	donald sterling, the racist los angeles clippers owner, is secretly battling cancer, sources say. the nba banned sterling for life following audio recordings in which he said he did not want black people at his games or posting pictures with them on instagram. sterling's fight with cancer was reportedly expected two years ago, but he has been taking "drugs" to stay alive. cancer in his prostate has already been revealed, the same condition former clippers assistant coach kim hughes struggled with a decade ago.
881	the "ethiopian caterpillar," a gold and enamel automaton silkworm dating back to the early 19th century is expected to fetch up to £200,000 when it is sold at auction by sotheby's on wednesday. the unique piece was created for chinese aristocracy and is part of a collection of 49 items of furniture and decorative arts in sotheby's "treasures: princely tastes" sale, a selection of sumptuous items commissioned by or made for great european rulers and dynasties.
882	gus poyet, sunderland's manager, believes player connor wickham now has the responsibility to develop into a full england international following the player signing a new contract with the club to remain until 2019. wickham joined the black cats at the age of 18, when he was sold by ipswich town for £8m. the striker has shown improvements and progressed well this season, and poyet hopes that wickham can continue his development and potentially become a part of the senior england team.
883	a video has emerged of a former marine and off-duty cop, neal auricchio jr., being beaten by three philadelphia flyers fans after a big game between rival teams. auricchio jr. was hospitalized with concussion after the assault. battered by fans wearing their opponents' jersey brand, auricchio jr.'s injuries include stitches in both eyes and a puffed-up eye, according to his father. the incident unfolded outside philadelphia's famous geno's steaks restaurant, following the new york rangers' victory over the philadelphia flyers in the winter classic game. police claim flyers fans paid a man $50 to spray a rangers fan with a liquid; video surfaced showing the unprovoked beatings.
884	a woman, her two sisters, and her two nephews were attacked by philip spence in a plush london hotel room in april 2008. all three sisters were left for dead with severe head injuries while spence stole valuables. spence, who denies attempted murder, was later caught and admitted causing grievous bodily harm with intent.
885	the differences between men's and women's brains can explain their different behavior, but they do not make men or women dumber. men and women have brains wired in unique ways that influence their thinking, decision-making and emotional responses. women have more brain cells in areas that control planning and conscientiousness, which helps them pack carefully, while men have larger brain cells in the amygdala, the part of the brain that controls fear and anger. these and other differences in brain structure and function have significant implications for how men and women approach problems and interact with each other.
886	grandfather anthony wilkinson caught traffic wardens removing snow from double yellow lines, making it appear as if drivers had intentionally parked illegally. once the hidden lines were revealed, wardens issued tickets on nearby vehicles. wilkinson started an 18-month campaign to prove the tickets shouldn't have been issued. the council finally admitted the wardens were in the wrong and canceled the fines. the incident exposed a possible culture of deception and disdain among parking industry employees. 
887	john g. sperling, the founder of the university of phoenix, has passed away at age 93. he is survived by his longtime companion joan hawthorne, his former wife virginia sperling, son peter, daughter-in-law stephanie, and two grandchildren. apollo education group ceo greg cappelli and chairman peter sperling issued a statement highlighting sperling's contributions in accessible higher education, particularly for working adults. he is remembered for pioneering online degree programs through his work.
888	with multicamera instant replays and social media today, it seems impossible for a group of baseball players to get away with throwing a world series game. the fact is that even in the early 1900s, with radio broadcasts and newspaper reporting, some sports reporters were able to detect suspicious events taking place in games. back then, chicago white sox players threw the 1919 world series to fix matches, but this was able to go unnoticed until reporters began paying closer attention to the games.
889	former tennis star boris becker was spotted at the us open with a noticeable lump on his elbow, causing speculation about an injury, but it appears to be tennis elbow. as novak djokovic's coach, becker may need to take a break to allow the injury to heal. the condition is caused by repeated stress on the elbow muscles and can be managed with medication and physical therapy. djokovic will face paul-henri mathieu in his next match.
890	after winning the 2014 world cup, german football players celebrated with their wives and girlfriends (wags) by joining the on-field party at the maracana stadium in rio de janeiro. players, including andre schurrle and bastian schweinsteiger, wept, hugged, and shared moments with their significant others, while team captain joachim low also greeted and hugged the wags. injured players like sami khedira's girlfriend lena gercke and others, as well as some fans, watched the event from the nearby area.
891	britain could face "brownouts" this winter, where household lights are dimmed, due to a series of power shortages as coal-fired power stations are closed to meet eu carbon targets. the risk for power shortages is at its greatest in almost a decade. should extreme cold sets in, safety margins would be erased, causing brownouts. to maintain power reserves, the grid is planning to turn off machines at some large factories during peak hours, and pay energy firms to switch on backup power stations with increased imports. while assuring there will be no blackouts, politicians insist there is no chance of homes losing power altogether.
892	xi jinping, born in 1953, is expected to take over as china's leader when the 18th communist party congress begins on november 8, 2012. a former vice president since 2008, xi is widely anticipated to become the country's president next march, replacing incumbent hu jintao. despite tight control of details about xi's life, he has risen to prominence through loyalty to hu, a political leader who has not been known to shift policies significantly or challenge the status quo. if he is indeed chosen to lead china, xi faces the challenge of leading a country with a population of over 1.3 billion people, a vast and influential economy, and tensions in some regions due to its territorial ambitions. to read more about xi's background, family connections and rise to power, see the sources linked throughout the article.
893	a set of 200-year-old tunnels utilized as french prisoner housing in the napoleonic wars is being sold for £19,000 ($25,000). the tunnels, located in devon, uk, were later used as air raid shelters and are being auctioned as an investment property. the current owners have chosen to part ways with the property due to its restrictions and location, mentioning potential uses for potential buyers, such as storage or personal recreation like a workshop.
894	nearly half of 11-year-old children have not used public transport by the time they reach that age, according to a recent major uk study. children nowadays have less freedom due to the increased access to gadgets, limiting experiences such as travelling on public transport. moreover, the study found that 76% of children reported being bullied by a sibling, and 58% reported being picked on by another child. 
895	the brazilian barbecue tradition, known as churrascaria, features a wide variety of beef cuts, including picanha, baby beef, alcatra (top sirloin), filet mignon, and more, cooked in a slow-roasted style over charcoal. churrascarias offer diners the experience of selecting individual cuts of meat, sliced off fresh to taste, as well as other meats like pork, lamb, and chicken, served alongside rice and beans.
896	in november 1970, the bodies of six people were found in two rusting vintage cars submerged in an oklahoma lake for over forty years. the discovery raised the mystery of three local teenagers and three other people, who went missing decades ago without a trace. among the remains, police officers found three bodies presumed to be the local teenagers who went out for a drive in 1970, whose blue 1969 camaro was found alongside the lake. another car, a 1950-model chevrolet, contained three bodies believed to belong to washita county residents who vanished in the 1950s or early 1960s. local witnesses claimed that jimmy allen williams, aged 16, thomas michael rios, 18, and leah gail johnson, 18, had gone hunting at foss lake after williams’s brother heard them talking about it. the family members of the victims have not yet received confirmation of the identities but the local newspaper made a direct connection between the discovered camaro and the teenagers. 
897	there has been a sharp increase in radiation levels detected in pipes and containers holding water at the damaged fukushima daiichi nuclear plant in japan. tokyo electric power company (tepco) stated that a single drop of contaminated water escaped from the holding tanks, but they are confident in providing safety for workers. tepco discovered high radiation readings at the storage tanks and the affected pipes over the weekend. despite the high readings, they found no change in the water levels, indicating that no contaminated water leakage is expected.
898	philip kettle, a morbidly obese bus inspector, shed 17 stone by changing his diet and exercise habits after being ridiculed for taking up multiple seats on the london tube. at 31 stone 7lbs, kettle was warned by doctors about his health and faced daily stares from commuters. he joined weightwatchers, banned snacking and walked more frequently, returning to health, fitness and becoming a new, happy person.
899	this article highlights the importance of rivers and river appreciation, noting that rivers are often overlooked, invisible, and polluted. however, there are still people devoted to rivers, known as river people, who care about adventure over efficiency and enjoy the wild nature that rivers bring. these river people have submitted stories and photos about their favorite rivers to cnn's change the list project, showcasing that many people do value our rivers and hope to restore them for a better world.
900	six injured british servicemen, including four amputees, arrived in barbados after completing a 3,000-mile ocean rowing challenge across the atlantic to raise £1 million for wounded comrades. faced with no running water, comfortable bed or toilet during the gruelling seven-and-a-half-week ocean row, the servicemen experienced similar conditions to those encountered on tours of duty in both iraq and afghanistan. their mission, 'row2recovery,' raises funds for charities supporting injured soldiers and their families - help for heroes, ssafa and abf.
901	biohackers in california have found a way to create cheese protein genes based on sequences in cow dna, before growing them in baker's yeast and using them to create a 'milk' substitute. this milk can then be churned using traditional cheese-making methods to produce real vegan cheese.
902	kieran maxwell is a teenager who lost his leg to cancer and became inspired to take up gymnastics after watching the olympic heroes of london 2012. despite the challenge of having a prosthetic leg, he has become an accomplished acrobatic gymnast, making him an aspiring paralympian. kieran raised £25,000 to buy a new prosthetic limb, and with the help of the uk's biggest-ever lottery jackpot winners, received a brand new prosthetic leg that enables him to engage in the sports he loves, like football and gymnastics.
903	u.s. soccer player hope solo has been suspended for 30 days from her team after an incident at training camp. solo won't be participating in matches next month in europe, however, the cause of the suspension remains undisclosed. solo's husband, former nfl star jerramy stevens, was also arrested this week for suspicion of driving under the influence. solo's suspension comes at a crucial time for the u.s. team and she is eligible for reinstatement after the suspension, pending review and approval by u.s. soccer and coach jill ellis.
904	a dedicated father donated 20% of his own liver to his critically ill son, giving him a healthy organ that will grow alongside his own as a functional replica of the original organ. through a rigorous process, the father was determined to be a suitable donor, and on december 6, 2013, the transplant occurred, resulting in a successful outcome. muhammed ali's health began to improve significantly, and both father and son are on the road to a full recovery. this selfless act shows the extraordinary bond between a father and his child, and the miraculous benefits a life-changing surgery can provide.
905	anders behring breivik, a man responsible for killing 93 people in a 2011 massacre in norway, has been linked to the english defence league (edl), an organization with far-right views opposed to multiculturalism and islam. breivik wrote in one online posting, “i have on some occasions, discussed with… edl, and recommended them to use conscious strategies." the tactics of the edl is to "entice" an overreaction from jihad youths/extreme marxists, which has been successful several times, boosting the edl ranks high. in another posting, breivik analyzed the differences between edl and british national party. he allegedly made contact with another far-right group, stop the islamification of europe, according to the sunday telegraph. the edl has denied any connections with breivik. the norwegian branch of the organization released a statement saying that "the terrorist acts are connected with a person who is against multiculturalism and is against islam [...] we must emphasize that the suspect has never been a member of our organization." the english defence league has distanced itself from breivik and any connection with his actions. the revelation has led to the news that extra security will be put up at mosques around the uk, said british muslim leaders, fearing for the safety of their communities and against the potential targeting of mosques.

908	a 60-year-old man named sambany lived with a 12-kg (26.45-lb) tumour on his neck for four decades which weighed just over a stone. charitable medics at mercy ships performed a 12-hour operation, removing one of the largest tumours they have seen in their 30-year history. sambany was delighted with the procedure and plans to recover on the ship for the next few months. mercy ships, a charity providing free medical care, was able to help transform sambany's life by removing the tumour and improving his wellbeing.

911	the second world war hero, captain robert boscawen, who was horrifically injured during a german shell attack at arnhem before becoming an esteemed mp, has died at the age of 90. the tank commander was one of the first to enter brussels in 1944 and served as an mp for wells and somerton and frome for over 20 years after returning from the war.

916	the supreme court declined to consider appeals from families of elementary school students over distribution of religious-themed gifts on campus. the issue involved whether school officials can be sued for violating the first amendment rights of students who claimed their "private, non-curricular speech was based solely upon its religious viewpoint." a federal appeals court had previously ruled that school officials could not be sued for violating the students' rights, based on the "qualified immunity" legal standard.

920	jerome murdough, a mentally ill, homeless former marine, passed away in an overheated jail cell after being found more than two months ago, his relatives share that he was a giving and kind person. a modest family funeral was held, reflecting memories of happier times. the medical examiner claims more tests are needed to establish the cause of jerome's death; however, initial reports suggest his cell was overheated to at least 100 degrees due to malfunctioning equipment. multiple city officials confirmed he was discovered "basically baked to death." the death of jerome murdough highlights the flaws within the criminal justice system, with the mentally ill accounting for approximately 40% of the roughly 12,000 jail inmates in the country. the marine corps did not comment on the situation.

926	the newest map of antarctica, called bedmap2, provides the most detailed rendering of the earth's surface beneath the ice and features improved data that helps scientists predict how the continent will react to climate change. bedmap2's information allows for better understanding of how the ice sheet will flow, affecting ocean currents, raising sea levels, and the impact of melting ice on the rest of the planet.

932	city watchdogs are investigating allegations that foreign exchange traders are manipulating exchange rates. the investigation centers around claims that bank staff are making trades before processing customer orders and timing them to influence the setting of benchmark rates. this scandal has been referred to as "the wild west," similar to the libor rate-fixing scandal that involved barclays and royal bank of scotland. concerns have also been raised about the manipulation of natural gas, oil, and petrol prices. the forex market is not regulated, but banks are subject to oversight from the financial conduct authority.
933	russia's football association (fa) does not have enough funds to pay national team coach fabio capello, reveals sergey stepashin, a member of the governing body's executive committee. capello's salary remains unpaid for five months, as the financial issues with the russian football union are causing concern. the former england manager, who has coached clubs like real madrid, juventus, ac milan, and as roma, is yet to receive wages since taking over the russian team in 2012. capello had previously extended his contract in january 2018, with the new deal said to be valued at approximately £7 million per year.

944	uk culture minister, ed vaizey, expressed concerns that the government's "presumption in favor of development" is inflating estimates of housing demand, potentially leading to the countryside being flooded with thousands of unwanted homes under new planning laws. vaizey warned that the projected levels of housing need in specific regions were up to three times the current need, and this would have significant consequences for local communities affected by unrealistic expansion plans. he called for an urgent review of the planning methodology to ensure more realistic outcomes result. housing minister, nick boles, defended the push for new housing, stating that high house prices and affordability were issues that needed to be addressed. however, both agreed that the new assessment of housing needs shouldn't automatically invalidate local housing plans or prevent expansion.
