1165	one year ago, a tunisian street vendor set himself on fire, sparking a series of events leading to a revolution that toppled his country's oppressive government. however, a new threat to digital activism is emerging in the united states, with the stop online piracy act (sopa) and the protect ip act. these bills would require social media platforms to proactively monitor and censor users to prevent copyright infringements, and they could block websites anywhere on earth. while the creators of the bills do not intend to stifle digital activism and protect intellectual property, they worry that unintended harm to speech freedoms at home and abroad will result from the bills' legal and technical solutions that resemble methods used by repressive regimes for censoring and spying on their citizens.
1166	isis fighters have been training to fly captured fighter jets at an air base in syria, according to observers. initial flights are believed to be the first time the militant group has taken to the air. there is concern over potential attacks on british, us, and french targets in neighbouring iraq. kurdish forces, bolstered by us and uk air strikes, have gained ground against the islamic state on the strategically important syrian-turkish border.
1167	dr. anand kamath, an nhs dentist who never turned away patients, was driven to suicide when health authorities threatened to strike him off for his record-keeping. his wife accused health chiefs of treating her husband "like bullies." kamath, 42, faced an investigation after nhs officials criticized his record-keeping, which had worsened due to his 10,000-patient list. the british dental association now calls for an nhs inquiry into his death.
1168	more than five million people in the uk go undiagnosed with high blood pressure, which has been called britain's biggest 'silent killer' as it doesn't cause any symptoms. high blood pressure can lead to life-threatening conditions like strokes, heart attacks, or kidney failure. to prevent such deaths and complications, experts recommend reducing salt intake, maintaining a healthy weight, and avoiding excessive alcohol consumption. companies should offer high-quality blood pressure testing for staff at work, and the government is urging for the nation's blood pressure levels to be tested more frequently and encourages people to keep up with regular checks.
1169	luis suarez may face a long ban for allegedly biting an opponent during uruguay's key world cup victory over italy. even though he claims the incident was an accident, fifa has opened disciplinary proceedings against him, and if found guilty, could face a ban of up to 24 games or two years according to the fifa disciplinary code.
1170	a furious husband, rintu karmakar, aged 60, lost his temper when he returned home from work and found that his wife, monu, aged 55, had not cooked his meal or done any housework. infuriated, he tried to cut her head off with an axe while she slept, but this failed, so he resorted to using a scythe. he confessed to police that he had decapitated her and brought her head to the station. although he initially seemed calm, he later showed them his wife's head, prompting the arrest.
1171	alabama's chief justice intervened to try and keep the state's unconstitutional same-sex marriage ban in place, ordering probate judges to turn away same-sex couples seeking marriage licenses. suspicion of enforcing the ban was raised since some judges stated they are expecting to follow through with u.s. district judge callie granade's ruling that ruled the ban unconstitutional.
1172	the wealthy donors are being called upon to use their money to help save the environment and fight against climate change. some wealthy individuals have already contributed or pledged to contribute large amounts of money to various philanthropic and environmental causes. there are concerns about the effectiveness of such donations, given the potential for poor results due to a lack of adequate oversight, the need for ethical decision-making, and the potential for the donations to be used for non-environmental objectives. nonetheless, the concept of philanthropy among the rich has the potential to significantly impact global environmental issues.
1173	a 35-year-old businessman from africa admitted to a horrific cannibalistic act, where he ripped a man's heart out and ate it alive after insulting him, claiming it was to show he was not gay. andrew chimboza, originally from zimbabwe, killed mbuyiselo manona, 62, in self-defense at a client's home. while chimboza initially claimed self-defense, it was found that the heart was not in the deceased's body, meaning the victim was still alive at the time of chimboza's consumption.
1174	surrey has signed kumar sangakkara, the top-ranked sri lankan test batsman with 12,203 runs, due to his retirement from one-day international cricket after this year's world cup. sangakkara is expected to play for most of the county season, though the specific dates are yet to be determined. surrey's director of cricket, alec stewart, is thrilled about the addition of the talented player and his positive influence on the club. 
1175	during a south africa-usa match at the hsbc sevens world series, a fan rushed the pitch and tackled player perry baker. baker, in turn, kicked the fan in the stomach as the fan lay on the field, leading to a disagreement online between supporters. baker apologized soon after, and the american player has received criticism but also support online.
1176	in 2013, uk prime minister, david cameron, dismissed a suggestion from princess anne to consider eating horsemeat as a way to improve horse welfare. princess anne argued that france's higher standards for animal care would result if britain could embrace horsemeat. however, cameron, an enthusiastic horse rider, stated that he was not keen on the idea and wanted to "stick to our non-horse eating habits."
1177	sony has launched the waterproof android smartphone xperia z ultra featuring a 6.4-inch screen, making it the largest display and thinnest large-screen smartphone on the market. the smartphone can be submerged in water up to 1.5 meters and allows the user to take pictures and film videos in full hd underwater. it includes a qualcomm snapdragon 800 processor, which sony claims is the world's fastest, and handwriting recognition software. it was introduced alongside the sony smartwatch 2 sw2, a 'second screen' for any android phone featuring remote control of calls, emails, music volume, and taking pictures.
1178	formula one drivers were left frustrated as the second practice for the monaco grand prix was marred by wet conditions. a heavy downpour before the session left the drivers in the garage for most of the 90 minutes until the circuit dried enough for a full complement of cars to be on the track. fernando alonso in his ferrari finished quickest in drying conditions, but mercedes duo lewis hamilton and nico rosberg posted best times with hamilton leading by 0.032 seconds. the monaco grand prix final practice will take place on saturday.
1179	maria bartiromo, a veteran tv anchor and financial reporter, ended her 20-year tenure at cnbc on an emotional note, breaking down in tears during her last day at the network. bartiromo's departure comes after she announced a move to fox business network. she was the first journalist to report live from the floor of the new york stock exchange and is known for her high-profile work and photogenic looks. her last day at cnbc was marked with an emotional clap-off at the nyse and a high-record day of the dow jones industrial average. maria bartiromo has already taped her final episode of 'on the money' and her co-host will be joined by cnbc's rising star kelly evans.
1180	a man named mark hibberd, who was in a relationship with suzanne clarkson and described her as his 'soulmate', stole over £3,000 belonging to clarkson's five-year-old daughter after her death. additionally, he also took over £1,200 raised through charity events for the child. when clarkson inherited money, hibberd took it for himself. at court, he denied stealing from the charity funds, but admitted to stealing from the inherited money and was sentenced to eight months' imprisonment, suspended for a year, and 200 hours community work.
1181	in a new delhi neighborhood, residents wait for government water tankers and face water shortages. to address this issue, the government plans to install 500 "water atms" across the city as an innovative solution initiated by an indian social enterprise sarvajal. this solar-powered solution provides cheap access to water, alleviating concerns over health and daily activities. 
1182	a husband in tennessee claiming self-defense, fatally shot his wife after she threatened him with a knife because he refused to remove his shoes that belonged to her father. the shooting took place at their home on moore lane, culleoka, and the husband was later released due to his self-defense claim. no charges have been filed, and an investigation will be conducted before any decision is made.
1183	in south africa, a judge must decide if oscar pistorius intentionally killed his girlfriend, reeva steenkamp, by firing four shots through a locked door. if he knew she was behind the door, he could be sentenced for life in prison, but if he did not, he could be convicted of a lesser crime called culpable homicide. pistorius claims that he made a mistake and thought he was defending himself from an intruder. the judge will make her decision after analyzing the case and considering two experts known as assessors. pistorius is facing four charges, including murder, as well as two weapons charges and a charge related to having ammunition without a proper license. his verdict could influence the sentence.
1184	in a nutshell, johnny manziel faced controversy surrounding his drinking and partying after he missed a saturday morning team treatment session, due to oversleeping, and consequently was fined by the cleveland browns. despite recent scandals, manziel remains with the team and partied at nightclubs in miami for new year's eve. some argue that he should seek professional help for his problematic drinking behavior, although the quarterback has yet to respond to critics.
1185	scientists have developed a new way to take pictures called compressed ultrafast photography, able to generate 2d color images at up to 100 billion frames per second. this new technique uses ultrasonically compressed pulses of laser light to capture images of fast-moving objects or phenomena that are usually not observable. researchers hope the technique will revolutionize science and open up new areas of research, particularly in biomedicine and astronomy.
1186	the immigration minister, mark harper, resigns after employing an illegal colombian cleaner at his south london second home in 2007. he may now face a £5,000 fine for not keeping copies of the immigration papers shown to him by the cleaner to prove her legitimacy in the uk. harper was tipped by many to become the uk prime minister but faced criticism for not keeping proper checks on her, despite previous home office investigations finding that illegal immigrants can often provide fake passports and other documentation easily.
1187	a 45-year-old man called barry wilkes from birmingham, uk overcame cancer by undergoing a six-hour surgery where a tumor weighing almost one and a half stone, twice the size of his heart, was removed from his stomach. the tumor was responsible for the majority of the weight loss barry experienced during his stay at the queen elizabeth hospital in november. as a result, he did not need chemotherapy or radioactive therapy.
1188	syria's leading opposition movement warns of an imminent government "massacre" in the city of homs, designed to suppress activists. reports, videos, and information obtained by activists on the ground indicate that the regime may commit a massacre to quell the revolution in homs and to discipline other syrian cities that have joined the protests, potentially leading to massive casualties. additionally, at least 17 people were killed in homs and 29 in other parts of syria on friday, according to opposition group, local coordination committees of syria.
1189	john mcafee, a software pioneer, was arrested in guatemala after being on the run for about a month. he was deported from guatemala and will be called to the u.s., ending his illegal entry to belize. mcafee claimed belize officials wanted to persecute him and said they might harm him if he turned himself in for questioning. although left behind by mcafee, his 20-year-old girlfriend sam vanegas was still in guatemala.
1190	the cia director, leon panetta, and the director of national intelligence (dni), dennis blair, have a power struggle due to their overlapping roles in intelligence. the cia director primarily runs the spy agency, while the dni focuses on overseeing the larger intelligence community. the setup has a natural tension between the positions, and some suggest it is not functioning ideally. however, the pair are determined to work cooperatively and maintain a good relationship.
1191	michael foley, brother of beheaded journalist james foley, hopes western nations work together to fight kidnappers like isis, as inconsistent messages send the wrong message to militants. foley also hopes people honor james by donating to a scholarship fund set up in his name, go.mu.edu/remember-foley.
1192	a 14-year-old special needs student is accused of coaxing her 19-year-old boyfriend into stabbing to death her father in maryland. the teenager, morgan lane arnold, and her boyfriend, jason anthony bulmer, planned the murder over facebook and skype for months. they allegedly planned to kill the victim's fiance but didn't get the chance. arnold is due for a preliminary hearing, while bulmer faces a similar proceeding in june.
1193	over 500 surgeries in england may be forced to close within the next year due to an increasing number of general practitioners (gps) reaching retirement age, posing a threat to the local community and putting more pressure on neighboring surgeries. thousands of patients may be forced to travel further to see a gp, and waiting times at these practices will lengthen further. the royal college of gps warns of a severe shortage of younger doctors to replace retiring gps, potentially exacerbating the situation. david cameron aimed to ensure everyone could see their family doctor seven days a week by 2020, but senior gps worry these plans may not work with a shortage of doctors to provide services at weekends.
1194	thomas müller scored a penalty in front of a virtually empty luzhniki stadium, helping bayern munich beat cska moscow 1-0 in a uefa champions league match. the match was held behind closed doors as a punishment for racist chants by cska fans during a previous game. the lack of atmosphere did little to distract bayern, as they held onto the lead.
1195	a federal immigration board rejected an appeal for a stay of deportation for alleged nazi war crimes suspect, john demjanjuk. demjanjuk is being sought by germany for his alleged involvement in killings at a nazi camp during wwii. if deported, this would close the case in one of the longest-running pursuits of an alleged holocaust perpetrator and pave the way for a german war crimes trial.
1196	during world war ii, a cunning plan called "starfish" was executed to build decoy towns and set them alight as a way to fool the luftwaffe into believing they hit their targets. the starfish sites, which got their name from the initials 'sf' for 'special fire' sites, were intended to simulate burning cities during the blitz. the dummy towns were sited miles away from communities and cities likely to come under attack. emergency teams would extinguish the flames, light the decoy fires, and race to ignite them when the first wave of german bombers hit a real target. the ruse was developed by colonel john turner and was considered a stroke of dad's army-style genius. around 230 dummy airfields were built in the uk, and a total of 400 fake urban and industrial sites were created to confuse the germans. by the end of the war, 237 starfish sites had been constructed, successfully diverting 730 bombing raids to protected targets.
1197	a federal jury convicted an arkansas doctor, randeep mann, in the february 2009 car bomb attack on the head of the state's medical board. mann will face up to life in prison and his wife, sangeeta mann, faces up to 20 years in prison for conspiring to conceal evidence and obstruct the investigation. mann was convicted of several charges, including using a weapon of mass destruction against a person and property, using an explosive resulting in personal injury, and possession of 98 unregistered grenades.
1198	the european space agency's (esa) big horn is part of the most powerful sound system in europe to subject satellites and spacecraft to the same noise a launcher produces. it can generate noise of 154 decibels, which is like standing close to multiple jets taking off. no humans can survive hearing it when turned to its maximum volume, so it's shut away behind reinforced walls. its use also has potential military, terrorist, and crowd-control applications, but risks causing hearing loss and disorientation if not properly utilized.
1199	on april 20, 2013, a devastating avalanche occurred in colorado, killing five people, including experienced snowboarders and a skier. the victims included christopher peters, joseph timlin, ryan novack, ian lamphere, and rick gaukel. another snowboarder, jerome boulay, was buried but survived. the group had been participating in a snowboarding event called the rocky mountain high backcountry bash to raise money for the colorado avalanche information center when the disaster struck. the avalanche happened near loveland pass in the rocky mountains, where many backcountry skiers and snowboarders flock during the springtime as conditions become dangerous, despite ongoing warnings from authorities.
1200	actress tina malone, 51, spoke about her experiences becoming pregnant at 18 and 50 after a gruelling ivf process, revealing her desire to have a child again. despite the difficulties, she expresses her happiness and feels ready for another pregnancy. malone, best known for playing mimi maguire in the channel 4 sitcom shameless, documented her journey through pregnancy in a tlc documentary. her autobiography, "back in control," is available now.
1201	in 2005, ryan brunn took a polygraph test and lied about his involvement in the murder of 7-year-old jorelys rivera. eventually, brunn was arrested and confessed to the crime. he later pled guilty and was sentenced to life in prison. later, brunn hanged himself in prison. the case showed the limitations of polygraph tests and emphasized the importance of careful and thorough investigations in solving crimes.

1203	french reality star nabilla benattia, also known as "france's kim kardashian," has been arrested for allegedly attempting to murder her boyfriend in paris. the 22-year-old model, who was originally arrested for "assault and battery," was held at a police station after her boyfriend, fellow reality tv star thomas vergara, was stabbed in the throat and chest during a heated argument. prosecutors have upgraded the charge against benattia after seeing vergara's injuries.
1204	an alitalia jet experienced trouble during its landing at rome's leonardo da vinci airport, causing it to crash-land and skid off the runway. ten passengers received minor cuts and bruises, and about ten 'code green' injuries were treated at the airport. both the plane's pilot and passengers were able to evacuate the affected aircraft safely through emergency slides. the incident is now under investigation.

1208	a 25-year-old man from southwestern missouri, brian williams, has been charged with four counts of murder for the killing of three people, including a pregnant woman and her unborn child. williams appeared in court and was jailed without bond on four counts of murder and armed criminal action. he is also alleged to have tampered with a motor vehicle, manufactured meth in a meth lab, and stolen a gun. williams has a criminal history dating back to 2008, which could increase his prison sentence.

1211	in response to north korea's nuclear threats and provocations, the us must focus on realistic assessments of five key factors: the north's intentions, the danger involved, the efficacy of dialogue, the approach to china, and the role of alliances. the main challenge is to establish a sustained pressure that constrains weapons development and proliferation while maintaining stability and cooperation with china. a strong trilateral plan including the us, south korea, and japan on missile defense, intelligence sharing, and missile defense collaboration is key for addressing north korea's threat.
1212	nigel evans, the deputy speaker of britain's house of commons, denies the allegations of rape and sexual assault made against him, calling the claims "completely false." the police arrested a 55-year-old man in northwest england regarding offenses alleged from two men in their 20s. the alleged events took place in pendleton between july 2009 and march 2013. evans had previously served as vice chairman of the tory party and a prominent gay rights activist in england.
1213	in the wake of a failed christmas day bombing on northwest flight 253, the united states is increasing air passenger screening, particularly for individuals flying from 14 nations the country deems "state sponsors of terrorism or other countries of interest." 300 more full-body scanning machines are being ordered for u.s. airports, but some security experts suggest that a more proactive approach is needed for greater safety. isaac yeffet, the former head of security for el al and currently an aviation security consultant in new york, believes that focusing on well-trained and qualified agents interviewing all passengers is the key to preventing future terrorism.
1214	monsanto, a giant american 'frankenstein food' company, has stopped attempting to force genetically modified crops (gm crops) on dinner tables in britain and europe, primarily as a result of low interest from farmers and consumers in growing or eating them. this announcement comes despite uk secretary of state owen paterson's efforts to actively support gm farming and food, as he launches series of initiatives to overcome scepticism and accelerate approvals in europe. however, monsanto and other gm companies are now significantly scaling back or even abandoning attempts to get their crops accepted in europe. supermarkets, such as marks & spencer, sainsbury's, and the co-op, have begun allowing the use of gm soya and maize in animal feed, despite claims that these moves come at the expense of non-gmo supplies from brazil, usa, and other destinations. these supermarkets fail to label products accordingly, in contrast with a european trend of transparency and shoppers' preferences.
1215	two police officers in victoria, australia, were caught on film seemingly ignoring parking rules while enjoying an iced coffee at a café. the video featuring the officers, reportedly from the victoria police, gained over 230,000 views within 21 hours, with the unnamed facebook member uploading it to the group 'victoria police corruption'. the video shows officers parked within meters of a no standing zone, with the person filming questioning their actions. victoria police stated that employees are 'required to park police vehicles legally at all times', adding that an exemption is in place for emergency vehicles.
1216	lisa swinton mclaughlin, age 56, died seven days after giving birth to twins after 30 years of longing to have a child. she was a medical director at the american red cross in baltimore, maryland, and passed away from a bowel obstruction, despite being in pain which she believed was the result of a cesarean section surgery scar. her husband, mike mclaughlin, 67, who is now raising their two sons alone, mentioned that this was the happiest he had ever seen her in his lifetime.
1217	new york giants star david diehl was charged with drunk driving after he was found to have a blood alcohol level of .182 percent, more than twice the legal limit. the 31-year-old nfl player had been in a bar watching croatia beat the republic of ireland 3-1 in the european championship when the incident occurred. diehl, a 6'5, 304lb offensive linesman for the giants, pleaded no contest to the charge and was sentenced to jail time and a year of driving restrictions.
1218	a story about pope francis allegedly saying animals can go to heaven became viral, but it wasn't true. in a correction, it was mentioned that the pope misquoted scripture on the topic. despite having been told this, the false story continued to spread, showing news outlets' need for fact checking and demonstrating how strong people's feelings are on their pets' experiences in the afterlife.
1219	lance armstrong's ex-fiance sheryl crow has expressed her relief for him following his shocking doping confession last week to oprah winfrey. she discussed the scandal during an interview on entertainment tonight, where she reluctantly spoke about the situation. she emphasized the importance of honesty and stated that carrying a weight of lies is devastating in the long run. "i think that honesty is always the best bet and that the truth will always set you free," she said, "it's got to be really hard walking around, knowing you're not telling the truth about something. i always contend that the truth is the best way to go. to carry around a weight like that would be devastating in the long run." armstrong was once again stripped of his tour de france titles in august after revealing his doping history during his confession. during the two-part interview, armstrong fought back tears as he talked about the impact of his doping on his family.

1223	russia has been suspended from its elite g8 group of leading economies by the remaining countries, including the uk, the us, germany, france, italy, canada, and japan. this group has agreed to meet again without russia until its leader, vladimir putin, "changes course" over ukraine, or the country will remain excluded indefinitely. the g7 leaders have also called on russian leaders to return to discussions as they believe international law has been breached by russia's actions in ukraine. the g8 summit, scheduled to be held in in the russian resort of sochi, was also cancelled, and replaced with a summit to be held in brussels in june without president putin attending for the first time since russia joined the g8 in 1998.
1224	the bodies of four rhinos in south africa's lalibela game reserve were found, with grim images showing bloodied remains close together. forensic teams investigated the scene and it's believed the rhinos were possibly darted before having their horns clinically removed. the deaths come amidst the same week of four rhinos found shot and dehorned in assam, india, sparking outrage. rhino killings in south africa this year have surpassed 400; many of these deaths occur on private reserves due to improved security.
1225	a couple in the marine corps with a young son are both deploying to afghanistan. they will be away for a year, leaving their son behind. the mother has been preparing him for the deployment, saying she and the father will always return for him. they were not officially ordered to go, but the woman volunteered since she hadn't yet deployed. there has been backlash from some people who learn of their decision, but they continue focusing on returning home together.
1226	a detroit-area man, theodore wafer, who claimed he accidentally shot and killed a 19-year-old woman he thought was breaking into his home, will stand trial on a charge of second-degree murder, as there is enough probable cause. district court judge david turfe ruled that there was enough cause to believe that wafer made a bad choice when he armed himself with a shotgun instead of seeking help upon seeing renisha mcbride on his porch. wafer's next court appearance is scheduled for january 15th.
1227	on january 28, 2012, violence in syria reached new heights as the syrian free army stepped up its mission to control the streets from the government forces. the article states that opposition forces have split control of damascus among rival gunmen fighting for or against president bashar assad. two days of bloody carnage resulted in at least 74 deaths. the arab league observer in syria, sudanese general mohammed ahmed al-dabi, said violence in the country has spiked over the past few days. however, international pressure on damascus to end the violence has produced few results, as the un security council has been unable to agree on a resolution due to strong opposition from russia and china.
1228	electronic cigarettes might be included in the smoking ban in wales, with health ministers in wales proposing to ban them in indoor public places such as pubs and restaurants, due to concerns they might normalize smoking and act as a gateway to conventional cigarettes. the proposal has not reached further in england yet.
1229	starting november 2015, people in aberdeen (01224), bradford (01274), brighton (01273), middlesbrough (01642), and milton keynes (01908) will need to include the full area code when calling local homes and businesses. the move is intended to prevent the uk from running out of landline numbers and is expected to create nearly one million new numbers. the move will have no effect on call costs, and the shift in telephone use toward mobile phones and internet calling is expected to reduce the demand for new landline numbers.
1230	monsignor victor rene rodriguez, a high-ranking mexican catholic church official, receives reports of threats, extortion, and abuse towards priests by drug traffickers. drug-related violence, particularly in states like chihuahua, has caused a growing risk for catholic worshippers. some priests have been forced into confronting drug traffickers and mincing for them, while others have reported being attacked or killed. mexico city's catholic population represents 90% of the country's total population, and evangelical churches have also faced similar threats. in response, the mexican catholic church has taken several precautionary measures for its priests.
1231	bradford west mp george galloway received police questioning following a public speech, in which he called israel an "illegal, barbarous, savage state" and proclaimed that he wouldn't "silence" his opposition to their actions. the police probe began after galloway's controversial comments and was influenced by an earlier statement made by israeli ambassador daniel taub.
1232	uefa football club barcelona has been hit by a 2-window transfer ban after breaking fifa rules for recruiting young international players. the club will now have to appeal against the ruling and is expected to face severe consequences if unsuccessful. the transfer ban means they won't be able to sign both senior and youth players in the next two transfer windows.
1233	christian eriksen credits mauricio pochettino's pre-season training regime for driving tottenham's success, with increased belief and character. the side has benefited from four goals in the last five minutes in premier league fixtures this season, resulting in nine points, and a key moment was when eriksen rescued his side with a last-minute strike in the 2-1 win at swansea city. despite these victories, eriksen is concerned they are not performing consistently in the season that has seen them beaten six times in the league.
1234	thousands of protesters in montreal have marked the 100th day of demonstrations against planned tuition hikes in the province of quebec, resulting in no arrests after police and protesters agreed to a planned route. earlier this month, an "emergency law" prohibited mass gatherings without advanced written details and the route information given to police.

1237	a pit bull named mickey, previously declared vicious after it mauled a 4-year-old boy, will spend the rest of its life at an animal shelter created by maricopa county's controversial sheriff, joe arpaio. arpaio offered to take in the dog himself to show his compassionate side, and the judge overseeing the case granted his request to house the animal in the shelter. arpaio will continue to take care of mickey and similar cases, despite his office facing a civil rights lawsuit. 
1238	claire craig, a mother of two and interior designer, initially assumed her numb fingers were due to a nip from her puppy. over time, her symptoms worsened, leading to a diagnosis of a brain tumor. despite her tumor being relatively benign, her road to recovery was lengthy and difficult. now, four years later, her experience serves as an example of the progress being made in the field but also reveals that more research into brain tumors is still necessary.
1239	on july 2, 2013, then-president barack obama and former president george w. bush met in africa on a chance encounter. they honored the victims of a terrorist attack in dar es salaam by visiting a monument and paying their respects. both presidents initially did not plan to meet, but they eventually came together. their wives, michelle obama and laura bush, later engaged in a warm and chatty joint appearance at a summit on african women.
1240	a subsidiary of peanut corporation of america in texas potentially has salmonella in its products, which led to the company voluntarily closing its plant on monday night. the state's health department has been investigating the situation, while the fda is ensuring there have been no illnesses linked to plainview products. state investigators and the fda are working with the company to establish the necessary criteria for resuming production. other companies have also faced a dip in sales due to the salmonella outbreak.
1241	google is lobbying u.s. states to stop proposals to restrict the use of google glass while driving, as concerns mount over distracted driving and legal issues with the technology. there are eight regions in the u.s. currently considering restrictions on google glass and wearable technology, particularly with the potential for billions-dollar market growth as wearables develop.
1242	edward snowden claimed that he had the authority to wiretap anyone, violating the laws of physics. however, the national security agency (nsa) has access to metadata and does not store or analyze content of conversations, as confirmed by the intelligence committees of congress and nsa advisor steve bradbury. the metadata program, which focuses on determining potential terrorists, was approved by at least 14 federal judges every 90 days since 2006. 
1243	in 2013, four republican lawmakers suggested classifying bombing suspect dzhokhar tsarnaev, 19 years old at the time, as an 'enemy combatant' without reading him his miranda rights. the lawmakers argued that the 19-year-old naturalized us citizen, accused of causing the boston marathon bombings, should not be given these rights because terrorists shouldn't remain silent. however, the american civil liberties union (aclu) criticized this suggestion, labeling it as 'un-american.' the obama administration's department of justice was considering the 'enemy combatant' option, but ultimately sought the death penalty in tsarnaev's case.
1244	fusilier lee rigby was brutally murdered in 2013 by two extremists. the greenwich council initially agreed to build a commemorative site for rigby, but later decided not to name it after him due to concerns that it may offend islamic fanatics. instead, an inscription at the site reads, "to commemorate all those servicemen and women who have served or lived in woolwich and who gave given their lives." some critics have called this decision "disgusting," but rigby's family and supporters are accepting of the location and commemoration being proposed.
1245	chris hemsworth, known for his role as thor in marvel's movies, was recently named the "sexiest man alive" by people magazine. although he is often referred to as "that guy from 'the hunger games,'" chris hemsworth is actually the ripped australian actor and tv personality. his younger brother liam recently starred in the film franchise.
1246	ebola has been eradicated from the democratic republic of congo, the world health organization announced. the un health agency credited the country's leadership and coordinated response, including monitoring those with the disease and the people they had been in contact with, for the milestone. the drc has had 38 confirmed and 28 probable ebola cases in recent months, and 49 people, including eight health-care workers, have died of the virus. despite the good news, ebola remains a potential threat in other regions, notably west africa.
1247	thierry henry, former footballer, is set to make his big screen debut in 2015, with a short cameo appearance in the entourage movie. the entertainer will join actor adrian grenier and sportscaster adrian grenier on the film's set earlier this year. although henry is enjoying a retirement from soccer, he has joined sky sports and plans to earn his coaching badges for the hope of one day managing arsenal, where he previously played for eight years.
1248	in london, a rare gathering of iconic routemaster buses was held to celebrate the diamond jubilee of the routemaster association, with around 130 buses parading through the city's finsbury park. these buses, which have been recalled from france, scotland, and germany, are a nostalgic tribute to the original style that once dominated public transport in london, with only two heritage routes using these buses currently in operation. the occasion was a joyous celebration of the routemaster's 60th anniversary, as well as an opportunity for enthusiasts and history buffs to appreciate the unique design and significance of these iconic vehicles.
1249	australian national broadcaster, abc, has refused to apologise to military officer, captain cate mcgregor, following anti-transgender tweets that appeared during a q&a program. some viewers called for the moderator's sacking, while the abc argued the tweets were within broadcast guidelines. captain mcgregor is thought to be one of the highest-profile military officers and has been praised for her appearance on q&a and her reaction to the controversial tweets.
1250	a disturbing video surfaced of a search vessel being violently tossed by waves in the south indian ocean while searching for mh370, leading to the temporary suspension of the search due to intense tropical cyclone conditions.
1251	the united nations (u.n.) says that congolese women were held in a prison and systematically raped by uniformed men, in incidents that also resulted in the deaths of three people and caused victims to return to the congo in the nude and with no belongings. the rapes were reported to the u.n. on saturday. over 20 congolese women were also raped in another region of the democratic republic of the congo. the u.n. office for humanitarian affairs expressed concern and encouraged expulsions to happen with respect for human rights. 
1252	prince charles has warned that many britons have lost any real connection with the land and are increasingly suspicious about farming. while people treasure the countryside, they should not take its benefits such as landscapes, and local foods for granted, or they might lose them. the prince of wales aims to keep the countryside in great condition and preserve the land, villages, and farms for future generations.
1253	to summarize this in a few sentences: france is sending four state police units to guadeloupe, an overseas department, after months of sometimes violent demonstrations over low wages and living conditions. the situation is serious, but not new, and the french president, prime minister, and french interior minister are all responding to the ongoing crisis. officials are ready to approve a compromise to give a monthly supplement to workers in guadeloupe with low-paying jobs to help alleviate their living conditions. several demonstrators were shot, and one has died as tensions with the police persist. 
1254	a pregnant former olympic runner, meskerem legesse, passed away at the age of 26, days before her due date, after collapsing at a connecticut restaurant. doctors were able to save her baby, as the eight-months pregnant ethiopian athlete had a heart attack minutes after arriving at the establishment. she was known for her careful health habits during her pregnancy, and her excitement for the birth of her daughter, who was named athena. legesse was set to return to ethiopia for the first time in nine years to visit her mother.
1255	president barack obama visited his adopted hometown of chicago to garner support for his executive action on immigration reform, highlighting frustrations in communities of color over unequal law enforcement. he also noted that the bipartisan bill passed by the senate a year and a half ago was unsuccessful due to republican leaders in the house withholding a vote. during his speech, three immigration activists briefly heckled him, calling him the “deporter-in-chief” before obama explained that his executive action is just the beginning of change and that he believes his actions are legal.
1256	roger federer takes on robin soderling, who upset top-ranked rafael nadal, in the french open men's final. a victory would give federer 14 grand slam titles, tying him with american pete sampras. federer faced juan martin del potro in the semifinals but defeated him, setting up a showdown with soderling, who defeated nadal in an earlier round.
1257	a ban on powerful vacuum cleaners is set to take effect in september due to energy efficiency regulations. consumers are advised to purchase these models before they sell out, as companies will be prohibited from manufacturing or importing any vacuums with motors above 1,600 watts. consumer magazine which? said the ban will lead to better vacuum cleaners than ever before but may make house-proud householders' lives harder. the european union's new rules will include energy labels for the vacuum cleaners.
1258	in a tragic incident, stephen avery, a 42-year-old taxi-driver and former local football team manager and coach, lost his life due to heart infection which could have been prevented if doctors had recognized and treated his symptoms 48 hours earlier. inquest findings condemn the hospital staff's mistakes in diagnosing his heart conditions, as the heart expert revealed a compelling testimony. avery, from crossacres, wythenshawe, had visited his gp for multiple times with symptoms indicating a heart infection, but the condition went undiagnosed and untreated until it was too late, eventually leading to his death.
1259	a 33-year-old south sea islander, arihano haiti, was sentenced to 28 years for murdering stefan ramin and sexually assaulting ramin's girlfriend on nuku hiva, french polynesia. haiti was found guilty of killing ramin, a german adventurer, and carving and burning his body. he later admitted to sexually assaulting ramin's girlfriend. prosecutors were unable to prove cannibalism claims in court.
1260	laszlo csatary, a nazi war crimes suspect who was accused of sending more than 15,000 jews to the auschwitz concentration camp during world war ii, has died at the age of 98. he was arrested in 2012 but was not convicted before his death. the simon wiesenthal center, which had considered him the most-wanted nazi war criminal, called it a "very unfortunate end to a saga that lasted far too long," and expressed their hope that csatary would have been brought to justice earlier.
1261	a thank you letter written by slaves from the amistad rebellion in 1841 to former president john quincy adams, who defended them in court and helped them obtain their freedom, has been released by the amistad research center at tulane university. the letter was published to mark the 175th anniversary of the rebellion, and adams was aged 74 when he represented 53 african slaves. the letter contains messages of gratitude from four of the 53 slaves.
1262	russell crowe and henry cavill's chance meeting at a school rugby match over a decade ago played a significant role in cavill's journey to becoming superman. crowe, impressed by cavill's talent on the pitch, sent him a box with various items to let him know his journey began, marking the beginning of their friendship. cavill now stars alongside crowe in the superman reboot, "man of steel."
1263	recently, major incidents have occurred, such as mass shootings and economic crises, which were expected to lead to changes in the way societies function. however, it has been found that our thinking does not adapt even after these crises occur. for example, gun laws and the treatment of the mentally ill have not undergone significant changes, despite numerous mass shootings. additionally, despite new information disproving a study on the effects of public debt and growth, there has been little acknowledgment and change in the prevailing beliefs on the subject. the study of immigration, along with many other issues, seems to follow similar patterns, as new information often goes unnoticed and fails to change long-term opinions.
1264	a university of montevallo student, christian todd slaton, faces four felony charges of first-degree animal cruelty after reportedly dismembering several cats and displaying their remains on campus, including hanging one up on the flag pole. two other cats were found near a sculpture by professor ted metz, and one near slaton's off-campus apartments. slaton has been banned from the university and is due to appear in court on december 12. the animals were reportedly not killed by natural causes.
1265	ukip leader nigel farage has dismissed claims that ukip supports the repatriation of eu migrants who have lived and worked in britain for years. he insists ukip would allow lawful migrants to stay even if the uk leaves the european union. labour criticised his remarks, calling farage's response an echo of the policies british national party. conservative ministers did not condemn mark reckless's remarks.
1266	southampton's current position in the top four of the premier league has surprised even their own players. morgan schneiderlin, who once wanted to leave the team, admits they never expected to recover so quickly from their drastic summer surgeries. victor wanyama's goal against swansea city marked their third consecutive premier league win. southampton is aiming to continue their winning streak and believes it's crucial to improve in the upcoming winter fixtures.
1267	england batsman gary ballance has fractured a finger but has been passed fit for the upcoming world cup. despite the injury, he will remain with the squad and no additional batting cover will be added. ballance has not played yet in australia, remaining with the team for the ongoing tri-series against australia and india.
1268	scientists have discovered the coldest place on earth, where temperatures plummet to -91c. the newly-found spot is situated along an antarctic mountain ridge, where the air temperature could freeze a human's eyes, nose, and lungs within minutes. researchers from america's national snow and ice data centre used satellites and other techniques to measure temperatures in antarctica. the -91.2c spot is even colder than russia's vostok research station, where the world's previous coldest air temperature of -89.2c was recorded in 1983.
1269	the number of hate groups in the us has decreased by 7% since 2012, according to a report from the southern poverty law center. the decline could be due in part to factors such as obama's re-election, an improving economy, and increased law enforcement efforts against hate groups. however, the trend is not consistent, and although hate groups are decreasing, violence and terrorism connected to such groups remain very present in the us.
1270	police are searching for shareef allman, a 45-year-old suspect in a workplace shooting at a california quarry, killing three people and wounding seven others. he then attempted a nearby carjacking, shooting a woman. he was not successful in obtaining the woman's car. allman has a "minor criminal record" and is believed to be armed and dangerous. schools in the area were closed, and authorities have been in contact with the suspect's family.
1271	wayne rooney took physiotherapists with him on his holiday to ensure he is prepared for the world cup event next week despite some concern over his slight groin injury by england manager roy hodgson. other players were advised to unwind for the week in order to be primed for their arrival in brazil. rooney, however, has been injury-free throughout the season and considered an asset to the national team.
1272	former nfl football player and sports commentator deion sanders was delighted to be reunited with his $15,000 german shepherd, yasko, nine months after it went missing. the mystery behind the disappearance of yasko led to rumours that sanders' ex-wife pilar biggers may have been involved, but sanders did not comment on the circumstances.
1273	mohammad, a syrian doctor who moved to the usa five years ago, works long hours in detroit and is an avid fan of the detroit red wings. although he wants to return to his home country, he's convinced that change needs to happen in syria. this mindset has led him to support the syrian revolution and engage in fundraising and public speaking to inform the global community about the violence taking place in his homeland.
1274	benjamin till and nathan taylor tied the knot in a musical that aired on channel 4's our gay wedding: the musical. it was filmed a week before gay marriage became legal in england and wales. the stress-filled experience had the couple having to write and record music and lyrics in just seven weeks. the show features intertwined musical numbers and a mix of real-life guest performers such as stephen fry, jon snow, and ed miliband.
1275	in 2013, a hacker named deric lostutter, known as kyanonymous, publicized incriminating social media posts by high school football players in steubenville, ohio, ridiculing a rape victim. if convicted of hacking crimes, lostutter could face up to 10 years in prison, which is nine years more than the minimum sentence for the convicted football players. he claims he did not hack the website, but received the screenshots and posts from activists online.
1276	mohammed liaqat ali, 37, was sentenced to life in prison for strangling his estranged wife, lilima akter munny, 27, to death in a dispute over a piece of land. the couple's relationship broke down when ali became involved in a land dispute with his wife's mother. ali was also ordered to serve a minimum of 15 years to be behind bars after the killing.
1277	lindsey lowe, a 26-year-old mother, was found guilty today by a tennessee courtroom of the first-degree, premeditated murder of her newborn twin sons. after deliberating for two hours, the jury convicted her on two counts of each felony first-degree murder and felony premeditated murder. sentenced to two-life terms, lowe will be escorted from the courtroom and taken into immediate custody.
1278	amid amy winehouse's reunion with a new man, blake fielder-civil, her ex-husband, seeks divorce proceedings on the grounds of her adultery. the couple, who married in 2007, faced jail time together for drug charges and have been arrested separately on multiple occasions. winehouse, known for her battle with drug addiction, has stated she is "off the drugs for good" and has a new man in her life.
1279	a young couple, cliff henry and fiona hehir, had their elaborate wedding proposal turned into a magical moment by dublin-based band keywest on october 29, which also happened to be fiona's 30th birthday. the moment was captured by a covert film crew, and led to unexpected encounters with u2 frontman bono and his wife ali, who gave their blessing and shared words of wisdom before the proposal. fiona unexpectedly found out about the proposal, and when cliff asked for her response, she needed to be asked twice before accepting. since their engagement, the couple's video has gone viral, and they plan to have keywest perform at their wedding.
1280	world leaders are meeting in seoul to discuss ways to prevent nuclear terrorism and limit the risk of nuclear materials and weapons ending up in the hands of terrorists. one of the most significant threats arises from the nuclear-tipped country pakistan, using proxy groups for national interests. reducing the use of such proxy groups would likely reduce the availability of nuclear material to terrorists. as countries use proxies to serve national interests, finding common ground through understanding fears and establishing transparent policies is key to addressing the issue.
1281	six possible cases of bacterial meningitis, including two deaths, have been reported in students of a rural oklahoma elementary school. two children from the oologah-talala public school district have died from meningococcal disease, and the district canceled school on friday to prevent further spread of the outbreak. the oklahoma state department of health and rogers county health department have introduced antibiotics to prevent the spread of the disease. meningitis symptoms may arise two to 10 days after infection.
1282	liverpool legend ian rush believes mario balotelli still has a future at the club despite his slow start, as he needs to show commitment to the team and learn to play for one of the best clubs in the world. balotelli has scored just one goal since his £16 million transfer from ac milan. the italian forward was substituted at half-time in liverpool's game against real madrid.
1283	a homeless man, ranjit singh, was crushed to death by a large metal-clawed crane at a biffa recycling plant in tipton, west midlands, after he fell asleep in a wheelie bin. night supervisor mark bradshaw discovered singh's mangled body among a pile of rubbish when it was lifted onto a conveyor belt, and emergency services were called. an inquest concluded singh's death was an accident due to catastrophic injuries and a history of alcohol abuse. biffa had several systems in place to help drivers deal with people in and around bins at the time.
1284	two prisoners have confessed to digging a tunnel that led to the escape of 63 inmates last week, yemen's state-run saba news agency reported. dozens of suspected al-qaeda militants escaped from a jail in mukalla, yemen's interior ministry official said. they managed to break out of the jail using a 35-meter (115-foot) tunnel. angry protests against president ali abdullah saleh's rule have dominated yemen for months.
1285	barack obama won the presidential election with a popular vote and an electoral college victory. he received support from diverse groups like women voters, young voters, african-american voters, and latino voters. this victory signaled a new coalition that helped shift the balance of power between red and blue states.
1286	garden & gun magazine has shared five unusual summer vacation ideas in the united states south, featuring a safari-style tent in texas, a bed-and-breakfast on an island in north carolina, treehouses on a private wildlife refuge in south carolina, a sustainable community in georgia, and an african safari-style tent in florida's key largo area. each suggestion offers a unique and memorable experience for travelers seeking an adventure.
1287	in 2013, nearly 50,000 women in the uk and 400,000 worldwide were affected by the pip (poly implant prothese) breast implant scandal. a new national register will log every breast implant operation in england, with marketing control recommendations introduced to prevent such scandals in the future.
1288	bayern munich manager pep guardiola dismisses rumors of a potential return to barcelona as club president joan laporta, saying he does not believe he is the solution for the club. guardiola speaks on barcelona's internal affairs regarding manager luis enrique's future and team dissent among lionel messi and other players.
1289	marks & spencer becomes the first retailer to stock whole wild red grouse, introducing grouse to the high street and sparking interest from the public. m&s is offering the dish as part of a new range of british game, which includes rabbit, wood pigeon, venison, pheasant and partridge, and plans to expand seasonal production in october.
1290	dutch tv presenter and model yolanthe sneijder-cabau recently nominated both louis van gaal, the manchester united manager, and paris hilton for the als ice bucket challenge. both individuals are given 24 hours to either complete the challenge and share their participation on video or make a donation to the als association instead.
1291	liam dalgarno, a baby born with a swollen heart, has made a remarkable recovery following risky surgery. valves in his heart were so narrow that it caused severe pressure on the left side. his mother was told the heart swelled to the size of a football, but liam had six additional operations to fix his heart leading to living like any other healthy three-year-old.
1292	protests continue in st. louis, missouri, as demonstrators gather in shaw to protest the fatal shooting of 18-year-old black teenager vonderrit myers jr. by an off-duty police officer on wednesday. demonstrators burned american flags, blackened intersections, and banged drums, while shops and storefronts were subsequently vandalized and glass windows shattered, littering the streets with broken glass. protesters also burned images of president obama and other symbols. on thursday, the situation escalated as police officers in riot gear faced off against protesters, who used pepper spray in response.

1294	a major sydney hospital has discovered a fault in a refrigerator containing vaccines, possibly exposing them to slightly above optimal temperatures since august 2013. a precautionary attempt to contact over 570 women who gave birth and received these vaccines is ongoing, as the effectiveness of the vaccines is uncertain. however, royal prince alfred hospital assures the public that there is no risk and maintains their high-quality patient care. a free clinic will re-vaccinate affected individuals, while investigations aim to determine how this issue occurred.

1296	paul hudson, a bbc weather presenter, claimed that nearly every met office forecast for the annual global temperature has been "too warm" for the past decade. the met office's predictions have been wrong 13 out of the last 14 years, all of which were "on the warm side," according to hudson. this bias may be due to a lack of observational data from the arctic circle, as well as the absorption of heat by deeper areas of the ocean.
1297	the king power stadium saw arsenal lose two points against leicester city, who won via a goal from leonardo ulloa two minutes after alexis sanchez's opener. although arsene wenger's team controlled the match, leicester put on a strong performance, maintaining their aggressive play. arsenal continue to be hindered by their inability to find consistent fluency in their play, but wenger's reluctance to act hastily on signing a new centre forward is a testament to his confidence in his current options.
1298	on march 27, 2013, carl pistorius, the brother of double amputee athlete oscar pistorius and facing culpable homicide charges, went on trial in a south african court. carl pistorius, who was wearing a dark suit, was accompanied by his sister aimee as he faced the charge, equivalent to negligent killing in britain. initial proceedings focused on whether the trial should be broadcast live and covered by photographers.
1299	a massive security operation is being carried out in ireland ahead of queen elizabeth's visit next week. over 6,000 police officers, defence forces members, and military aircraft will be deployed in dublin and other locations along her itinerary. anti-aircraft guns, a special forces unit, and bomb disposal teams are also being prepared for potential threats. the operation is estimated to cost €30m ($42m), and surveillance has been intensified on known dissidents, who are planning demonstrations. the queen and her husband will be staying in the phoenix park, which will be closed for her protection.
1300	in 2010, french company poly implant protheses (pip) made breast implants using industrial-grade silicone instead of medical-grade gel, which contained more contaminants. these implants, used in 65 countries worldwide, including 300,000 women, have been linked to a health scare, causing increased incidence of rupture, inflammation and possibly other health risks. pip founder jean-claude mas was charged with involuntary injury and is under investigation. the implants, once the third-largest supplier, are banned. the company went bankrupt, and mas is blaming media pressure and intense fear. there is no money for compensation for victims, and some are calling for government regulation of the plastic surgery industry and building insurance into national health systems for elective procedures.
1301	lutfur rahman, britain's first elected muslim mayor, is accused of using illegal tactics to win the mayoral election in tower hamlets, east london in may. voters were allegedly promised council houses if they backed rahman and were told they should be "good muslims" and support him. rahman's supporters are accused of doctoring ballot papers, manipulating postal voting, and sabotaging the chances of his main rival, labour candidate john briggs, by branding him racist and anti-islamic. four voters in a damaging dossier of evidence have submitted to the high court in an attempt to have the allegations heard at a full trial, expected to be held in tower hamlets later this year.
1302	malcolm gladwell's new book "outliers" explores why some people are successful and why others with the same intelligence or abilities may fall short. he finds connections between the beatles, bill gates and canadian hockey players, and reasons why planes operated by certain cultures have a greater likelihood of crashing. success, gladwell argues, is not just about individual intelligence or talent, but also involves factors such as opportunity, hard work, timing, and luck.
1303	a chacma baboon in zambia at victoria falls refused to move from a bench when tourists approached, choosing to enjoy the sunshine and even defying them by sucking its finger. the baboons are very used to tourists, leading to many photo opportunities for visitors.
1304	sarah sellers, a former fda employee, experienced frustration when she couldn't effectively help clean up compounding pharmacies, which create customized medication solutions for patients. compounded drugs can carry risks as demonstrated by deaths and infections that have occurred in connection with these pharmacies. despite acknowledgement of the issue from the gao and numerous outbreaks, new sterility guidelines for compounding pharmacies have not been introduced. despite pressure and challenges from the industry, critics say the problem is bigger than just a few outbreaks as illnesses might not be traced back to contaminated drugs.
1305	prince philip, the duke of edinburgh, was taken to hospital yesterday with abdominal pains. the hospitalization came after a grueling four-hour thames pageant on sunday, which is one of the events in celebration of queen elizabeth ii's diamond jubilee. philip has undergone minor heart surgery in the past and has been diagnosed with a bladder infection, and is now at king edward vii hospital in london under the care of doctors for several days as a precaution. the queen, who has been by her husband's side, will continue with her diamond jubilee celebrations alone, but the rest of the planned events, including today's service of thanksgiving at st paul's cathedral and the flypast over buckingham palace, will go ahead as planned.
1306	aria, a 15-year-old yazidi girl living in the khanke refugee camp in iraq, tells her story of escape from terror, abuse, and death at the hands of isis militants. aria and her friend were captured and forced into marriage when they were driven to mosul, the islamic state's stronghold in iraq. aria and the girls were raped, and in some cases killed, if they did not convert to the islamic faith. aria eventually escaped and reunited with her family in the refugee camp.
1307	thomson, a holiday company, is phasing out their iconic superclubs and fishbowls in favor of a new brand for young travelers called thomson scene. the new brand will appeal to 18-35-years-olds who seek more sophisticated trip experiences with trendy accommodations and stylish new destinations like goa in india, santorini in greece, and ibiza. the portfolio will offer two segments: thomson scene hub for the younger, budget-conscious travelers, and thomson scene style for the more sophisticated, higher-spending travelers. this move will see the end of their 2wenty concept, reflecting a departure from large, uniform, all-inclusive style hotels for the younger demographic.
1308	a group of killer whales who were trapped beneath ice in canada's hudson bay are not visible and are in danger, but emergency crews are still prepared. eleven whales were trapped in a small area trying to survive, but after overnight wind changes, the ice broke giving them some more space. the whales last seen wednesday afternoon, are no longer near the town and emergency crews are ready if needed. the incident inspired a celebrated rescue and the 2012 film "big miracle".
1309	media tycoon alexander lebedev is ordered to serve his 150-hour punishment in cleaning or repairing a remote russian village, popovka, as disciplinary action for throwing punches at a property mogul in a tv show. the 53-year-old will be working two to four hours a day in the village and must complete his sentence before moving back to moscow.
1310	israeli president shimon peres emphasizes the need for a two-state solution in his discussion with us envoy, george mitchell. both sides must prioritize peace efforts to take advantage of the current "historic period." prime minister benjamin netanyahu's opposition to an independent palestinian state has cast doubt on the future of the peace process. obama has called on israel to stop construction of settlements in occupied territories, but netanyahu has refused, insisting on natural growth in settlement blocs and ongoing discussions.
1311	german authorities are investigating whether to prosecute a former nazi camp guard living in the united states for 60 years, following evidence presented in 1994. johann breyer admitted to being a perimeter guard at auschwitz concentration camp, where more than 1 million people, most of them jews, were killed during world war ii. authorities are seeking a ruling on whether or not german law can be applied to the case, set to receive preliminary results in october.
1312	chinese filmmaker chen kaige, known for his exploration of love, passion, and friendship in his work, struggled to forgive himself for denouncing his father during the cultural revolution when he was a teenage red guard. his latest film, "forever enthralled," delves into the world of beijing opera and serves as a tribute to his father's work. chen kaige hopes future generations of filmmakers can bring to light the truth behind the cultural revolution and give chinese citizens a better understanding of that crucial period in their history.
1313	fired designer, leanne phillips, won her unfair dismissal case against "my big fat gypsy wedding" dressmaker thelma madine, after the tribunal described her action as "unreasonable" and criticised her for making it based on personal factors rather than business reasons. the judge also mentioned a highly volatile atmosphere at the bridal shop, highlighting that it needed to focus more on work and less on drama for the television show.
1314	bernard hopkins, a 49-year-old former champion, returned to the boxing ring after suffering a crushing defeat to sergey kovalev. hopkins, who will never retire as an underdog, announced he will fight 'one more time'. he reiterated there will be dignity in his retirement and he won't cheat or shortchange himself or his legacy.
1315	japan airlines plans to slash jobs by more than a third, seek a 521.5 billion yen ($6.2 billion) debt waiver, and receive a 350 billion yen ($4.2 billion) investment from the state-backed turnaround initiative. the airline will cut 45 money-losing routes, replace aging planes, and partner with american airlines to focus on trans-pacific routes in an effort to return to profitability. upon completion of the overhaul, the company hopes to go public once again by the end of 2012 and achieve profitability by the end of fiscal 2010.

1318	steve carter, a 35-year-old software salesman, stumbled upon his own missing children's website a year ago and made a self-discovery. carter, adopted at age 4 from an orphanage in honolulu, found himself after curiously exploring the website and recognized himself on an age-progressed image. carter soon volunteered for a dna test and got confirmed fragments of his story. he had been named marx panama moriarty barnes. his father, mark barnes, had reported him missing 33 years ago. carter also intends to meet his new kin and hopes to uncover the missing period between his disappearance and arrival at the orphanage in hawaii.

1347	two babies were born with incurable diseases after errors in ivf treatment that should have prevented inherited illnesses. both mothers visited the same clinic in an attempt to avoid passing on severe conditions from their families. several blunders occurred at a laboratory used by the care fertility nottingham clinic, that are being described as "grade a" errors, the most severe type. one mother wanted to screen against sickle cell anaemia, a serious blood disorder that can lead to complications, while the other hoped to prevent neurofibromatosis, a condition causing tumors and reducing life expectancy by 15 years. the misdiagnoses resulted in the babies being born with the illnesses the parents had hoped to prevent. the mix-up has reportedly devastated the families involved, while the human fertilisation & embryology authority, who published their report, called the two incidents "very serious."
