1391	in 2013, a 19-year-old named chris mcgarry was falsely accused of shoplifting by tesco staff in northumberland, uk, while with his mother following a failed card payment transaction. after apologizing, tesco later issued a £5 voucher as compensation.
1392	russian oligarch boris berezovsky, known for his business innovations and influential involvement in politics, has passed away in england. the exact circumstances of his death are unknown but are consistent with hanging. berezovsky was well-known for his unyielding passion for russian interests and his support for the russian people.
1393	this proposal suggests giving financial help to long-term jobless people to move house in order to find work in areas with better job opportunities. those who have been unemployed for over a year would be given cash by their local council to cover moving costs, such as using a removals van or paying a deposit on a new home. the aim is to encourage better job prospects by changing people's residence and increase labor market participation. despite facing opposition, the policy's supporters argue it is necessary to improve employment situation in the uk.
1394	on december 19, 2013, a tv host named josh gates received a pair of hamburger earmuffs as a result of an amazon order mix-up. gates, who hosts destination truth on the syfy network, began amusingly sharing his experiences wearing the unusual item on twitter. the viral campaign created by gates helped turn the earmuffs into a highly sought-after item during the holiday season. unfortunately, the hamburger earmuffs sold out quickly after the publicity increased their demand, and the company couldn't restock due to product manufacturing in china.
1395	a gold coast helicopter pilot safely lowered a heavy water tank onto the river bank, following a close call, despite concerns raised by building manager david gardner to the city of gold coast and the civil aviation safety authority. the pilot, with ten years of experience, safely completed the task after successfully transporting heat pumps and the first two water tanks without issue. all necessary safety precautions were in place during the operation.
1396	real sociedad, a spanish football club, is considering david moyes to become their manager, replacing jagoba arrasate. moyes is currently without a job since leaving manchester united in april last year. they are discussing the idea with four coaches, one of whom is current head coach asier santana, and they plan to get to know each person and weigh their options. the team is currently second from bottom in la liga with six points.
1397	on a busy motorway in kent, at least nine suspected illegal immigrants were detained after climbing out of a foreign lorry. the gang strolled through the english countryside, and although all were arrested, nearly half were released a few minutes later. the individuals were given free accommodation, accommodation, and provided information on how to apply for asylum and benefits.
1398	on september 11th, 2001, australia's city of melbourne evacuated its world trade center building due to the 9/11 terrorist attacks in new york. separated by almost 10,000 miles from new york, australia has a unique geographical isolation and identity, with a long history of having an indigenous population, unique flora and fauna, and often being chosen as a penal colony. the country has dealt with its fair share of terrorism and tragedy, exemplified in the sydney hostage situation of 2014. australian society has rethought its ideas on society and way of life, and the world's growing connection through technology and globalization has led to events like the sydney hostage situation that were once felt more overseas becoming more local and familiar. 
1399	lloyd's of london appoints inga beale as its first-ever female ceo, signaling a historical milestone in the insurance industry. other female financial trailblazers include sri mulyani indrawati, christine lagarde, janet yellen, and ngozi okonjo-iweala, who have made impacts on global finances and the world economy.
1400	the humble cat has replaced the iron in the popular board game monopoly. the manufacturer, hasbro, conducted an online poll to determine which iconic token would be replaced, and the cat won by securing 31% of the votes. the iron was voted out due to featuring in the game since the 1930s and securing only 8% of the votes. the eight tokens in the game originated when the niece of game creator charles darrow suggested using charms from her charm bracelet. monopoly's iconic pieces have been part of the game since its introduction in 1935.
1401	the lawyer for the alleged victims in the julian assange sex crime case has denied any involvement of the pentagon or cia in the accusations. rumors suggesting otherwise have been described as "complete nonsense."
1402	john terry, the longtime chelsea captain, is set to lead the team in his 500th match against crystal palace at selhurst park on saturday. terry, who has been praised for his service to the west london outfit, has captured 13 trophies and has an impressive track record of achievements in his football career. several former chelsea stars have offered their praise for the club's captain and leader.
1403	hannah kritzeck, a 19-year-old teenage girl born with primordial dwarfism, is only 39 inches tall. the extremely rare condition affects about 100 people worldwide, causing short stature and health issues, including the threat of brain aneurysms. although facing typical teenage challenges, hannah also deals with her condition by pursuing her passion for dancing, attending classes, and dreaming about love and a family life. a new film, 'little and looking for love,' follows hannah's journey to graduation from high school, choosing a career and finding love.
1404	in 2012, david cameron, british prime minister, hinted at possibly holding a referendum on britain's relationship with the european union. while not at the time, he suggested that one could be held during the next general election in 2015. however, it required tactical and strategic patience due to uncertainty in europe at that time. in october, the prime minister gave a speech laying out his vision for repatriating powers back to the united kingdom from the eu in areas such as social issues, employment law, and home affairs.
1405	sixty years ago on saturday, laika - a stray dog plucked from the streets of moscow - became the first living creature sent into space when she was launched into orbit by sputnik 2, cementing russia's position as the leader in the space race during the cold war. however, laika's journey ended tragically as the team behind the mission had not made provisions for her safe return, and she died in orbit before any significant data could be gathered about sustaining life in space. though her trip marked the beginning of the canine's historic legacy in space exploration, it serves as a solemn reminder of the importance of ensuring the safety and comfort of animals in space travel.
1406	former first lady laura bush praised president obama's job performance, stating that she thinks he is doing a good job under tough circumstances, particularly in addressing schoolchildren. she also criticized the sharp political divide in washington and washington's educational department plans. bush defended obama's decision to address schoolchildren and promoted awareness of the president's address.
1407	an innocent couple was accused of harming their month-old baby due to their baby milk supply, which caused rickets. it was believed by social workers and a judge that the baby had been the victim of horrific abuse, as he had broken bones. after examining expert evidence in june, a judge ruled that one or the other of the parents must be responsible for the child's injuries. however, a recent revelation has opened the possibility that the boy's injuries may have been caused by an inherited vitamin d deficiency rather than intentional harm. as a result, the parents have the potential to get their son back after the realization of the medical significance of the youngster's records.
1408	thousands of elephants roam chobe national park in botswana, putting humans and elephants in close proximity and leading to human-wildlife conflicts. researchers are now monitoring small-scale wildlife corridors within urban communities as a solution, which could reduce conflict before it happens. elephants without borders, a conservation group, is also advocating for legislation and legal rules to apply to designated wildlife corridors for the protection of both humans and elephants.
1409	rielle hunter, john edwards' mistress, shares information about her affair in her book "what really happened: john edwards, our daughter, and me." she talks about the pain her affair caused john edwards' wife who used video footage of her and john as her computer screensaver to constantly watch his reaction. hunter reveals that she believes she had no regrets for "following her heart" into john's bed. her book also discusses her relationship with their daughter, quinn, and how it affected her life. though criticized for her role in destroying the "myth" of john and elizabeth edwards, rielle claimed the book was part of her "duty" to john's three other children.
1410	south korea, with the world's fastest broadband infrastructure, leads in identifying and treating gaming and internet addiction, spending millions per year. around 8% of the population suffers from addiction, and the american psychiatric association proposes considering "internet use disorder" as a warranting further study. dr. han from chung-ang university hospital treats patients using techniques similar to alcoholics' counseling, virtual-reality therapy, and offers his top five warning signs for internet or gaming addiction.

1413	the uk could launch a military strike against syria without the support of the united nations, as claimed by government legal advice released on august 29, 2013. downing street published the official legal position suggesting britain would not breach international law if it launched ‘military intervention to strike specific targets with the aim of deterring and disrupting’ further use of chemical weapons. the government released an intelligence report, likened to the so-called iraq dossier, which claimed it is ‘highly likely’ that the syrian regime was responsible for a chemical attack in damascus on august 21.
1414	thousands of britons receive sickness benefits due to being too fat to work, at a cost to taxpayers of £54 million. nearly 12,000 people received disability benefits linked to obesity-related illnesses, a significant increase from 5,500 in 2010. the crisis has been fueled by a combination of high cost of obesity-related health problems, the failure of governments to adequately address the issue, and the food and drink industry not doing enough to cut calories in their products. the cost of obesity to the nhs is more than £9 billion a year. 
1415	a national audit office report warns that a government scheme helping first-time buyers with up to £600,000 uk homes may not provide value for money, as the cost to taxpayers is uncertain and likely to be significant. chairman margaret hodge questioned the need to assist buyers of such expensive properties under the scheme. the house of commons public accounts committee expressed concerns about the scheme's effectiveness and whether it genuinely aids people in need. 
1416	a senior consultant ignored concerns about a patient's excruciating pain following a routine knee operation in a private london hospital. david sellu, 66, was accused of providing substandard care to james hughes, 66, who later died from blood poisoning. the hospital is blaming sellu for his negligence.
1417	in 2013, us secretary of state john kerry visited the mekong river delta during an official visit, his first time back since fighting in the vietnam war. he met with young professionals and stressed threats like rising sea levels and the impact of upstream dam development on the mekong river, posing more severe dangers than his past encounter with viet cong guerrillas. kerry pledged $17 million towards a program to help the region's rice producers, shrimp and crab farmers, and fishermen adapt to potential changes caused by higher sea levels, which could bring saltwater intrusion into the delta's ecosystem. he also aimed to ensure that no country exploits the mekong river exclusively at the expense of others.
1418	comedian and satirist john fortune, who had recently suffered a stroke, passed away at the age of 74 after a television career spanning more than 50 years. fortune, alongside comedy partner john bird, rose to fame on the channel 4 show bremner, bird, and fortune, where they lampooned politicians and military top brass. rory bremner, a fellow comedian and colleague, described fortune as a fearless satirist and said he had influenced the satire boom.

1440	hurricane gordon has entered the eastern azores and is expected to pass between santa maria island and san miguel island. forecasters have warned of dangerous surf and rip current conditions in the central and eastern azores due to swells generated by the storm. as of monday morning, the hurricane was moving east-northeast at 20 mph, with maximum sustained winds of 75 mph. it is expected to weaken as it leaves the azores, and will continue moving towards mainland europe.

1467	natasha richardson, a renowned actress and member of the famous redgrave acting family, passed away after suffering injuries in a skiing accident. she was 45 years old. richardson was well-regarded for her performances in films, such as "the handmaid's tale" and "the parent trap," as well as on stage. she married actor liam neeson in 1994 and had two children.
1468	european champions chelsea advanced to the fifa club world cup final with a comfortable 3-1 victory over concacaf champions league winners, monterrey. goals from spanish duo juan mata and fernando torres, as well as an own goal from darvin chavez, secured the win for chelsea's interim coach rafael benitez. the win sets up a final showdown against copa libertadores winners corinthians on sunday. 
1469	isis has reportedly acquired the capability of using a drone for surveillance in its operations, raising concerns about terrorist groups' proliferation of technology. armed drones have traditionally been used by states, but numerous countries, including some nations that possess them, have not yet deployed them in combat. the development underscores the need for an international agreement on the use of drones and addressing concerns about the sale and transfer of sophisticated drone technology to nonstate actors, such as isis.
1470	labour peer lord ahmed has been suspended from the party due to allegations he blamed a jewish conspiracy for his jail sentence for dangerous driving resulting from sending text messages shortly before his car was involved in a fatal crash. lord ahmed became one of the first muslim men in the house of lords in 1998. labour leader ed miliband has reportedly suspended him and has launched an investigation into the allegations.
1471	an indiana woman, shelbi crouch, lost more than half of her scalp during a go-kart accident at whiteland raceway park in indianapolis. since the accident, she has been visiting plastic surgeons to repair her scalp and has undergone several painful surgeries and skin grafts. her hair, which was famous for its long, curly strawberry-blonde locks, was caught in the go-kart's axle causing severe injuries to her scalp and face, and now she is struggling to come to terms with not being able to have her own hair again. although crouch was wearing a helmet and neck brace, the accident still occurred and left her hair and scalp ripped off, resulting in long-term physical and emotional trauma.
1472	in recent bombings, boko haram has targeted schools, markets, and villages. girls as young as 10 have been used as suicide bombers, and many people have been killed. the nigerian government has reported 150 people killed in the attack, but private estimates claim the true number is 2,000. as a result of these attacks, the nigerian government and international communities have taken steps to protect children, improve security, and improve education in their countries. yet, many schools and communities continue to be victims of boko haram terrorism and need international support to become safer.
1473	a former minister warns that high-stakes gambling machines in betting shops can lead to violence and criminal behavior, urging that their use should be limited or stopped. 
1474	ohio is a culturally diverse, politically significant state in the united states that has given rise to numerous celebrities, sports, and political figures, including katie holmes, halle berry, lebron james, and eight presidents. with the battleground state being extremely close in the 2012 us presidential election, ohio consists of 18 electoral votes, higher unemployment than the national average at 7.2%, and a large portion of blue-collar workers. the state boasts various industries and cultural landmarks ranging from rock and roll music to world-famous sports franchises such as the 7-time championship cleveland cavaliers. additionally, ohio was the 17th and the last state to join the union in 1803, and is also known for its predominantly white population, with 4% of the state's population being african american.
1475	a 52-year-old dundee plumber, mark topley, gained fame after a co-worker filmed him dancing to a robert miles song during a job. he admitted feeling embarrassed initially but has now found the situation amusing and believes it helps relieve everyday stress. topley has received numerous calls and texts from people who laughed and appreciated his video.
1476	australia is expected to experience an early and more severe bushfire season as most of the country faces an above-normal risk. dry spell conditions and persistent droughts along the eastern states and the south and central regions of western australia are to blame for the higher risk. with this in mind, australians are advised to prepare for the upcoming season by completing physical and written fire plans.
1477	a 62-year-old man from texas, patrick smith, was charged with bigamy after his second wife used his cellphone to call his first wife in november 2012. smith had allegedly married his second wife janet mills maun while still married to his wife of 34 years, toni marie zimmerman. smith's indictment was handed up by a fort bend grand jury on february 10. if convicted, he could face 10 years in prison.

1480	spencer pratt and heidi montag, better known as spencer & heidi or speidi, revealed they faked their way to the final of celebrity big brother by playing villains to gain attention and entertainment. they claimed it was a job for them, and they were doing their best to stir up drama and provoke emotions. spencer and heidi competed in the show but ultimately missed winning the trophy, coming in second place to eventual winner rylan clark.
1481	two bombs in the iraqi capital killed over 20 people just hours before the city's curfew was set to end. the deadliest attack took place in the new baghdad section of the city, with a suicide bomber targeting a restaurant in a predominantly shi'ite neighbourhood, resulting in at least 12 deaths and 30 injuries. later, two more bombs went off at the busy sharqa market district, killing 10 more. in total, 22 people were killed, and 55 injured. the attack is not believed to be linked to the curfew decision-making process.
1482	recently discovered never-before-seen photos of the who performing at a small concert at cheam bath halls in 1966 emerged after almost 50 years. the candid shots show the band playing their early songs and showcase the raw energy and intimate setting of the event. the who, led by pete townshend, had just started making a name for themselves but had not yet shot to superstardom when these pictures were taken.
1483	in 2013, graham norton, famous bbc chat show host, received £2.61 million from the bbc for presenting the graham norton show and his radio program. this figure included presenter fees, production fees, and royalties. norton, 50, was part of a lucky few top bbc talents, earning between £500,000 and £5 million a year. the bbc has, however, declined to name all of these talents. the corporation has slashed the amount spent on its top stars from £9.7 million to £5.6 million over the past year, but still invested in its most valuable stars. despite norton's divorce, the british broadcasting company seems to value his talent in securing loyal viewership and keeping him within the company.
1484	china's bird flu crisis continues to escalate, reaching a death toll of nine. the first deaths in anhui and jiangsu provinces were reported, while the cases are still limited, with the majority in shanghai. shanghai announced a cull of over 100k live birds in an attempt to contain the problem, and several cities have announced trading suspensions. health organizations and authorities are still trying to reassure the public there is no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission.
1485	manchester city's under 19s maintained their 100% record in the uefa youth league, scoring four goals in the final 20 minutes to secure a 6-0 win in italy. with a total of six victories, the youngsters advanced to the knockout stages of the competition, led by coach patrick vieira. the victory was followed by a 2-0 win in the stadio olimpico, earning manchester city a place in the champions league round of 16.
1486	a ubs bank trader accused of fraud related to a $2.3 billion loss in unauthorized trading said he was "sorry beyond words" in a statement delivered by his lawyer. kwaku adoboli has been remanded in custody until october 20th and faces various charges connected to losses of over $1.5 billion and false accounting. ubs claimed no client positions were impacted, while the loss could potentially cause them a loss in the third quarter of the year.
1487	an unsuspecting sports car owner was in for a shock when he returned to his marcos mantis, which had its yellow bright paintwork wrecked after someone spilled paint on its bonnet and windows. parked under scaffolding on a london street, the car was splattered with white paint, leaving the £150,000 vehicle worth between £25,000 to £35,000 covered in paint and dirt.

1489	nato and russian alliance say that syria's regime is approaching collapse, urging the regime to stop violence and initiate a process that leads to accommodating the legitimate aspirations of the syrian people. rebel victory would bring a host of complicated issues to the shattered country. opposition groups still have support from the world community after president bashar al-assad's forces have used scud missiles against rebels.
1490	prince charles, accompanied by his son prince william and son-in-law prince harry, attended the funeral of his closest friend hugh van custem at brentwood cathedral in essex today. the prince of wales and camilla, duchess of cornwall were among those attending the service honoring conservationist mr. van custem, who died last week, aged 72.
1491	a claim made by the guardian that implicated the news of the world in causing milly dowler's parents false hope that she was alive by hacking into her voicemail and deleting messages was disproven. the incident led to the closure of the news of the world and the launch of the leveson inquiry. the guardian later corrected the story, and no evidence of criminal activity was found between journalist amelia hill and detective constable peter cripps. milly dowler was eventually found dead six months after her initial disappearance, with bouncer levi bellfield serving a life sentence for her murder.
1492	an investigation has been launched after kim fullerton, a performance manager at north west ambulance service (nwas), was photographed apparently asleep on the job during a night shift. mrs. fullerton was supposedly monitoring 999 calls at her computer, but a colleague claimed that she was actually taking a nap. the north west ambulance service office in liverpool was the location where the photo was taken. the photo is currently under investigation, as the performance manager's task is to monitor call activity to ensure all 999 calls are answered and categorized.
1493	researchers found a connection between melting of the greenland ice sheet and high heat flow from earth's mantle, suggesting a new aspect in climate change that could impact predictions. greenland ice melt affects global sea-level rise. additionally, a study led by harvard university's david keith proposes a technological solution for reducing the sunlight reaching earth to reverse global warming and restore the polar ice.
1494	company safe claims their disaster-proof houses protect against bio-chemical attacks, pandemics, and natural disasters. the founder and ceo, al corbi, and his wife, lana, showcased one of these safe houses in washington, d.c. the house features ballistic vaults, facial recognition software, and a helipad for quick escape in case of emergencies. additionally, it has an underground bunker for protection against nuclear or chemical attack, stocked with enough food, water, and medical supplies for survival. safe's security systems often appeal to high-profile clients, such as oprah winfrey, who had their house kitted out for $1,300.
1495	lewis hamilton believes ferrari and red bull will provide tough competition this season, after he was third quickest during the third day of the second test in barcelona. despite illness, he remained optimistic about mercedes' performance, but acknowledged not being able to know where they will lie among their rivals. hamilton won the title last year by 67 points and anticipates a harder fight this season.
1496	a record number of britons are saving into a work pension, with six in ten people now saving into a workplace pension pot, compared to half three years ago. this has led to a rapid increase in the number of people in pensions, bringing the total to 15.7 million. the latest pension figures show a reversal in the long-term decline in people taking out pensions due to an employer-enforced scheme launched in 2012. however, fewer workers are being offered gold-plated final salary pensions, and the annual survey from the office for national statistics showed that workers in the private sector received lower contributions from their employer, leading to lower retirement pensions. despite this, the rise in pension saving is the highest since records began, led by the success of automatic enrolment which is changing the culture of pension saving in britain.
1497	philip thomas burris jr., a 25-year-old oklahoma prison inmate, is suing the state corrections department. burris alleges that his caseworker, kasey mcdonald, aged 38, forced him to have sexual intercourse with her between 50 to 100 times while he was serving his sentence at the joseph harp correctional center in lexington, oklahoma. the case highlights an issue of sexual exploitation within the state prison system and challenges the concept of consensual sex in situations involving power dynamics between inmates and prison staff. the lawsuit also highlights the potential for contraband smuggling and allegations of marijuana supply within the prison environments. these criminal allegations are currently ongoing in court.
1498	bonnie neighbour, 50, has struggled with mental health issues for most of her life. at one point she was diagnosed with bipolar disorder which causes extreme emotional highs and lows. she is one of many women who experience mental health issues and are nearly twice as likely as men to suffer from major depression. the u.s. department of health and human services' office on women's health published a report suggesting that mental health needs to be a priority in women's lives to improve overall well-being. 
1499	a palestinian man in a minivan carried out a terrorist attack in east jerusalem by ramming into commuters at a train platform and then attacking them with an iron bar; this resulted in one person being killed and 13 injured. the militant hamas group took responsibility for the attack, which is the second of its kind in east jerusalem in the past two weeks. tensions between arabs and jews in the city have already been heightened, and on wednesday, israeli police dispersed palestinian youth who threw rocks and firecrackers near a contested holy site in jerusalem's old city, followed by a subsequent car attack.
1500	oscar pistorius, an olympic sprinter, is on trial in south africa for the murder of reeva steenkamp. prosecutor gerrie nel argues that pistorius intentionally killed steenkamp during a burglary, but defense lawyer barry roux claims that pistorius mistook steenkamp for a burglar and acted in self-defense. testimony will focus on pistorius' actions on the night of the incident and the possible sequence of events resulting in the shooting. the trial will determine if murder was committed, or if the defense's argument of culpable homicide or not guilty should be considered.
1501	scientists have made a breakthrough in cancer research, discovering a molecule called tic10 that activates a protein called trail, which helps destroy cancer cells. the protein is a part of the immune system and is less toxic than chemotherapy or radiotherapy. tic10 can cross the blood-brain barrier, preventing drugs from entering the brain and treating brain tumors. animal studies have shown that this molecule is safe and effective, and early clinical trials are underway.
1502	a shopper faced difficulty trying on clothing from m&s's limited edition range. although they found that some items fit in a size larger than what they normally wear, others didn't fit well, leading to confusion with changing sizes in different ranges.
1503	bill clinton, the former president of the united states, is often involved in political issues and was instrumental in hillary clinton's 2008 presidential campaign. recently, karl rove, a republican strategist, questioned hillary clinton's health, leading bill clinton to respond on her behalf. he supports his wife's political career, endorsing her in past elections and campaigning for her. the role of the former president in hillary clinton's potential future presidential campaign remains unclear.
1504	to ensure the safety of american airport travels, the transportation security administration (tsa) has increased security checks, especially after al-qaeda published instructions on making an undetectable bomb to attack passenger jets. although no specific, credible threat has been reported, the latest edition of al-qaeda's online magazine "inspire" outlines the process to make a potentially explosive device from household materials, which has led to increased vigilance by law enforcement and homeland security. the bombing instructions in the magazine is connected to previous bombings and has been suspected as a template for the 2013 boston marathon bombing.
1505	ash from a volcano in chile thinned over australia, allowing commercial airliners to resume flights. qantas and virgin australia airlines have resumed domestic flights from sydney, melbourne, canberra, adelaide, and albury to several locations. they made this decision based on information from australia's volcanic ash advisory centre (vaac), explaining how the jet stream has carried the volcanic ash particles a great distance to the east. australia's june 4 eruption of puyehue-cordon caulle volcano in chile has also caused flight cancellations before, as it is prone to frequent volcanic eruptions and located on the 'ring of fire'.
1506	a controversial scheme to pay gps £55 for every new case of dementia they diagnose is leading to patients being wrongly told they may have the illness, according to researchers. since the incentive was introduced, uk gps have seen a seven-fold increase in patients diagnosed with dementia. however, the research claims that around half of those referred to memory clinics for scans since october have been later found not to have dementia. nhs england argue that the scheme will cease at the end of march.
1507	three canadian prisoners escaped from their detention center by helicopter earlier this month. they were later caught and returned to the same facility. the men were arrested as part of a 2010 drug bust called operation crayfish and were awaiting trial on charges including murder and gangsterism. their escape triggered an international manhunt, and they were added to an interpol red notice list. two weeks after their escape, the trio was recaptured in montreal and is scheduled to appear in court. both the government and police are conducting investigations related to the prison escape incidents.
1508	iran's president ahmadinejad defends his government's relationship with the country's supreme leader, denying any political rift. ahmadinejad disputes the claims of a rift and insists that the relationship between his government and ayatollah ali khamenei is based on love and faith, like the relationship between a parent and a child. there have been discussions of a rift between high-ranking iranian officials after controversial presidential elections. despite recent criticism, ahmadinejad's appointment of controversial politician esfandyar rahim mashaie, who also faced criticism for attending a ceremony without iranian women dancing, could still be officially approved and inaugurated.
1509	the sri lankan team's bus was attacked by gunmen in lahore, pakistan, leaving six security personnel dead, and eight members of the cricket team injured, including two with gunshot wounds. the attack occurred when the players were traveling to the city's gaddafi stadium for the third day of the second test match against pakistan. a well-planned attack, the incident has raised concern for the safety of visiting cricket teams in pakistan, with future matches potentially being played outside the country.
1510	incumbent nigerian president goodluck jonathan appears likely to win the election, with initial counting showing he has more than 19 million votes, compared to his main competitor muhmmadu buhari, who has close to 9 million. a runoff is possible if jonathan does not get at least a quarter of the vote in two-thirds of the 36 states and the capital, though this election has been largely peaceful compared to the violence and fraud experienced during the parliamentary elections last week.
1511	more than 1,000 protesters in kuwait clashed with security forces on friday, demanding improved rights for non-citizen residents. the crowd grew after it started, leading to the use of water cannons. the kuwaiti government spokesperson claimed that the security forces were trying to protect themselves, while the protesters were told to pursue legal channels. the demonstration was eventually dispersed, and several protesters were arrested and questioned by security forces. kuwait has been dealing with rights for non-citizen residents for decades, with an estimated 100,000 such residents in the country.
1512	a new injection called aqualyx, claims to dissolve fat cells and help eliminate them through urine. sharon donaldson, from liverpool, was one of the first women to try this alternative to liposuction. aqualyx is made up of plant-based polymers that bind to fat cells. the fat then dissolves, resulting in fat cells being eliminated from the body over a three-week period. this procedure costs £1,000, with three injections spaced a month apart. people should carefully research and consult a doctor before getting such injections, as experts have warned about increased cholesterol and blood sugar levels, and the risk of becoming diabetic if these claims are true.
1513	on january 8, 2011, a mentally ill man shot former arizona congresswoman gabby giffords in the head, along with six others, outside a tucson supermarket. giffords, now married to astronaut mark kelly, and their family have recently become an influential voice in the advocacy of gun control and background checks amid the ongoing debate. they discuss their efforts at moving forward, with giffords managing the challenges following her recovery.
