1515	in 2012, oli beale, a londoner living in a communal flat, was unable to sleep due to a loud party featuring bad karaoke at his neighbour's apartment. instead of cursing his sleep loss, he decided to create a detailed review of the 'terrible' performance, covering the timings and titles of songs, and rating the songs out of 10. beale posted his complaint onto a board in his building's communal area and then tweeted a picture of the review. his final words were, "i hate you."
1516	a senior police officer was jailed for two and a half years for a string of frauds, after deceiving high street stores in refunds schemes. officer tanya brookes, 46, targeted stores including the white company, micro scooters, and boots, netting over £11,000 by claiming full refunds for discounted luxury items. among the items purchased were breast pumps, fertility tests, and cashmere blankets. judge andrew barnett condemned her for bringing "shame" on the police service and tarnishing the reputation of the police force.
1517	a crime-scene officer has been accused of substandard work in potentially undermining 90 criminal cases, including one involving a death. the independent police complaints commission (ipcc) is conducting an investigation into the quality of work and qualifications of the 48-year-old crime-scene officer, who worked for staffordshire police and cleveland police between 1996 and 2011.
1518	rutgers university athletic director tim pernetti resigned after handing in a letter of resignation, arguing that he initially wanted to fire the basketball coach last year after a video revealed that the coach was hitting and screaming at his players. pernetti claims that university officials convinced him not to fire the coach. school interim vice president was also fired as they were involved in the decision to "rehabilitate" instead of fire coach mike rice, whose abusive behavior was captured on video. rutgers university president robert barchi's job seemed safe after getting a public nod of support from the school's board of governors.
1519	footballer phil neville, who is known as "britain's most hopeless husband", has never performed household chores before. after his wife revealed this, neville started to learn how to do household tasks like cleaning, cooking, and using household appliances. however, his wife said that he still doesn't know where the rubbish goes or how to mow the lawn.
1520	india urges sri lanka's tamil rebels to release an estimated 70,000 civilians trapped in the country's war zone. the external affairs minister of india, pranab mukherjee, expressed india's readiness to assist in evacuating the civilians. mukherjee emphasized that as the conflict nears its end, the tamil tigers would better serve the interests of the tamils by releasing all civilians and laying down their arms. thousands have been displaced as government forces advance and tamil rebels retreat, and cnn's harmeet shah singh contributed to this report.
1521	footballers are advised not to sign for clubs in serbia due to the risk of not being paid, as 8 out of 16 superliga teams have their bank accounts blocked and cannot pay their employees. the situation is severe, with multiple clubs facing bankruptcy and leaving players struggling to purchase basic necessities. the world players' union and the serbian players' union have both warned against signing deals in serbia, as the players are facing serious financial problems and threats from fans.
1522	nine professional skydivers who experienced a plane collision 12,000 feet in the air in a thrilling situation have said they have not been discouraged by the incident. the experienced team from wisconsin, who appeared on the today show, said that they simply feel the incident is part of the experience and that it will not deter them from skydiving again.
1523	dr. richard curtis, britain's first transsexual doctor, is being investigated by the general medical council for his handling of sex-change procedures for his patients. the initial complaint came from a woman who underwent breast reconstruction surgery and hormone treatment but later regretted the decision. the doctor, who charges up to £240 an hour, is accused of not adhering to prescribing rules and providing care without second opinions. the situation raised concerns about the potential harm caused by his clinical practice.
1524	the prime minister plans to re-introduce an eu membership referendum bill to parliament later this year. following labour and liberal democrat opposition to his previous attempts, he has stated he will use the parliament act process to force the bill through. cameron is still pushing for a referendum to take place by 2017.
1525	the convictions of three ex-pakistani cricketers, salman butt, mohammad aamer, and mohammad asif, for spot-fixing in 2011 are being reviewed by the crown prosecution service (cps) due to doubts over the credibility of 'fake sheik' journalist mazher mahmood. their convictions were based on evidence from mahmood's sting operation in the news of the world. all three were handed five-year bans by the international cricket council for their involvement in bowling no-balls during a test match, which led to concerns over mahmood's reputation. as a result, their case is one of 25 currently under review by the cps.
1526	a snowmobiler from arizona got lost in a snowy canyon in remote northern utah. after getting stranded, he built a snow cave using debris from his snowmobile to protect himself from freezing temperatures. lawrence orduño survived by consuming crushed, frozen bottles of gatorade and wood pieces that he gathered. after being separated from his friend, search and rescue teams found orduño and rescued him from the canyon. local authorities expressed gratitude towards search crews for their efforts to reunite orduño with his family.
1527	a teen, skylar murphy, brought a pipe bomb to edmonton international airport but was allowed to board his flight. airport inspectors initially tried to return the bomb to him, and it took four days to alert the royal canadian mounted police about the incident. skylar received one year of probation and a fine for possessing an explosive substance, but the incident was met with outrage due to lax security procedures.
1528	flight simulators have come a long way since their inception at the turn of the last century, with the kc-97 flight simulator providing pilots with essential training for difficult aircraft like the kc-97 stratotanker throughout the 1950s. this simulator weighed 9 tons, cost £520,000 ($853,000), and was operated by three maintainers. it was equipped with a maze of dials, instruments, switches, and other gears that surrounded the pilot, co-pilot, and flight engineer. similar simulators like the kc-97, were vital in preparing pilots for fuel transfers between aircraft, and pre-flight checks. they played a significant role in the refuelling era, helping crews prepare for emergency situations and optimizing fuel management.
1529	the 87th academy awards focused on activism and controversial topics, covering issues such as immigration, suicide, alzheimer's disease, and wage inequality. sean penn's joke about immigrant director alejandro gonzález iñárritu's green card rubbed many the wrong way; although, in private conversations, gonzález iñárritu found the joke hilarious. other powerful moments included equal pay for women advocate patricia arquette, graffiti artist jr's powerful message projected onto the facade of the dolby theatre, and j.k. simmons, winner of the best supporting actor award for whiplash, encouraging viewers to call their mom.
1530	many men, including actors and former porn stars like tom 'billy' o'connor, are turning to plastic surgery to enhance their male genitalia, with some opting for penis extensions and girth or length enhancements. demand has risen by a reported 40% in the last year alone. plastic surgeons claim the increase is due to a rise in sexual images on tv, magazines and internet platforms as well as a need for confidence and self-esteem from men seeking to compete with images of muscular, well-endowed men circulating mainstream media.
1531	apple removed 500px, a popular photo-sharing app, from its store after discovering some users were able to access nude photos via its api. the app's co-founder, evgeny tchebotarev, claims the app has restricted access to nude content and that apple was unclear about some user complaints. apple has asked the developer to put safeguards in place to prevent inappropriate content.
1532	a 3-month-old baby is rescued from heavy flooding in the balkans that has claimed the lives of at least 40 people. members of the slovenian military used a helicopter to winch the infant to safety as floodwaters ravaged the northern bosnian town of šamac. the region has been struck by the heaviest rainfall since records began, leading to the deaths of at least 40 people in three countries – with more than one million people affected by floods and landslides in bosnia and herzegovina alone.
1533	a virus referred to as 'the plague' has spread rapidly within a texas high school, infecting over 700 students and staff members with symptoms including vomiting, diarrhea, fatigue, and weakness. school officials are attempting to find the source of the illness, which might not be food-related. cleaning personnel have been hired to sanitize the entire premises to prevent spreading the virus. although no source has been found, health experts recommend strict hygiene practices, such as diligent hand washing, to prevent further spread. 
1534	relations between president barack obama and the republican party on capitol hill have worsened considerably. obama has made it clear he refuses to negotiate with house speaker john boehner, who recently suggested he would no longer deal with the president on legislative deals. the two sides are clashing over the federal government spending, the national debt, and future economic policies. a large part of their disagreement stems from obama's push for deficit reduction through spending cuts alone. with the 2014 congressional elections approaching, republicans are struggling to define themselves, define their message and define their role vis-a-vis obama in his second term.
1535	four groups advocating for immigrant rights will challenge arizona's new immigration law, allowing police to ask anyone for proof of legal u.s. residency, claiming it is unconstitutional and discriminatory. the legal challenge questions whether the law will increase racial profiling of latinos and infringe on the basic right of due process.
1536	a mother who was brutally attacked by her ex-fiance is being forced to write to him in prison, even facing imprisonment herself, as he seeks updates on their twin sons under parental rights laws. natalie allman was tortured for seven hours and left with her throat cut by ex-fiance jason hughes because he wanted her to look 'ugly' following their break-up. court orders now require allman to send letters and photos of the young children to her attacker three times a year or face contempt of court charges.
1537	tennis legend and openly gay athlete billie jean king has been named part of the presidential delegation to the closing ceremony of the winter olympics in sochi, russia. king was initially part of the opening ceremony delegation but had to withdraw due to her mother's illness. russia has faced criticism for its position on gay rights since 2013, when the country passed an anti-gay propaganda law. king aims to draw attention to discrimination against the lgbt community and promote human rights and equality.
1538	prime minister david cameron was photographed leaving a performance of the controversial and popular musical "book of mormon" at the prince of wales theatre in london. the show, written by south park creators trey parker and matt stone, along with robert lopez, is a religious satire on mormonism, containing edgy themes and songs. its successful run in the united states earned numerous awards, including tony awards and a grammy. despite the show's success and critical acclaim, the lds church has released an official response, stating that while the musical may entertain audiences temporarily, it cannot change people's lives like the original book of mormon scripture.
1539	michael pollara, a florida man, collected over $1 million in stolen merchandise before serving two years in jail and now remains free to share the secrets of his trade. pollara's mother also served as an accomplice on numerous trips, sometimes stealing expensive items from toy and electronics stores. after being caught in 2012, pollara served his sentence and was given the nickname "toys r us" in jail.
1540	a 22-year-old food factory worker, tomas suchy, died when a collapsing stack of frozen fish pallets fell on him while he and his colleagues were trying to rebuild it at a temperature of -25c. suchy and three fellow workers had restarted the stacking process, with mr suchy receiving fatal head injuries from the incident, leading to an inquest ruling an accidental death. the health and safety executive found that there was "no robust monitoring" of the factory's working conditions, and the company was issued with multiple notices following the incident.
1541	amazon has increased its minimum order for free shipping to $35, up by $10, being its first price hike in 10 years. non-prime members previously received free five-day shipping with a minimum order of $25. this change is believed to encourage non-prime members to sign up for amazon prime, a $79-per-year service offering unlimited free two-day shipping and streaming of over 40,000 movies and tv shows. analysts think amazon is aiming to boost profits by raising prices on services.
1542	lionel messi, the tiger, transforms into a footballer for adidas' latest marketing campaign. the global sportswear brand's ad features the argentinian star playing with kids and showcasing their new golden adizero f50 boots in a series of stunning images filmed in barcelona. messi, who missed out on winning the football world cup following argentina's final defeat, will return to barcelona's la masia training base on tuesday to begin pre-season training following a break.
1543	on christmas day, 10.2 million viewers watched the five-minute regeneration sequence of doctor who featuring matt smith, making it the most-watched television moment for the day on bbc one. however, doctor who only garnered an average of 8.3 million viewers for its entire broadcast. the most-watched christmas day show with an average of 9.4 million viewers was mrs. brown's boys christmas special, beating out rival bbc soap opera eastenders for the first time in more than 10 years. eastenders lost its traditional top slot topping the christmas day viewing, and the audience for the bbc newscast fell out of the top ten this year, replaced by itv news.
1544	kobani, a city in syria, has endured conflict for years. its destroyed buildings, scare food supply, and continuous airstrikes make it difficult for daily life. the fight becomes more about who will win rather than any possessions left behind. local kurdish fighters, women included, struggle to defend the city against isis. injuries, deaths, and lack of proper weaponry complicate the situation, and the end result is uncertain.
1545	deval patrick, outgoing democratic governor of massachusetts, blames president barack obama's failure to clearly communicate the democrats' achievements ahead of the 2014 midterm elections for their loss. patrick urges the president to improve his storytelling and stresses the importance of democratic candidates standing up for their beliefs. despite the loss of his party in massachusetts, patrick refrains from taking responsibility and highlights the importance of candidates rather than those on the sidelines. referring to hillary clinton as a potentially strong candidate, he expresses his dissatisfaction with the narrative of inevitability surrounding her. patrick ruled out a 2016 run for president and emphasized the need for candidates who show their passion for the job.
1546	after a hip replacement surgery, zsa zsa gabor's recovery remains uncertain; her husband prince frederic von anhalt describes it as "critical," while her daughter francesca hilton says it is "guarded." the actress sustained the injury nine days prior after answering a phone while watching "jeopardy." gabor has been frail since a 2002 car accident and is often confined to a wheelchair. the hungarian-born actress is best known for her marriages and notable film roles.
1547	olympic swimmer rebecca adlington, at 5ft 10in, decorated her room with team gb paper-chains to make it feel more like home in the olympic village, where her bed is just 5ft 8in long.
1548	manchester united issued an apology after using a swastika-style logo in a newsletter to fans, causing widespread outrage due to its nazi connotations. the logo appeared alongside images of the team's young players, prompting an investigation into how it was cleared for publication. the club stated that they were "taken aback" by the incident and apologized fully.
1549	children of promise is a new york-based organization aiming to help children cope with having a parent in prison. it works with approximately 200 kids between the ages of 6 and 16 who have at least one parent in prison. the group focuses on programs that preserve the parent-child relationship, as well as provide resources and support for children who have been affected by incarceration.
1550	the ayr gold cup race features the favorite watchable, who is the first-choice of bookmakers like william hill, and is being trained by david o'meara. the gelding, a brother to the 2008 1,000 guineas fourth infallible, is running six days after winning a valuable sprint at the curragh. the high stands' side stalls were most popular at the draw, with watchable assigned stall five while its side competitor orient class was drawn in stall 18. the statistics over the past 20 years show a near even distribution of winners, and even with the low draw position, watchable is still the 8-1 betting favorite.
1551	a saudi cleric and ex-head of mecca's religious police, sheikh ahmed al-ghamdi, received death threats after his wife appeared with him on tv without a veil, while wearing makeup. the sheikh and his wife argued that islam does not require women to wear veils in public; this led to controversy amongst saudis who believe it breaks customary religious practices.
1552	germany defeated their arch-rivals the netherlands 3-0, marking their impressive credentials for the upcoming euro 2012 tournament. miroslav klose set up the first goal, scoring the second and reaching a new personal milestone. meanwhile, spain saved a 2-2 draw against costa rica just three days after a 1-0 defeat to england. england also won against sweden 1-0, while uruguay beat italy 1-0.
1553	astronauts on a spacewalk attempted to replace a video camera and update cable connections on the international space station, but two objects floated away during the activity. the first object was identified as a clamp used to attach cables while the second object appeared to be a small round washer. both objects were not considered a threat to the station.
1554	former archbishop of canterbury, lord george carey, has stated that the church of england is "one generation away from extinction," due to its failure to invest in younger generations. the church faces challenges from issues like the decline of christian beliefs in the uk, judicial rejections of christian beliefs, and government threats against the autonomy of the church of england. as fewer people are attending church services and younger generations are not being brought into the faith, the church urgently needs a new strategy for attracting them.
1555	london's technology sector is growing faster than silicon valley, with the industry expected to contribute $12 billion to the uk economy over the next decade. london is the center of digital innovation, employing more people in financial technology than new york and san francisco. the technology industry is also growing at a faster rate in london, the south east, and east england than in silicon valley, with many new inventions emerging from tech city uk.
1556	in july 2012, exxonmobil ceo rex tillerson claimed that although fossil fuels might be causing global warming, environmentalists, journalists, and the public overemphasize the risks. tillerson asserted that adapting to climate change would be possible for humanity and that the oil industry could provide enough energy to the public without incurring major risks. however, scientists and environmentalists criticized his statements as overly optimistic. they argued that severe weather events were happening as a result of climate change, and the industry must take necessary precautions to address environmental problems.
1557	google announced the closure of its 'reader' service, which allows users to see updates from their favorite websites, stating that it has seen a decline in usage and they are focusing on fewer products. however, the service's closure has led to thousands of irate internet users, with alternatives like feedly, rssowl, and newsblur seeing a significant increase in interest since google's announcement. google has offered users the option to export their data during the next four months to take out of various google products and transfer them to other platforms or services. this is not google's first product shutdown, as in 2011, it started streamlining its product base by pulling the plug on around 70 features or services.
1558	rock singer and reality tv star bret michaels suffered a brain hemorrhage, but his 'sheer will to live' kept him alive for doctors to stabilize his condition. michaels is currently in critical condition at a phoenix hospital, but his sister reported that he was able to talk and would recover.
1559	in the past year, more than 35 million women have gone through the discomfort of a mammogram. it is an important cancer screening and should be repeated annually for women aged 40 and older, although women with a family history of breast cancer might be advised to start earlier. the process involves the patient undressing from the waist up and then standing in an x-ray machine while the radiologist carefully examines and compresses each breast. the procedure is important in detecting breast cancer and should be carried out at a certified mammography facility.
1560	a new study finds that women aged 25 to 34 are the most stressed in britain, as they balance their careers, home lives, and raising children. this strain affects many british people, with 67% experiencing stress weekly, and over the past year, this group experiences 208 times of stress. managing bills and finances and dealing with various responsibilities are significant contributors to stress, but women face extra pressures like household chores and relationships. causes of stress are similar for both genders, but solutions differ between men and women. relieving stress can improve sleep quality, regulate food intake, engage in hobbies, and maintain a good night's sleep routine.
1561	a young health worker named cara reynolds died at 24 after mistakenly consuming an overdose of slimming pills containing caffeine, contributing to her death. cara bought the forza raspberry ketones 'natural' supplements from amazon to help her lose weight, and tragically, her condition worsened when she took several pills simultaneously. this led to a fatal overdose on caffeine, ultimately causing her heart to stop responding. the incident highlights the dangers of unregulated, over-the-counter supplements that may seem safe but can lead to tragic consequences.
1562	hull kr has released prop forward jonny walker from his contract with immediate effect. the 23-year-old, who was dropped by the team last month for disciplinary reasons, was released earlier today to pursue regular first team football elsewhere.
1563	duan shuyo, a 59-year-old grandfather, sacrificed his life to save his 15-month-old grandson, lu, from falling down a 30ft well during their nighttime walk. with his final breath, duan grabbed lu, pulled him to safety by his shoulders, and clung to him like a "death grip." rescuers struggled to find the pair the following day, and lu was found still clinging to his grandfather's body. lu suffered minor cuts and bruises, and doctors think duan likely died of a heart attack, caused by a muscle spasm and rigor mortis. despite the tragic outcome, duan's heroic act saved the young boy's life.
1564	at michael jackson's memorial service in los angeles, his 11-year-old daughter, paris, delivered an emotional tribute. paris was consoled by her uncle after taking the stage to honor her father. the speech surprised attendees, who marveled at paris' bravery and love for her late father. the event, which showcased performances from famous artists, was a celebration of jackson's life and legacy, emphasizing his strong bond with his children.
1565	mobile news apps have the potential to save local news about communities, as news media outlets have been losing ground with smaller size formats and digital advancements. mobile devices are set to become the most common way people access the internet in the coming years; however, while mobile news apps may save traditional print newspapers and broadcast news operations, it remains to be seen whether they could save the ad-supported news business. localytics' data suggests people spend around the same amount of time with news apps as they do with twitter's app, showing interest in the medium for advertisers.
1566	a brazilian supreme court ruling by chief justice gilmar mendes allows a 9-year-old boy to be reunited with his father, david goldman, who has been fighting an international custody battle with the boy's deceased mother's family since 2004. the son, sean goldman, arrived in rio de janeiro and was expected to remain with his brazilian relatives until a final decision was made. however, a ruling by chief justice mendes lifted a stay, allowing goldman to be reunited with his son. sean's grandmother plans to appeal the decision, but supporters say the ruling prioritizes sean's well-being and maintains the interest of the child over political pressure.
1567	top government officials, such as david cameron's strategy chief and chancellor george osborne, have shown support for a £40 billion airport plan in the thames estuary as an alternative to heathrow. the scheme would include a high-speed railway connecting the uk and europe and is backed by plans for a £50 billion airport on the isle of grain. the thames estuary airport has faced concerns from some government leaders, with the department for transport commissioning a report that will aid in shaping the future of aviation in 2013.
1568	the documentary 'the trials of muhammad ali' sheds light on the tumultuous history of its subject during the 1960s, when ali was reviled and faced controversy over his stances on the civil rights movement, the vietnam war, and joining the nation of islam. now admired for his unparalleled success in boxing and activism, ali's journey represents a significant social change within the country.
1569	a team of palaeontologists in myanmar has found the tooth of a pre-human ancestor afrasia djijidae, which is very similar to another early ancestor found in libya. this 37-million-year-old tooth reveals that early human ancestors lived in asia before moving to africa fairly late in their evolution, helping to solidify asia as the starting point for our species. the discovery of afrasia sheds light on the migration between asia and africa and can improve our understanding of these early anthropoid ancestors, as well as our shared human history.
1570	dr. anthony garcia, a 40-year-old doctor, was arrested by the illinois state police during a traffic stop in union county, on suspicion of carrying out two brutal attacks over the past five years in omaha. garcia was previously fired from the creighton university medical school due to erratic behavior. he is currently being held on four counts of first-degree murder and four counts of using a weapon to commit a felony, though further details of the case are not available. the attacks involved the murders of four individuals, including two pathologists. investigators believe that garcia acted alone and are searching for evidence in locations where he has lived since 2001.
1571	tracey connelly, the mother of tortured baby peter, could be released from prison on parole "within weeks", depending on the outcome of the board's review of her case. connelly was jailed in 2009 for her role in the death of her 17-month-old son, after serving a minimum of five years. her release was met with horror from baby peter's grandmother and criticism of the social services missed the indicators of abuse.
1572	the international olympic committee has suspended india's olympic association over its plan to hold an election with only one official, who has been accused of corruption, as an election candidate. as a result, indian athletes will not be able to participate in games, and the ioa will lose its funding. the suspension is due to the ioa's failure to comply with the olympic charter, as well as government interference suspected in the election process. shooter abhinav bindra and sports lawyer rahul mehra have both supported reforms in governance within the ioa to address the issue.
1573	a scrap yard worker, lee roberts, was turned into a human fireball while draining fuel from underneath a van. cctv footage captures the dramatic event where the electric spark from a drill caused the fuel to ignite, setting fire to his overalls. he received 22% burns to his hands, legs, and nose. his former employers, jason miller and stephen strange, have been ordered to pay £40,000 for health and safety failings and £25,000 in costs. the incident served as a reminder of the dangers of not properly ventilating fuel-filled areas and the importance of considering the risks employees face while working.
1574	rock star joan jett was removed from south dakota's float in the macy's thanksgiving day parade due to complaints from ranchers, who opposed her appearance as a vegetarian and critic of their livestock production. jett is a supporter of peta, the world's largest animal rights group, promoting a vegetarian diet and addressing concerns about factory farms and ranches. she will now perform on another float instead.
1575	in mississippi, a large footprint, believed not to be human or bear, was found in the woods. a cast made by peyton lassiter, who found the footprint, revealed it to be around nine inches long and almost six inches wide at the toes. this led lassiter to reach out to paranormal investigator david childers who had seen a large grey figure nearby a year prior, supporting lassiter's discovery. both are working together to investigate the area further, as there has been a recorded sighting of a human-like creature dating back to 1721 in the area.
1576	a metro-north train, which killed four people and injured dozens of others, had safety mechanisms that would have warned the engineer of possible issues. these safety mechanisms include the "dead man pedal" that requires continuous foot pressure and a "alerter" system that sounds an alarm if the engineer falls asleep or loses consciousness. however, it is unclear if these mechanisms were in use when the train crashed. two passengers have filed a notice of claim against the commuter railroad seeking damages. 
1577	venezuelan president hugo chavez is set to begin radiation treatment in cuba on sunday after undergoing cancer surgery in late february. chavez flew to havana late saturday night, and his treatment is expected to last approximately a month. chavez has not disclosed the specific type of cancer he is battling, and the government has released limited information on his health and political future. the president has led the nation of venezuela since 1999 and pledged to run for re-election in october.
1578	uk energy secretary ed davey pledged £720 million to a new un fund to combat climate change, emphasising the moral duty of helping the third world. other major economies, such as the us, japan, germany, and france, have also made substantial contributions. critics of the government's spending on foreign aid were dismissed by the liberal democrat climate change secretary as "little englanders." green climate fund assists low-carbon energy projects and helps poor countries adapt to low-carbon energy, such as wind.
1579	a widower cannot come to terms with the murder of his beloved wife and step-daughter by his turkish son-in-law, ensar gol, who repeatedly stabbed them to death, resulting in dozens of stab wounds to their necks and bodies. the women met gol during a holiday romance, and their marriage faced opposition, but michala wished for a father figure to be present. gol eventually became controlling, abusive, and cheated on michala. he returned to turkey, but michala contacted him and persuaded him to return home; he brutally attacked them after arriving back at the family home. michala was stabbed over 30 times and her mom, julie sahin, over 50 times when she tried to protect her. gol smilingly faced court, claimed self-defense, and was found guilty of the murders by a jury.
1580	emily sukiennik, a tightrope expert, and her fiancé mark solper, a base jumper and skydive instructor, decided to organize a unique photoshoot where they balanced 450ft in the air over a canyon. they performed this stunt multiple times, including sunrise and sunset, to capture breathtaking, adrenaline-fueled photographs which combine their two special skills. the couple thought the photos would be spectacular, and they tried to make eye contact while mark was hurdling past emily on the wire.
1581	chinese rock star cui jian has declined an invitation to perform during china's largest annual tv event, spring festival gala, in his first public statement regarding the tiananmen square student protests in 1989, where his music was adopted by protestors.
1582	netflix has launched a website called 'living with spoilers' that allows users to watch spoilers of tv shows and movies. the site features short video clips that reveal major plot points, with users voting on which spoilers they think should be available in the public domain. netflix predicts that spoilers will further personalise services like theirs within the next decade, with dedicated channels for each viewer and no more adverts.
1583	scientists are conducting the first autopsy on a 9,000-year-old bison found in russia, hoping to reveal vital information about extinct bison species. the body was preserved in ice and revealed after a shore collapsed. the autopsy aims to identify potential parasites that might have caused the extinction of bison species. researchers hope to publish their findings next year.
1584	prime minister julia gillard's partner, tim mathieson, made an insensitive joke about prostate cancer screenings, which led to media backlash. the joke was intended to raise awareness about the issue but was deemed in poor taste and offensive to some. gillard admitted the joke was inappropriate, but also commended mathieson's commitment to promoting men's health. the incident sparked discussion on social media about the joke and its impact on raising awareness about prostate cancer.
1585	a group of neighbors in exeter, england, broke into a german nurse's home, trashed it, and scrawled nazi slurs on the walls. the defendants, paul crowther (53), jamie hooper (23), and sarah ellis (24), were arrested, and all three were sentenced to one year in jail for burglary with intent to commit criminal damage. the judge ruled that the offense was racially aggravated because the defendants knew the victim was away and targeted his property based on hostility towards his race. the three defendants' lawyers argued that their clients were not racist, but the judge rejected that claim.
1586	a couple, with two young children, have both been diagnosed with life-threatening illnesses. paul, a deputy headteacher, has been told he has between three and five years to live with motor neurone disease (mnd), while his wife, clare, a police sergeant, has been given just a 30% chance of surviving an aggressive form of oesophageal cancer. the couple is currently making guardianship arrangements for their children.
1587	in khartoum, sudan, unrest grows over high gas prices, leading to increased civic unrest, government efforts to regain control, and spreading to other cities. students have been a major part of the protests, facing tear gas and possibly fatal gunshots from authorities. the root of this unrest lies in the sudanese government's decision to eliminate gas subsidies and the effect it has had on prices for other goods.
1588	here comes honey boo boo follows the daily lives of the entertaining redneck family from mcintyre, georgia, who gained fame on the reality tv series toddlers & tiaras. the show follows the family's daily antics, mainly focusing on honey boo boo's mother, june, and her addiction to couponing. alana, better known as honey boo boo, her mother, june, and her sister pumpkin can be seen redeeming groceries using coupons and engaging in wildly entertaining activities.
1589	eric moussambani, a 22-year-old swimmer from equatorial guinea, faced many difficulties including not having formal training, difficulty in adjusting to the large olympic-sized swimming pool in australia, and being the only one to compete in his heat. despite all of these challenges, moussambani displayed determination and perseverance by completing a significant part of the 100-meter freestyle swimming competition. his performance during the 2000 sydney olympics became famous after being aired on television and became an example of the olympic spirit.
1590	ally mccoist faces the end of his time as rangers manager, as his team is defeated by queen of the south at a crucial game in the championship race. with queen of the south finally breaking the deadlock with a well-placed free-kick and a couple of goals coming from key moments, ally looks set to fall short of his goal for his team to make the title push. as the team struggles to recapture the form seen in the past, mccoist remains at the helm, but it is uncertain whether he'll be able to pull off a comeback in the game and the season.
1591	a georgia woman named amy seiber lost her job at a wendy's fast food joint when a customer found a half-smoked marijuana cigarette inside her cheeseburger. seiber was ordered to police after smoking half of the joint while at work. the customer, shalon travis, suffered similar symptoms to food poisoning due to the discovery, leading her to seek medical assistance. seiber was arrested for possession and later fired by wendy's after the incident.
1592	west ham has revived their £3.5 million deal for striker diafra sakho after getting complaints from his club metz. metz threatened to take an official complaint to uefa due to west ham pulling out of the transfer, even after the player had a medical. west ham wanted a permanent deal initially but shifted it to a loan, leading to metz's frustration. meanwhile, west bromwich albion is expected to bid £7.25 million for west ham winger matt jarvis.
1593	head of a catholic girls boarding school, woldingham, warns parents that schoolgirls who wish for a 'healthy diet' may indicate an early sign of an eating disorder. due to social pressure, young girls feel compelled to look a certain way and may reduce food intake, leading to potential eating disorders resulting from stress and heavy workloads, particularly in female pupils aged 14-18. hormone oestrogen is found to contribute towards psychiatric disorders in adolescence.
1594	after a two-year-old syrian boy, bushr al tawashi, was accidentally left behind as his family fled shelling in damascus, he was found in the rubble by rebel fighters. rebuilding began after a legal process reunited the boy with his parents, who had mistakenly assumed he was dead. they now reside in a refugee camp in lebanon.
1595	danica patrick, a famous auto racer, is set to take part in the daytona 500, a famous motorsport race which she has never won before. the race has been won by other famous drivers like richard petty, dale earnhardt jr., and dale earnhardt sr. many in the motorsport world expect patrick to struggle in the race, as she has not yet proven herself at this level. still, the victory of a woman could be a significant breakthrough for women's sports.
1596	australian skincare brand moogoo has introduced edible lip balms made from all-natural ingredients, without any harmful chemicals or artificial dyes. the lip balms, which can be easily ingested, are vegan and contain ingredients like cow lick, tingling honey, and strawberry tinted. the brand replaced the cochineal insect dye (usually used for red color) with red beetroot extract, which offers a more natural and bug-free hue. the moisturizing balms are priced at £3.90 each.
1597	a family in the northern territory of australia experienced a gruesome surprise when they discovered a dried cane toad in their pack of beef jerky. the toads are an invasive species in the area and produce a toxin in their parotid gland that can be poisonous to many species, including humans. although the father who bit into the toad did not suffer ill effects, some locals have begun experimenting with cooking the cane toads as a delicacy.
1598	the eruption of a volcano in guatemala has been reducing, with emergency officials reporting a decrease in explosions and lava flows. however, an orange alert remains in place for nearby communities. 35,000 people might have theoretically been affected by the volcanic activity, but only 5,000 live in the threat direction. some have returned home while 800 sought shelter at shelters with the red cross.
1599	occupy wall street protesters' actions in new york may impact the world series, which starts in st. louis, missouri, on wednesday. protests and media spotlight have increased concerns for safety, while the world series will still go on as planned, honoring military veterans with a game between the texas rangers and st. louis cardinals. first lady michelle obama and dr. jill biden will attend the game in support of military veterans.
1600	a new zealand tourist, ryan, was exploring an island near the australian coast in his canoe. however, a large, 20ft-long crocodile started stalking him, forcing him to stay stranded on a hill for two weeks. after a chance encounter with a local man, don mcleod, using a light signal, ryan was rescued and taken to safety. ryan is now safe and in good health, and is grateful for don's rescue efforts.
1601	in july, 17-year-old tyler holder is believed to have abducted, raped, and murdered 6-year-old alanna gallagher. holder was shot by the police but survived, and is now facing charges of capital murder and attempted capital murder. newly released documents show police believe holder acted alone in the crime, buying a new cellphone and discretely disposing of alanna's body.
1602	several children in minnesota have died from a virulent strain of seasonal flu, prompting concerns from health officials and parents about the potentially lethal nature of the illness. up to 50 percent of students have been absent from school battling flu in some regions, leading to hospitalizations and fatalities amongst young people without underlying medical conditions. the h3 strain of the virus appears to be dominant this season, and some experts worry that the current flu vaccine may not provide enough protection. vaccination remains essential, with early prevention measures offering some degree of protection against the mutated h3n2 strain, as well as other strains that may become predominant later in the season.
1603	a volcano named mount tavurvur, located in papua new guinea on the island of new britain, erupted on friday. the volcano spewed ash as high as 60,000 feet above sea level, causing it to resemble a thick tower. residents shared dramatic photos on social media, showing the volcano belching fire and ash across a bay. past history shows the volcano erupted alongside nearby mount vulcan in 1994, which destroyed the township of rabual.
1604	ballinasloe horse fair, europe's oldest and largest horse fair in ireland, is a significant social and economic event for the irish travelling community. held annually in ballinasloe, county galway, it draws around 80,000 visitors from around the world to buy, sell, and race horses, along with other livestock like cattle, sheep, and poultry. traditionally, there has been a strong association between the horse fair and the irish travelling community, and it is the largest event held annually in the tradition. 
1605	blue light-emitting diodes (leds) were recently awarded the nobel prize in physics for their energy efficiency and significantly longer lifespan, but a new study indicates they may have a problem with insects. according to new zealand-based institute scion, blue led traps captured 48% more insects than yellow-emitting sodium-vapor lights. insects are more strongly attracted to blue light, which has been discovered to be fatal, causing flies to be thrown off their usual path and into the jaws of predators, disrupting the food chain.
1606	a ceasefire agreement aiming to bring an end to the six-year-long battle between the yemeni government and shiite muslim houthi rebels had gone into effect. however, the same day, yemeni deputy interior minister gen. mohammed bin abdullah al-qawsi accused houthi rebels of trying to assassinate him, saying his car came under fire by rebels in the northwestern city of saada while he was there to inspect security forces. despite this, the truce deal was still intact, with both sides continuing to lay down arms and cooperate on clearing land mines and releasing prisoners.
1607	in a 0-0 draw between burkina faso and equatorial guinea, burkina faso's hopes of reaching the african nations cup quarter-finals hang in the balance after losing their opening match and only drawing against hosts, equatorial guinea. the match saw missed chances by both teams and multiple close calls until the end. with only one point from two matches, burkina faso may struggle to secure the remaining spots needed for the quarter-finals.
1608	on august 5, 2011, passengers were removed from a us airways flight from scotland to alaska after a threatening note suggesting explosives were onboard. the note was sent to a london address. after arriving in philadelphia, the flight was taken to a different part of the airport and swept by law enforcement officials. a thorough search, including x-raying and inspecting luggage inside and outside the plane, found no problems. the plane continued onto anchorage, alaska, and no delays were caused by the evacuation.
1609	property owner saint pir pandariman is facing court after failing to carry out repairs on a damp property where a young, pregnant mother died. stacy bowman passed away in the mouldy home after suffering a series of chest infections. her husband had complained to the landlord about the living conditions, but the required repairs were not completed. the council issued an enforcement notice on november 25th, 2011, which bowman failed to fulfill before the mother's death in december. 
1610	an australian special forces soldier from the special air service (sas) allegedly threatened an australian secret intelligence service (asis) agent with a loaded gun during a drinking session in afghanistan, leading to the revelation of systemic issues in asis's control of weapons. asis agents with a blood alcohol content above zero are not allowed to carry or be issued with weapons.
1611	a wealthy man claims he spent over £115,000 on a woman he had been pursuing for a marriage proposal as she turned it down. the man, 65-year-old bruce dusting, says that marie lacombe, 42, from melbourne, australia, led him on to extract money from him for zumba classes, shopping trips, dental appointments, and cosmetic surgery, but she believes that the majority of the money he has requested her to return was given out of kindness. lacombe states that she worked as dusting's office assistant for four years without receiving payment, and the money he has requested a return has been spent on unsolicited gifts.
1612	shane warne, a former australian spinner, expresses his surprise at england's decision to choose matt prior over jos buttler for the series against sri lanka. warne questions the reasoning behind picking prior instead of buttler, who he believes would bring an extra element to the team with his batting abilities.

1614	a 10-year-old girl, latoya smith, was struck and killed by a lorry while trying to cross a road near her school, wearing earphones. her mother said latoya would have preferred not to change buses, and had good road sense. the inquest heard testimonies from eyewitnesses who saw the accident unfold, with some suggesting the driver may not have seen latoya. the driver later expressed guilt for the accident and the inquest continues into the circumstances of latoya's death.
1615	the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) urges anyone who received an injection from new england compounding center to be vigilant for meningitis symptoms. over 230 people have fallen ill, and 15 have died due to receiving steroid injections. while the fda has released a list of products and hospitals where infections may have occurred, it is difficult for patients to determine whether they received these products, and even doctors face challenges in identifying those who may have had these injections. the fda is continuing to work on identifying the products and distribution list.

1617	in kinshasa, democratic republic of the congo, there is a trend of "les sapeurs" – affluent men dressed in designer labels and expensive clothing, even though the country is known for one of the highest poverty levels in the world. the sapeurs are part of the congolese cultural story, born out of economic improvements leading to independence and a way for many to show off their wealth and cultural heritage.

1619	facebook is considering utilizing all of its 1 billion-plus members' profile photos to enhance its developing facial recognition database. the altered data usage policy states that this action serves to improve performance of its 'tag suggestions' feature which automatically tags friends and other users appearing in posted photos on the site. facebook assures users that they can opt-out of the tagging feature if they are uncomfortable with facial recognition technology but still maintaining that the move further helps ensure online privacy.
1620	a perfectly preserved medicinal chest dating back to the reign of george iii is expected to fetch more than £3,000 when it sells at auction later this week. the chest contains 29 exotically named bottled concoctions, including turkey rhubarb and laudanum, thought to be used by doctors to treat ailments such as gout, depression, or indigestion but have since been replaced by modern medicines. found in derbyshire, the chest is complete with scales, mixing bowls, and other utensils with many of the remedies still visible. the chest contains a set of instruction books that detail the uses of the medicinal potions.
1621	south korea is stripping the title of "honorary consul" from jill kelley, a florida socialite involved in a scandal that led to cia director david petraeus' resignation. she will lose the designation after a new york businessman accused her of trying to use the title to solicit business. kelley's title, which carries no official responsibility, was revealed after petraeus resigned in the wake of admitting to an extramarital affair.

1623	the world's largest particle accelerator, the large hadron collider, has commenced its first beam test, which marks a significant milestone as the machine prepares to analyze particle collisions and potentially provide new insights into how the universe was formed. the project, located underground on the border of france and switzerland, is expected to begin generating data by 2009, while scientists hope it may lead to the confirmation of theories and the potential discovery of the higgs boson.
1624	after a record-breaking halloween with hot temperatures, the uk experiences heavy showers, plummeting temperatures, and a tornado, causing the met office to declare it is "back to business as usual." a tornado struck leicestershire, damaging cars, bins, roofs, and a store at the belvoir shopping centre. while no one was reported to be injured, teams of council workmen were sent to aid in the cleanup process. the met office predicts november to be "back to business as usual" with cold and unsettled weather, and rain moving across the country in the upcoming two weeks.

1629	a european space agency (esa) team is training astronauts by sending them to navigate dark, damp caves in italy, which they say simulates the challenges of space travel. the 'caves' training program involves navigating uncharted caverns and mapping in real-time using 3d cameras and laser mapping devices. the astronauts will also encounter new species and measure carbon dioxide and radon levels.

1637	a man named andy decided to try a new approach to losing weight. instead of committing himself to a single strict diet for months at a time, he decided to switch between 10 different diets in the span of 50 days. the goal was to see if constantly changing diets would be more effective and enjoyable than following the same plan for an extended period. the 10 diets he tried were: 1. the 5:2 diet 2. the special k diet 3. following nhs guidance for a healthy diet 4. a juice fast 5. the high-fat, low-carb atkins diet 6. a raw food diet 7. the baby food diet 8. calorie counting using a mobile app 9. the grapefruit diet 10. the cabbage soup diet throughout the challenge, andy lost a total of 30½ pounds and reduced his waist size from 38-40 inches to 34-36 inches. he found that by constantly changing his diet, he was able to overcome the boredom that often plagues people on other diets. andy's method may not be for everyone, but his experience shows it is possible to achieve weight loss and improve overall health by varying dietary choices instead of committing to just one long-term plan.
1638	more doctors, dentists, veterinarians, and lawyers are becoming alcoholics, leading to a rise in professionals seeking rehab treatment abroad to avoid recognition. it is claimed that these "functioning alcoholics" avoid rehabs nearby, but demand for treatment is increasing due to high rates of binge drinking and obesity in the uk. one in fifteen doctors will develop an addiction problem, and they are three times more likely to develop cirrhosis of the liver than the general population. alistair mordey runs a substance abuse clinic in chiang mai, thailand, and there was a growing demand from professionals in london, where he would not want them to be. addiction specialists warn that shame and stigma surrounding addiction prevents many professionals from seeking help, as they feel they must continue to help others.

1642	a study finds a significant increase in the number of city dwellers suffering from hay fever in urban areas due to pollution. demand for hay fever products has increased by more than 50% in towns and cities, with the highest demand reported in london, followed by birmingham and manchester. pharmacists note hay fever and the common cold have varying symptoms, with hay fever resulting from an allergic reaction to pollen and the common cold caused by a minor viral infection with similar symptoms but clear discharge. sufferers are advised to consult pharmacists and take antihistamines, wash daily, and wear wraparound sunglasses.

1656	health experts warn against washing chicken before cooking, as this can spread potentially fatal campylobacter bacteria. almost half of britons rinse raw chicken, which may lead to thousands of cases of food poisoning annually. the bacteria can survive and spread in the region of three feet during this process. while washing meat kills many germs, campylobacter bacteria is behind more than 500 deaths a year, and costs the economy hundreds of millions of pounds in healthcare costs and sick leave. despite concerns, cooking chicken thoroughly kills most harmful bacteria; even without cooking, the bacteria can be found in untreated water, unpasteurised milk, undercooked chicken liver, and liver paté.

1664	australian swimmer chloe mccardel, who gave up her attempt to swim from cuba to florida due to dangerous jellyfish encounters, has concluded that she will not return to the water again. the endurance athlete had picked june as a tentative low-danger time for jellyfish, but encountered a swarm in her journey and suffered painful stings that made the endeavor impossible for her. furthermore, her attempts to tackle these water hazards have resulted in multiple failures with other women attempting to complete the swim. although some experts believe the cuba to florida swim is possible, the harsh conditions and the potential fatal consequences, caused by the box jellyfish in particular, make it a difficult and potentially dangerous challenge to take on.

1675	u.s. aviation authorities have launched an investigation after a jetblue airways passenger jet was forced to abort its takeoff when another plane carrying holidaymakers crossed the runway at new york's john f. kennedy international airport without authorization. jetblue flight 1295 was preparing to depart when a caribbean airlines boeing 737 had just landed and crossed into its path. the jetblue captain hit the brakes to avoid a collision, and the aircraft returned to the gate and took off for austin, texas, three hours late. the caribbean airlines flight crew was on the wrong frequency at the time of the incident, causing them not to hear tower instructions to stop. there were no reported injuries.

1678	a magnitude-7.1 earthquake struck the central philippines on tuesday, causing at least 99 deaths and 276 injuries as people were celebrating a religious holiday. buildings collapsed, causing panic in the streets. the effects affected 2.9 million people, and dozens were missing. tuesday was a national holiday during the muslim festival of eid al-adha. earthquakes of this magnitude can sometimes cause tsunamis within 100 kilometers of the epicenter.
1679	a tragic collision between a truck and a suv in dumas, texas, left five teenagers dead, injured the truck driver and resulted in a fire. the crash emphasizes motor vehicle accidents that are the number one killer for youths in the us. another accident in warren, ohio, occurred just hours earlier and resulted in six teenagers' deaths when an suv they were inside crashed, after which they were speeding down a road. these accidents highlight the ongoing issue of teen fatalities in the us from traffic-related incidents, emphasizing the need for road safety measures.

1682	a stampede occurred during the love parade music festival in duisburg, germany, resulting in 21 deaths and 511 injured. witnesses reported overcrowding in an underpass between the main event site and an expansion area, leading to a panic as people lost consciousness from being crushed against the walls and each other. german chancellor angela merkel called for a thorough investigation, with numbers disputed by both organizers and police on the number of attendees.
1683	a plain white short-sleeved t-shirt can make a man up to 12% more attractive to women. this is because it creates an illusion that broadens the shoulders and slims the waist, producing a more v-shaped body, which is considered masculine. the best results were observed in participants who were most out of shape, with the study concluding that shifting focus to a man's gut reduces his desirability. a waist-to-chest ratio (wcr) of between 0.7 and 0.8 is seen as the ideal. the t-shirt study shows how fashion and optical illusions can have an implicit positive effect on perceived attractiveness and health.

1687	in st. louis, a bosnian woman was attacked, threatened, and dragged out of her car because of her ethnicity. this comes after the recent murder of a bosnian man nearby. the victim said she was threatened with murder and called a liar by the perpetrators who assaulted her, pushing her back to the ground and kicking her. the police and the fbi are treating the case as a hate crime.
1688	a 22-year-old and her best friend are creating australia's first moveable tiny home, with a cost of just $15,000. the home, which is made of miniature proportions with all the basic features of a typical house, follows the 'three use' principle, where every object must have at least three uses to be accepted. the moveable home has been created to reduce their footprint on the environment and explore living with less stuff.
1689	the fbi is investigating an arson fire at the chinese consulate in san francisco, which has led chinese diplomats to call on the united states for increased protection. footage from surveillance cameras showed a person emerging from a parked mini-van and pouring gasoline on the front door before igniting it. there have been no claims of responsibility, and the united states has not been aware of a specific threat against the consulate.
1690	a hoax call targeting kate middleton, the pregnant wife of prince william, led to the suicide of a nurse at king edward vii's hospital. southern cross austereo chairman max moore-wilton calls the event "truly tragic" and hopes for full details in an investigation, while australia's prime minister condemns the event as "very sad." the hoax call's australian radio station issued an apology and took its djs off the air for an undetermined period, while the hospital criticized their prank call actions as "truly appalling." the controversy led to advertising being pulled from the station and calls for consequences on social media.

1692	in the sea of japan, two russian military aircraft flew close to two us navy ships, participating in a joint military exercise with south korea. this event occurred after previous russian overflights of us ships in the past year. us military officials stated that the incident was a demonstration of russian military prowess but considered it less significant than other recent events.
1693	the united states is moving a warship and a sea-based radar platform closer to the north korean coast to monitor their military moves, including possible new missile launches. the decision to move uss john s. mccain and the oil rig-like sea-based x-band radar follows provocative rhetoric from north korea. the united states and south korea have continued joint military exercises, while north korea has lashed out at recent tensions and u.s. sanctions against it. concerns remain that north korea could carry out a localized attack, as it did in 2010 when it shelled yeongpyeong island in south korea, killing four people.
1694	a village in north yorkshire has been overrun with flies, causing residents to consider moving as a result of the large number of flies entering their homes. poultry farms have been blamed for the problem that has persisted for more than a decade. the issue prompted residents to hold a meeting, collect fly paper, and contact the council's environmental health team.
1695	a doctor recalls her first encounter with a premature baby 20 years ago, emphasizing the delicacy of their care. following a 2012 power outage causing flooding at nyu's langone medical center, 64 patients were evacuated, including three mothers in labor and seven newborn babies. dr. kenneth davis, ceo of mount sinai, was called upon to assist, ultimately admitting the affected patients to mount sinai. one of these babies, named emma, weighing 2 pounds 13 days old, was safely transferred. the story highlights the immense effort that goes into caring for premature infants and the risk of exposing them to the potential dangers of transport outside of the icu.
1696	ten americans, some members of a charity organization based in idaho, were detained and accused of child trafficking in haiti after they allegedly tried to move 33 children from haiti to the dominican republic, claiming they intended to take the children to a shelter. however, haiti's prime minister said the group was kidnapping the children, and it is unclear who is responsible or what their intentions are. the detained americans are being treated well and are trusting in the truth being revealed, while their actions are further examined in haiti. the group of americans, among them members of new life children's refuge, claimed they were trying to help orphaned children in haiti, but were detained for alleged immigration violations and child trafficking. 
1697	president barack obama announced the creation of a national monument to honor labor and civil rights activist cesar chavez, making him the first national park service monument to honor a latino born later than the 1700s. decades before, when chavez led his farm worker movement, people didn't care about invisble farmworkers - they were bent over the beating sun, living in poverty, being cheated by growers, and often left in old age with no rights. by protesting and organizing, chavez led to the creation of farm worker contracts. president obama says we should live up to cesar chavez's example, but there is still much more work to be done. obama's decision is seen as an effort to both honor and connect with important latino voters.
1698	the recent spate of mass shootings in the united states has led to concerns and fears among americans. a former los angeles police officer, christopher dorner, is suspected of perpetrating a massacre, which serves as a reminder of the prototypical nature of mass killings that typically involve victims targeted for specific reasons. although often fueled by bitterness and resentment, mass killers tend to act methodically and with purpose, often driven by a need for vengeance and a desire to bring others to justice for perceived mistreatment.
1699	a report by the rac foundation suggests that introducing restrictions on young driver's licenses could result in a reduction of fatal accidents in the age group of 15 to 24, which is the most dangerous time for young drivers. restrictions such as night-time driving bans and limited passenger allowance, could help to improve their experience before unlimited driving. the report recommends a 1-year minimum learning period, a one-year post-test probationary period, and a final full license after two years of successful probation. the foundation's call for reducing the drink-drive limit from 80 to 50mg/100ml blood alcohol content would provide greater safety benefits for younger drivers, and benefit the rest of the driving population.
1700	in august 2012, a qantas jet experienced a delay due to two first-class passengers refusing to fly unless they received the correct size of luxury pyjamas. the couple demanded either a pair of first-class pyjamas in xl-size or they would wait for another flight. as a result, the aircraft was delayed for departure by 30 minutes while the couple's baggage was removed from the plane. the delay caused amusement among the other passengers, who were informed of the reason by the captain. once the couple received the correct pyjamas, they disembarked, and the plane continued to melbourne as scheduled. the passengers found amusement in the situation and sympathized with the couple to some extent.
1701	in the united states, a quarter of adults suffer from mental illness but may not receive proper treatment. smartphone apps and therapy can help, with tools available for a variety of conditions, from ocd to depression. for instance, the "live ocd free" app utilizes exposure and response prevention therapy. other mental wellness apps track moods and behaviors, and apps are used to boost happiness and gratitude. bipolar disorder connect aims to help manage bipolar disorder, while the pts disorder coach and tactical breather apps are helpful for stress management and relaxation.
1702	several elderly chinese people have been killing themselves to ensure they are registered prior to a looming ban on burials in anhui province, which will take effect after june 1. the ban is necessary as cemeteries in the province are running out of space. since the announcement of the ban on april 1, several elderly people have killed themselves to guarantee one of the last few burial options available. the government has received criticism for the decision to enforce the policy so quickly.

1710	in recent years, the number of vacant homes in atlanta has increased due to unpaid mortgages, resulting in an increased number of burglaries. the atlanta police department has formed a special vacant home burglary team in response, but law enforcement officials across the country are also experiencing a surge in such incidents. the rising cost of copper is driving some of the thievery, but it is not the only target of the burglars. estimated damage from one burglary can reach up to $20,000, yet the thieves manage to steal only a fraction of that value in copper. housing developers and homeowners are often required to replace stolen items and fix the property after a burglary, with the cost far exceeding the value of the stolen items themselves.

1712	police in moscow are questioning a suspect in connection with an acid attack that severely disfigured the artistic director of russia's bolshoi ballet, sergei filin. the attack occurred in january and left filin with severe burns, requiring at least six months for him to recover. the investigation is ongoing, with bolshoi ballet authorities revealing that filin had previously faced intimidation and unidentified individuals attempting to hack his facebook page before the attack. filin was hired as the ballet's artistic director in 2011.
1713	scientists at bangor university in wales claimed that they killed a 507-year-old clam, nicknamed ming, simply to find out how old it was. researchers opened ming's shell and discovered it was 507 years old, ten years older than their previous estimate of 405 years. although they had no idea of the animal's age when they found it on the coast of iceland in 2006, researchers said they didn't "want to leave any doubt" over ming's age when measuring its rings to determine its age. ming's life included being around during historical milestones such as the english civil war, the enlightenment, the industrial revolution, and two world wars.
1714	a mother has been given permission to change the surname of her three-year-old twin sons due to their father's online blogging activities, which were deemed "bizarre" by a family court. the father, embroiled in litigation and with a perceived "perception of martyrdom," had posted sensitive and confidential information about the children and their mother, putting their welfare at risk. the judge deemed it "necessary and proportionate" to allow the children to change their names to protect them from future harm.
1715	a recent study conducted by researchers at the university of illinois revealed a link between physical fitness and brain structure in children aged 9 and 10. the study found that children with higher levels of aerobic fitness had more compact and fibrous white matter in their brain, which is critical for sending signals between brain regions. this white matter structure may contribute to higher-fit children achieving better results on cognitive tasks. the team aims to investigate further by studying the effects of white-matter tract integrity on brain health and cognition in children who begin regular physical fitness programs and maintain them over time.

1762	kurdish fighters have taken the syrian city of kobani from islamic state (isis) control, after 112 days of fighting. the people's protection units (ypg) now controls the city, with kurdish officials expressing hope for an official announcement on tuesday. the news comes a day after iraq's diyala province was "liberated" from isis. officials are now working to clear the streets and defuse possible booby traps, before allowing residents to return to their homes.
