2088	whistleblowers from the u.s. department of veterans affairs (va) detail secretly received secret information about the mistreatment of american veterans which included delayed colonoscopies and endoscopies leading to the death of up to 20 veterans. employees fear retaliation for speaking out, which can lead to career harm, loss of financial stability, and even jail time. the office of special counsel is investigating alleged punishment of 37 va employees accused of exposing wrongdoing.
2089	jk rowling, the author of the harry potter series, has said in an interview that while she cannot guarantee topping the success of the popular children's books, she plans to continue to write and support charities. the seven-book series has made rowling an estimated £1 billion in wealth, and she has been involved in philanthropy and set up her charity, lumos, to fight the institutionalisation of children.
2090	"jackson 5ive" is a heavily fictionalized representation of the rise to fame of the jackson 5, adapted into an animated series that began airing on abc's saturday morning cartoon lineup in september 1971. produced by rankin/bass and motown records, the series features the jackson brothers solving problems with their music and intelligence rather than resorting to violence. most episodes include the j5 living with their manager, motown founder berry gordy, exploring different settings and themes, with michael jackson occasionally slipping into fantastical dream scenarios as a result of accidents. the show premiered in 1971 and was later released on dvd/bluray by dreamworks classics.
2091	in 2011, during the conrad murray trial, it was revealed that michael jackson's doctor, dr. conrad murray, had multiple girlfriends and was on the phone with some of them at the time jackson stopped breathing. the prosecution claimed that murray's actions, including making phone calls instead of attending to jackson, contributed to the singer's death.

2093	timothy walker, a 34-year-old man, was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole after admitting to aggravated murder in the slaying of sergeant derek johnson, 32. traci vaillancourt, a former model and walker's long-time girlfriend, read a letter she had written to walker from jail, saying she forgives him for shooting her in the back but not for murdering the police officer. despite all they have been through, vaillancourt still loves walker and prays for him, hoping that one day they can be together again.
2094	a care worker, jennifer marley, stole cash from a housebound pensioner, mavis pately, over a six-month period, causing pately to die as a result. surveillance footage caught marley stealing around £1,000 from pately's home, and she was subsequently convicted of two counts of theft at plymouth crown court. although marley returned the £1,000 stolen, the family believes £2,000 is still missing. after pately's death, her family installed cameras in the home and shared the footage with the police, helping to secure marley's conviction.
2095	a mix-up between comedians nazeem hussain and waleed aly led to abc 7.30 host leigh sales being tempted to change her usual show opening. the age newspaper mistakenly published a photo of hussain alongside the caption: "waleed aly joins the project," with aly's face replacing a portrait of the comedian. although sales joked about incorporating aly's name into the show, she did not follow through on her remarks.
2096	tom magliozzi, a half of the "click and clack" team and host of npr's car talk radio show, passed away at the age of 77 from complications of alzheimer's disease. the show, which has been on air for more than 25 years, focused on relaxed discussions about cars, with tom and his younger brother, ray, taking questions from listeners. the show became a top-rated program for npr and inspired at least two books as well as two television shows.
2097	online pharmacies may offer tempting prices, but the fda and other authorities have warned against them, as they often sell counterfeit or substandard medication, or without proper safeguards. several websites have been shut down, and officials have arrested 58 people and seized illegal medications valued at over $41 million. the fda commissioner believes the safest drug supply in the world still comes from regulatory medicines, though the scope of the online pharmacy issue remains difficult to define. a combination of fda, customs, and pharmaceutical company efforts has been implemented to track and combat the issue.
2098	pepsico removed the word 'natural' from some of its products and replaced it with 'simply.' this move was implemented last year as an attempt to update their marketing. the shift comes amidst lawsuits against other companies using the term 'natural' in their products, such as naked juices by pepsico.
2099	uk proposes to ban cigarette packets from branding and require plain-packed cigarettes to deter smoking and decrease smuggling, but faces opposition from the tobacco industry and potential issues with trade agreements.
2100	malala yousafzai became the youngest recipient of the nobel peace prize, but just a day earlier had passed the two-year anniversary of the assassination attempt on her life. in 2012, the 15-year-old was the target of gunmen in swat valley, pakistan, but survived and was taken to the united kingdom for treatment, where her recovery from critical condition was considered a miracle. since then, she has continued advocating for the right of girls to have access to education, which has led to worldwide support for her cause and several awards, including the nobel peace prize.
2101	new york's top police official, pedro perez, announced his resignation, the second acting superintendent to quit in two weeks. perez denied his resignation was due to the ongoing ethics scandals in albany, stating that his decision to retire was based on his own honest choices. his resignation takes effect on friday, and perez's career as a police officer will end after 28 years. the investigations involve a top aide to governor david paterson, who has been embroiled in several recent controversies.
2102	the duke and duchess of cambridge decide to spend christmas with the middleton family at their home in bucklebury, berkshire. the couple, prince william and kate middleton, are expecting their first child together. the queen and duke of edinburgh have given their approval for this decision. their families, sister pippa and brother james middleton, are also expected to join them.
2103	a new video called "anthropocene" shows earth transformed by humans through light pollution, paved and unpaved roads, railways, electricity transmission lines, and air traffic routes. the video, created by anthropologist felix pharand, is the result of 13 years of work and uses data from agencies like the geospatial intelligence agency and atmospheric administration to accurately illustrate humanity's global impact on earth's land surface. the anthropocene video highlights patterns of global sprawl and our planet's degree of human-influenced development.
2104	gavin clark, a 41-year-old primary school caretaker, was jailed for 12 months and placed on the sex offenders' register for 10 years after being found guilty of possessing indecent images of children. he lived in a school cupboard during his divorce and was discovered with 1,749 pornographic pictures of children on his computer. clark claimed he found the images in a card he came across near the school. he was suspended from his position after the discovery and was sacked.
2105	six republican presidential candidates own a vast array of houses, each reflecting their unique personalities and preferences. among them is former house speaker newt gingrich, whose mansion features a marble bathroom with gold vanity and chandelier. jon huntsman, former governor of utah, has a five-bedroom townhouse in washington, d.c. mitt romney has a six-bedroom lakefront house in new hampshire, rick perry's gated california home has five bedrooms, ron paul's texas ranch includes a pool, and michele bachmann's home in minnesota is more traditional. former senator rick santorum's virginia residence is in colonial style.
2106	former suburban omaha teacher, ann urwiler, and her husband jon were sentenced to 39 days in jail, two years of probation, and $1,000 in fines each. they pleaded guilty to contributing to the delinquency of a child after officers saw teenagers fleeing from a party at their papillion home in july. sarpy county prosecutors dropped charges of procuring alcohol for a minor in exchange for their pleas. the urwilers will serve their jail time every other weekend at the sarpy county jail and will comply further with strict measures to ensure nothing like this happens again.

2110	two men are being searched for by the police in new york city after committing a violent armed robbery at a jewelry store in manhattan's diamond district. the suspects entered the building with possible automatic weapons, pistol-whipped the owner, and stole an unknown amount of cash and jewelry. they were later confirmed to have left the scene, but the possibility of them still being inside the building prompted a full building search and evacuation. the suspects are described as black and one was wearing a long black trench coat.
2111	a propane gas plant in florida experienced a violent explosion that injured five workers fighting for their lives in critical condition, and three people were injured in total. the cause remains undetermined but has been attributed to a spark from a passing forklift and a combination of human error and equipment malfunction. firefighters are investigating if the spark caused a spark from a forklift to ignite a flammable propane mixture that led to the explosion. the blast injured eight people, and the plant hosts 53,000 small 20-pound propane tanks on site.
2112	this article by shari miller, published on january 24th, 2014, discusses a photographer from russia, sergei kokinskiy, who captured stunning images of a large colony of penguins at south george island near the falkland islands in the southern atlantic ocean. the chicks, still with thick brown fur, can sometimes number up to 200,000, waiting for their parents to return with food.
2113	european leaders have put a new policy in place, allowing the search and rescue operation called mare nostrum in the mediterranean to end, as they believe it is too costly. mare nostrum has saved 150,000 people while also pulling out 3,343 bodies from the waves. this decision is met with disapproval from the rest of the world. starting from november 1, the european union’s border and coast guard agency, frontex, will assume the operation with its focus being on securing borders instead of rescuing sea-crossing migrants. this decision by the european union has been met with backlash as they are viewed as closing their eyes to the refugee crisis.
2114	schalke faces their first real test since roberto di matteo became their coach as they host second-placed wolfsburg in the bundesliga. schalke has won all three games at home, although their away form has been poor with three defeats. di matteo insists he is focused on the game but not the reunion with former club chelsea in the champions league next week. borussia dortmund are keen to build on their win over borussia mönchengladbach last time out when they play host to paderborn this weekend.

2116	nawaz sharif, the previously ousted prime minister, appears to be back in the top position in pakistan, with unofficial results showing his party, the pakistan muslim league nawaz (pml-n), as having won most of the seats in the national assembly. the election comes after months of violence, targeting both candidates and innocent citizens alike. in spite of the unsettling circumstances, there was a high turnout, with many exercising their right to vote for the first time. the election is considered a historic democratic step, signaling a possible shift in the nation's political landscape.

2118	cristiano ronaldo, a professional football player, recently reached a career goal total of 400 with a double in his club team, real madrid's 3-0 win over celta vigo. despite this accomplishment, he has never scored in the seventh minute of a professional match. despite the seventh-minute curse, ronaldo has scored goals in practically every minute of a game during his career, including a total of 47 goals for his national team, portugal.

2120	the strong national museum of play in rochester, ny, will be establishing a world video game hall of fame as part of the national toy hall of fame. this new exhibit will recognize and celebrate the iconic impact of video games like pong and grand theft auto. beginning in march, the public may submit nominations for their favorite video games online, while an internal advisory committee will choose the finalists. in future, an international selection committee will choose annual inductees based on their icon-status, longevity, geographical reach, and the influence they have had on other games, entertainment, popular culture, and society in general.
2121	children should be encouraged to play sudoku and crosswords in school as these activities can boost their brain power according to experts. doing sudoku puzzles improves memory while crosswords enhance verbal fluency, vocabulary, and problem-solving skills. university of cambridge researchers found that puzzles have psychological and cognitive benefits for pupils up to the key stage two level and can support the national curriculum. tablets usage among three-to-four-year-olds at home has increased, which has led to nurseries inviting childnet to teach online safety.
2122	researchers claim that when people cry with happiness at weddings, it is a response to a happy experience with a negative reaction. the reaction may help restore emotional equilibrium in those experiencing strong positive emotions, enabling better management of intense emotions. the study sheds light on emotional expressions and control, providing insights essential for understanding mental and physical health, relationships, and work performance.
2123	ronny deila, the manager of celtic, woke up feeling defeated after their dismal champions league defeat to legia warsaw. despite being devastated, the norwegian manager determined to take advantage of the football team's lifeline as a result of the opponent's registration error. this unexpected stroke of luck offers the opportunity for the team to potentially earn a £15 million windfall, enabling deila to finally sign a player of superior caliber instead of adding more “jersey fillers.” despite feeling fatigued and overwhelmed in the wake of the loss, deila acknowledged the importance of not wallowing in defeat; football is all about results and, in the short term, every match is about a single result. the team has the chance to show their improvements and take advantage of this second chance on wednesday against maribor.

2127	more premature babies born when their mother is 24 weeks pregnant are surviving, but babies delivered earlier rarely live, say british researchers. a new study showed that the numbers of babies born very early increase are being helped to survive. however, the number of children and adults with long-term disabilities due to premature birth will rise, according to researchers. the figures suggest that while rising numbers of babies born very early are being helped to survive, the number of children and adults with long-term disabilities as a result will also increase.
2128	maria kang is an american fitness enthusiast who is 32 years old and works out for 30 to 60 minutes per day, six days a week. she is under attack from her facebook post where she took a provocative photo with her 1, 3, and 4-year-old sons. she poses in her workout bra and shorts, and in the photo, she has the number of hours she sleeps, drinks water, and exercises daily. the photo has over 16 million views and has generated both positive and negative feedback. kang believes that her intention was just to inspire and motivate people to get healthy.

2132	a protein called periostin plays a critical role in tumor spread. by blocking periostin, scientists in switzerland were able to prevent the formation of secondary cancers. they found that certain conditions are necessary for metastatic cancer to develop, and periostin seems to be a key element in that process. the research, published in the journal nature, has potential for developing new cancer treatments.

2134	a 10-year-old boy, michael joseph delvecchio, was found safe on monday morning after running away from his home on sunday in florida, usa. he was seen walking near a publix on orange blossom trail by a motorist, who recognized him from tv news bulletins. the boy was found a mile from his home and reunited with his family.
2135	a nanny from india, sandra samuel, saved a 2-year-old boy named moshe holtzberg during terrorist attacks in mumbai. she brought moshe to safety and risked her life to keep him safe, but claims that she sees no heroism in her actions and wishes she could have done more to help moshe's parents. after the attacks, she was brought to israel, where moshe lives under the care of the chabad movement. despite their harrowing experiences, samuel stays close to moshe and continues to care for him.
2136	actress bailee madison shares her experience as youth spokesperson for alex's lemonade stand foundation, promoting awareness and fundraising for pediatric cancer research. the organization has raised over $80 million since 2005, supporting families with travel expenses for treatments. madison encourages people to hold lemonade stands to support alex's dream and contribute to finding a cure.
2137	chelsea clinton traces her african awakening back to 1990 when she witnessed nelson mandela walking out of prison. she has taken on a trip with her father, former president bill clinton, showcasing african projects involving better health, economic empowerment, and climate change. the clinton foundation works to close the gaps that arise due to not being born in the right place and supports projects with the aim of no longer needing their help in the future.
2138	connecticut governor dannel malloy signed a bill into law abolishing the death penalty, making the state the 17th in the nation to abandon capital punishment. the law goes into effect immediately, replacing the death penalty with life in prison without parole as connecticut's highest form of punishment. lawmakers have tried to pass similar bills in the past but were blocked by former republican governor jodi reell. connecticut has previously had capital punishment since its colonial days; since then, the death penalty has been upheld by the supreme court in 1976.
2139	ukrainian politician olga lyulchak claims to be the victim of an icloud hacker after her naked pictures leaked online. she does not feel ashamed and, in comparison to great masters like van gogh, considers her raunchy images a form of fine art. lyulchak is a candidate for the ukrainian democratic alliance for reform (udar) party and stands up against the demonization of women who appear naked in photographs. ukrainian parliamentary elections are scheduled for october 26.
2140	police, paramedics, a rabbi, a nurse, and a boy scout leader are among 71 people arrested in the new york city area during operation caireen, a sweeping investigation into the secret trading of child porn on the internet. the operation led to charges against 70 men and one woman and marked one of the largest local roundups of consumers of child pornography yet. consuming child porn is not seen as occurring solely among unemployed drifters, with those arrested representing all segments of society.
2141	kenyan-born british cyclist chris froome won the seventh stage of the tour de france, with his teammate bradley wiggins moving into the race leader's yellow jersey. froome, an expert climber, showed his ability in a steep finish at la planche des belles filles. meanwhile, defending champion cadel evans came in second, and wiggins has emerged as the strong front-runner to become the first british tour de france winner.

2143	in kabul, afghanistan, militants attacked u.s. and afghan troops in eastern afghanistan, leading to the deaths of eight american troops and two members of the afghan national security force, marking the largest number of americans killed by hostile action in a single day in over a year, according to cnn records. the fighting lasted about 12 hours, with militants attacking from multiple locations using rockets, mortars, and heavy-caliber machine guns. coalition forces were able to repel the attack and inflict heavy enemy casualties. general stanley mcchrystal, the top us and nato commander in afghanistan, has been focusing on protecting afghan civilians rather than holding remote outposts.

2145	a guide dog owners' charity, guide dogs for the blind association, has expressed concerns among visually impaired people in london due to irresponsible cyclists. the association claims that over half of blind or visually impaired people have been involved in an accident with a cyclist, while over three quarters experienced near-collisions with them. the charity has launched the "cycleyes" campaign, aimed at raising awareness and promoting responsible cycling for better safety for all road users by calling cyclists to use their eyes for those unable to see properly.

2149	the lumbia belt aims to alleviate lower back pain and prevent the need for surgery, specifically targeting those suffering from lumbago. 80% of people experience lower back pain at some point in their lives due to age, arthritis, spinal damage, or poor posture. the lumbia belt helps improve posture by using a sensor to detect when your posture is poor and vibrating to remind you to change it.

2202	fitness experts have named walking as the "superfood of fitness," as it may be more beneficial than intense exercise and may cost less than alternative "superfoods." walking requires movement "nutrients," which similarly support the body as dietary nutrients. combined physical activity and inactivity are believed to be more important for chronic disease risk than physical activity alone. walking frequently and engaging in low-intensity exercise can improve physical health and wellbeing without requiring grueling hours at the gym.

2209	the monaco grand prix is a prestigious formula one race known for its glamour and sophistication. with 78 laps around the narrow streets of the principality, the event draws the interest of wealthy residents who view the action from yachts moored at the mediterranean port. some legendary drivers such as michael schumacher and ayrton senna have dominated this race, while others consider it to be an extraordinary highlight of the season. the large sums of money at stake make it quite a sought-after race for top drivers.
2210	eva braun, who married adolf hitler just days before their suicides, wrote letters expressing her growing sense of despair as the soviet army overran berlin in april 1945. she reported on the war from the bunker hideout, where she shared with hitler and his henchmen, and on her suicide with him. the letters are published in a book by third reich expert anna maria sigmund, and their authenticity is assured by her descendants. hitler had kept eva braun's existence secret from the german people, as he believed it served his purposes better to be "married to the nation."
2211	new generations of chinese fashion designers are gaining international recognition and are becoming a force to be reckoned with at fashion weeks in paris, london, milan, and new york. these emerging designers, influenced by western design education and the rich chinese culture, have made a name for themselves in the fashion world.
2212	the meteor that exploded over russia in february had previously survived collisions that blackened its surface, making it difficult to spot. due to these impacts, the meteor, which was mostly made of ordinary rock, reflected only 5% of the light or less. researchers found that small asteroids are harder to detect because they reflect less light. the blast damaged the city of chelyabinsk and raised concerns about humanity's vulnerability to dangerous asteroids. nasa aims to launch a mission to observe, study, and potentially deflect asteroids.
2213	anti-obama campaign posters with children giving the finger to president obama have sparked controversy in massachusetts, with some deeming them offensive and illegal while others find them funny. these provocative billboards are on display outside a motorbike accessories store and show support for republican candidate mitt romney. town officials argue that the signs are distracting for drivers and could be dangerous, as the store's owner didn't obtain a permit to display the posters. while some find the signs amusing, others believe they are racist and regressive.
2214	the vietnam war was a devastating chapter in president lyndon johnson's presidency, ultimately affecting his legacy more than anything else. despite his landmark domestic achievements and strong social contract, johnson intensified america's involvement in the fight against communism in vietnam. at the height of his political power in 1965 and following a huge electoral victory, he was influenced by the pressure to appear tough on defense and the "domino theory" which stated that if one country fell to communism, others would follow. initially, johnson had doubts about the war, but ultimately pushed for the gulf of tonkin resolution, which became a significant turning point in the conflict. despite mounting criticism from within his own party, including hubert humphrey, johnson maintained a strong stance throughout his presidency, further entangling the united states in the vietnames quagmire. 
2215	model abbey clancy has been unveiled as the face of ultimo's party lingerie range by founder michelle mone obe. the range features three problem-solving products, including a low back body, low back bra, and strapless 'wear 5 ways' multi-way. clancy showcased the products in an ultra-sultry campaign shoot in a french style boudoir. she has made a name for herself in the modelling world and has recently been named the face of fragrances for both avon and veet, showcasing her talents across multiple industries.
2216	on december 15, 2013, published at 9:00 pm est, nelson mandela's death is mourned worldwide. however, in a table of people's historical importance created by google engineer richard skiena, mandela ranks just 356th. the list includes toppers such as jesus, napoleon, and muhammad, below mandela are winston churchill (37th), george w bush (33rd), and ronald reagan (46th). despite being lower in the list, winston churchill is the highest-placed prime minister. the table is based on a program that mainly draws on the entries from wikipedia, internet newspaper reports, books published on the web, and other parts of the internet to rank historical figures. the list highlights that some historical figures are often overlooked, and a scientific approach might help to correct human errors.
2217	the das park hotel offers innovative accommodation for budget-conscious travelers in refurbished sewer pipes, featuring cosy rooms, power points, and even artwork by austrian artist thomas latzel ochoa. however, the rooms are without windows and require guests to use nearby public toilets and showers. the hotel is currently only open from may to october, with bookings available for up to three nights free of charge or by paying 'whatever they can afford'. das park hotel aims to offer a unique and cost-effective travel experience, integrating local infrastructure and businesses into the concept.
2218	a blizzard caused more than 2 feet of snow to pile up in washington, cutting power to thousands as president obama remained busy in the city while staying safe in an armored four-wheel drive chevy suburban. blizzards affected many locations, bringing severe weather conditions and resulting in flights being cancelled and significant road accidents. over a million customers were left without power due to the storm.
2219	a new york yankees newcomer, shane greene, faced criticism after his gentle underarm toss to first base went terribly wrong, flying over his teammate's head. although there was no run for the opposing team, it has caused mockery due to greene's three errors in one game since 1988. fans compared his performance to that of a 5ft 105-year-old widow who made a strong underhand toss the night before.
2220	bosnian striker edin dzeko will miss euro 2016 qualifier against israel due to a calf injury, which may sideline him for up to three weeks. the absence of dzeko will negatively impact bosnia's chances of getting their group campaign back on track, with teammate vedad ibisevic already ruled out long-term. bosnia manager safet susic expressed concern over the team's outcome without their top scorer, fearing there is no chance of winning without dzeko.
2221	british new wave ska legends the specials performed their 30th-anniversary tour with an energetic, sold-out show at london's brixton academy. despite frontman jerry dammers' absence and lynval golding's lost voice, the band played five consecutive sold-out shows, with audience members eagerly bouncing and singing along to their hits. 
2222	rafael cabrera-bello managed to achieve a feat even rory mcilroy was unable to do, surging into contention for the season-ending dp world tour championship on friday. cabrera-bello overcame a difficult first round and opened with five birdies during his second, while mcilroy birdied four out of the first five holes on earth course at jumeirah golf estates in an early lead.
2223	bitter arctic winds could cause parts of britain to experience their coldest spell of august weather in almost a century. low pressure from the north is responsible for dragging in cold air, leading to low temperatures and damp, windy weather that may reach as far as scotland. the chance of snow and sleet has also been predicted. while temperatures should rise in the coming weeks, this weather event will likely make the end of summer disappointing for many.
2224	anthony weiner, a politician who lost the new york mayoral primary due to a sexting scandal, has issued a heartfelt apology to his wife, huma abedin, in a gq interview. weiner, who stood by the sexting behavior as meaningless, now realizes the pain he caused his partner and his impact on huma's reputation in the press.
2225	mitchell whisenhunt, a 26-year-old man from longview, texas, passed away from marfan's syndrome, but not before leaving behind 30 letters to his wife, ashley, and their 1-year-old daughter. the letters provide comfort and guidance to his family and remind them of the special occasions he wanted to acknowledge before he passed, similar to the novel and movie "p.s. i love you". gofundme has been used to help with their memorial costs.
2226	a measles outbreak that originated at disneyland has spread to at least 95 people across the united states. nearly 200 children who could have been exposed in arizona must stay home for 21 days or wear masks when leaving, as health officials are working to prevent further spread. the virus has now been confirmed in five other states including washington, oregon, utah, colorado, and mexico, as health officials advise individuals who haven't been vaccinated to stay home to prevent any exposure risk.
2227	thousands of pro-russian activists stormed the odessa police station, releasing arrested protesters after clashes that led to dozens of casualties. the protesters clashed with police in riot gear, asserting their claims to bring peace back to the city. the violence escalated to a dramatic point when pro-russian activists attacked police, attempting to seize control. eventually, the violence died down, and a few hours later, police released prisoners, many of whom were pro-russian activists.
2228	cesar laurean, the 22-year-old suspected killer of 20-year-old pregnant marine, was extradited from mexico to north carolina. he was held on a murder charge for the killing of lance corporal maria lauterbach, who was found charred, along with her fetus in his backyard. laurean, a camp lejeune marine, fled to mexico but was finally extradited and will stand trial for lauterbach's slaying in a civilian court. if he is convicted, laurean could face the maximum sentence of life in prison without parole.
2229	ukraine's interior ministry has warned that attempting to deal with pro-western protesters using peaceful means is ineffective, as protesters continue to amass weapons and violence escalates. president viktor yanukovych refused to sign an eu deal in favor of stronger economic ties with russia, leading to the opposition demanding his resignation and early elections, which the government currently refuses. the eu is now attempting to prevent further escalation of the situation.
2230	japanese officials are concerned with an overabundance of cute cartoon mascots, known as yuru-kyara, which are used for a variety of purposes ranging from food and train lines to local regions and prisons. despite their amateur origins, the japanese deeply connect with these characters. osaka has even more mascots than its population, and its local government plans to cut the number, focusing on one mascot, moppi.
2231	indonesia summoned the australian ambassador to express their anger towards allegations that australia tried to listen in on the phone calls of indonesian president yudhoyono. the envoy took careful note of the issues raised and reported back to the australian government. this came after reports by the australian broadcasting corporation and the guardian australia, citing documents provided by edward snowden, claiming that australian intelligence tracked yudhoyono's mobile phone and monitored his calls in august 2009. indonesian presidential spokesman teuku faizasyah urged clarification by the australian government to repair damaged trust and restructure diplomatic relations.
2232	the united states does not know the location of deposed libyan leader moammar gadhafi, with the national transitional council (ntc) also believed not to have the full information. an unidentified spokesman for the new tripoli military council claimed that anti-gadhafi fighters had cornered the fallen leader and that he had no method of escaping.
2233	the syrian civil war has greatly impacted the lives of children, leaving millions suffering from trauma, malnutrition, and disease. over two million children have been afflicted, with one in three suffering from injuries. schools have been destroyed or turned into shelters, and one-third of children in northern syria are without vaccinations against preventable diseases. the war has also led to children being used as human shields and recruited by armed groups. the need for an effective un security council solution has been noted.
2234	ukip's nigel farage has called for limited access to the nhs to british citizens, and for an end to voting rights for non-uk citizens. farage claimed that the nhs should only be for uk citizens, and criticized the healthcare service's reliance on foreign workers, specifically pointing out the significant percentage of healthcare staff who come from overseas. the ukip leader suggested that measures be taken to limit the numbers of foreign immigrants accessing health services and reducing reliance on migrants. farage also proposed exempting people entering the nhs system from studying medical subjects from tuition fees to reduce the need for imported staff. 
2235	a missouri man, david lee mangum, who tested hiv positive in 2003, had more than 300 sexual partners and didn't tell them about his condition due to his "fear of rejection." he's now facing a felony charge for exposing one of his former live-in partners to the virus. police are filing probable cause statements for two more alleged victims who wish to seek charges against the 36-year-old mangum. 
2236	democratic lawmakers insisted that a reduction in job opportunities due to obamacare would lead to a positive outcome in the long run, with house democrats claiming it would provide more choices and the white house stating that individuals will be able to have more control over their lives. according to douglas elmendorf from the congressional budget office, the affordable care act may lead to 2.5 million full-time employees losing their jobs in the us. despite this, democrats believe this would be beneficial for workers by providing greater flexibility and choice in their livelihoods. the council of economic advisers and the white house argued that the affordable care act could save people time, allowing them to spend more time with their families rather than working long hours.
2237	andrea hill, the chief executive of suffolk county council, has resigned with a £219,000 ($292,000 usd) pay-off after accusations of bullying and claiming excessive expenses. hill earned more than the prime minister and repeatedly refused to take a 10% pay cut, though she claimed her position as chief executive made her more "high-risk." hill's management style came under significant criticism, and she will remain on paid leave until june 30 while the council searches for a new permanent leader.

2239	a security company, g4s, has been placing asylum seekers in four-star hotel rooms due to a shortage of space in specialist hostels. migrants stayed for over a month in rooms with amenities such as satellite tv, free broadband, and 24-hour room service at the £100-a-night holiday inn in barnsley. security company g4s booked more than 400 rooms at the establishment for the asylum seekers, but despite the luxurious accommodations, they failed to inform the police and council of the arrangement. the exact cost of the accommodation was not disclosed, but a daily breakfast and evening meal at the hotel can cost over £100 per night. the home office said they were aware of this temporary housing, but the situation is no longer ongoing.
2240	a sleepy english village in lincolnshire has recently discovered that their ancient limestone church's titling tower leans at a greater angle than the world-famous leaning tower of pisa, located in italy. villagers are hopeful that their grade ii listed church of st. james’s will soon draw a significant number of tourists to their picturesque corner of the united kingdom. the church tower currently leans up to 5.1 degrees to the west, compared to pisa's famous tower, which leans 3.99 degrees to the south-east. the mystery behind the titling is still unknown, though there are several theories about how the church's tower came to lean, one of which includes the soil being used elsewhere.

2243	the video game industry is set to grow 10% this year, but only $4 out of every $10 will come from traditional disc-based games played on consoles and pcs. the rising popularity of online and mobile games has caused a drop in traditional games, with online games expected to make up 31% of revenue and mobile games to account for 28% of game sales. experts predict spending on disc-based games to peak again in 2016, but further growth depends on value-oriented plays from micro-consoles like ouya, nvidia's shield, and huawei's tron.

2245	a man accused of murder and illegal firearm possession escaped from russia's maximum-security matrosskaya tishina prison using a spoon and bed sheets. 32-year-old oleg topalov, described as 'mentally abnormal' by guards, scaled his eight-person cell's wall, dug a hole in the ventilation vent, and escaped via the ventilation vent. this was the fourth escape from the institution in twenty years, and the first in twelve years from a detention facility in the russian capital.
2246	the damage cost of a deadly tornado that struck an oklahoma city suburb was estimated to be over $2 billion, making it more expensive than the $1.4 billion in damages from the 2011 joplin tornado that killed 158 people. the oklahoma tornado, which lasted 40 minutes and left a 17-mile-long path of destruction, has left a trail of 2,400 homes damaged or destroyed.

2249	referee mike dean awarded arsenal a controversial penalty in the 24th minute against manchester city, with questions raised over whether he even saw the foul. replays showed he was looking away during the incident when vincent kompany blocked nacho monreal off the ball inside the box at the etihad. after scoring the penalty, arsenal went on to win 2-0 against the barclays premier league champions, damaging their chances of retaining the title.
2250	in melbourne, florida, police officers issued scratch-off lottery tickets to motorists who were speeding or breaking traffic laws on christmas day. the officers bought the lottery tickets using their own funds and hoped the surprise gifts would spread holiday cheer while reminding drivers that obeying the law keeps roads safe. by 1 p.m. on christmas day, over 30 tickets had been handed out to speeders and other traffic violators. while none had won yet, the officers hoped the gifts would change the way people viewed the law, improving their attitude towards police work.

2253	harold jellicoe percival, an aged world war ii veteran with no close family members or friends, lived in a care home before he passed away at the age of 99. percival, a last living link to the dambusters raid, served in an eminent role with bomber command. after his passing, percival was originally set to have a simple funeral with only a few people in attendance. however, upon learning about his story, the local newspaper released an appeal in hopes to reach out to the community, asking for people to come to the funeral to pay their respects and remember percival's service. as a result, over a thousand people turned up to the funeral, many of whom had never met percival before. despite his solitary life, it was quite a meaningful and heartwarming ceremony for the public, who came together to support the forgotten war veteran.

2259	the war crimes trial of former bosnian serb commander ratko mladic has been suspended until further notice due to the prosecution's failure to disclose some evidence against mladic. the abrupt suspension came only a day after the long-awaited trial began. prosecutors were planning to focus on the massacre of up to 8,000 muslim men and boys at srebrenica but defence called for a halt when it was discovered that the prosecution had not shared all the evidence against mladic. the trial is expected to resume soon, the exact date yet to be determined.

2261	a report from an independent government review board argues that a national security agency program for collecting telephone and internet communications from suspected targets outside the us has the potential to infringe on the privacy rights of us citizens. the program is still deemed as legal, valuable, and effective in protecting national security, with no evidence of intentional abuse found. however, "certain aspects of the program's implementation raise privacy concerns." the government doesn't know the amount of data involving americans' communications that is being collected, while privacy protections must be strengthened.

2273	a brazilian, vinicius font, is the first non-italian to top the world rankings in beach tennis. despite facing skepticism when he started playing, he fell in love with the sport and is determined to prove people wrong. the sport, a hybrid of volleyball and tennis, is gaining popularity, and font aspires to be the world's best player once again. beach tennis, a relatively new game, began gaining traction in brazil in 2008. unlike conventional tennis, the game doesn't allow the ball to touch the ground and features serve and volley with paddle-like rackets.

2275	tank the tortoise, a six-month-old hermann's tortoise, is an adorable pet at paradise wildlife park in hertfordshire, which wows visitors with its tiny size. tank can fit inside the head of a spoon and is so dwarfed by a lip balm that it makes a computer mouse look gigantic. despite its small size, tank has shown a powerful energy for life, and despite future growth to be about seven times its current size, it will continue to spread joy to its visitors.

2281	a study by axa ppp healthcare reveals that one in three brits leave gp appointments feeling confused by medical jargon, with one in ten 18-24 year olds misinterpreting their diagnosis due to misunderstanding terms such as "benign", "haemorrhage" and "hypertension". only 63% of 18-24 year olds correctly identified a fracture as a broken bone compared to 91% of older respondents, and up to 52% of young adults thought hypertension was a hyperactive disorder.
2282	karl rove, president bush's senior political adviser, announced his resignation, stating it was the "right time to start thinking about the next chapter in our family's life." rove held a top position in the white house since bush's inauguration in january 2001 and will step down as of august 31st. he plans to spend his post-white house career writing a book and teaching.
2283	two american hikers, josh fattal and shane bauer, have been sentenced to eight years in iran's evin prison, where former us journalist roxana saberi and sarah shourd endured severe solitary confinement. fattal and bauer are currently being held on charges of spying and illegal entry. sarah shourd, who was jailed together with the two men but later released for medical reasons, warned about the harsh and oppressive conditions in evin, describing how they had feared their lives during the arrest process and their imprisonment in solitary confinement.
2284	lancashire skipper paul horton has been suspended from the opening two matches of next year's natwest t20 blast after displaying dissent towards the umpires during this year's final match against birmingham bears. horton was handed the punishment by the england and wales cricket board's cricket discipline commission (cdc) after being reported by match officials for his actions. the penalty for the level two breach of the ecb's discipline code is three penalty points, but the cdc felt additional action was necessary and imposed a two-match ban upon horton who has accepted the punishment. horton apologised to the umpires and stated that he realised his actions were unacceptable, given the high profile nature of the match.
2285	there's a clash between mercedes teammates lewis hamilton and nico rosberg in the belgian grand prix. rosberg admits for the first time to "regret" his actions but still refuses to apologize, while hamilton alleges that his crash with rosberg was deliberate.
2286	ten years after my last visit to chechnya, i was surprised to see the vast changes that took place under russian government control. construction was ubiquitous, and signs of violence, such as bullet holes, were scarce. i observed armies of workers building high-rises and roads, and the city had started to show signs of prosperity. the russian government spent vast amounts of rubles on rebuilding the region and had formed a deal with former rebel fighter ramzan kadyrov, who now ruled the chechen republic. many aspects of kadyrov's rule, such as a showroom of antique guns and sabers at his mansion, were eccentric but seemed to assure relative peace. however, critics of kadyrov and his security forces continued to be targeted, and chechnya still remains fragile in terms of security and stability.
2287	the article discusses the fear of federal programs, such as medicare and social security, invading individual freedoms and eventually leading the us to socialism. while past predictions about the consequences of these programs have not come true in practice, current conservative politicians often still criticize federal programs for expanding government. this tension between the ideological and operational perspectives of citizens reveals that there is a balance between accepting government programs for their benefits and maintaining a constitutional order.
2288	air pollution in beijing remains an ongoing problem due to rapid urbanization and industrialization. despite efforts to control pollution sources, the country continues to experience harmful levels of airborne particulate matter. china acknowledges these issues and has planned to implement green development plans such as energy efficiency, renewable energy, pollution reduction and control, and adopting new standards for air pollution measurement. however, there are still concerns about the government's initiatives to improve air quality for the benefit of future generations.

2290	binyamin netanyahu's new coalition government intends to change the conscription laws for ultra-orthodox jews, aiming to cut israel's benefits bill. the community might be conscripted, and former military chief moshe 'bogie' ya'alon, expected to become israel's next defence minister, is driving this controversial move. the move has sparked protest among the ultra-orthodox community and could take them off the country's benefits bill. the next government has a better chance than its predecessors in altering the law, given netanyahu's decision not to include the ultra-orthodox shas party in his coalition and replace them with the centrist yesh atid party, the jewish home party, and the hatanua party. netanyahu and ya'alon both share similar views on iran, with ya'alon having helped draft the plans.
2291	dentists call for a reduction of added sugar consumption by approximately 75% to prevent tooth decay. the university college london suggests consuming around four teaspoons of sugar per day, less than half a can of coca-cola. this would reduce tooth decay treatment, which currently accounts for 6-10% of total health costs.

2293	a woman in melbourne's south-east was rescued after falling into a three-metre deep sinkhole while hanging out some washing. the 53-year-old cleaner was assisting an elderly woman when the ground suddenly gave way, causing her to land in a pool of water. the woman managed to swim in the sinkhole for about 30 minutes before her neighbours noticed and called 000 for help, which arrived within a few minutes. an investigation into the sinkhole revealed it was due to an old and poorly concealed well.

2301	the national trust warns that the spread of giant windfarms across britain constitutes the 'most widespread and persistent threat' to the countryside. chairman sir simon jenkins criticizes the government's planning reforms, claiming they will cause 'warfare' if not delayed. the trust fights wind farm applications frequently and opposes wind turbines blighting the landscape, though it supports renewable energy in the right location. the trust calls for a delay in adopting the new rules that aim to come into force later this month, to prevent local communities from engaging in costly battles with building and wind farm developers.

2303	the united states, during the cold war, relied on the theory of deterrence to protect against nuclear attacks, believing that as long as it maintained nuclear forces to survive a first-strike and retaliate, the soviet union would be deterred. the strategy was costly, wasteful, and dangerous but also effective. in the more recent cases of north korea and iran, the obama administration is acting differently, treating both nations differently, mainly because they perceive them as aggressive religious fanatics who would not be deterred from using nuclear weapons. while deterrence theory may still apply, the united states needs to work harder to achieve president obama's goal of a world without nuclear weapons, and it would be wise to consider a more conciliatory posture for future negotiations with iran.

2308	a 14-year-old girl, izzy dix, was found dead in her home in brixham, devon, by her mother. friends claimed she was a victim of bullying on the website ask.fm. izzy's friends created a poignant youtube video blaming her death on the site, as it had around 60 million users when the video was created. the video urged every student at the school to shut their ask.fm accounts, and the school also offered counseling services to affected students. the devon and cornwall police treated izzy's death as an accident, saying that they would investigate the circumstances surrounding her death. the website had caused controversy about cyberbullying and deaths related to it.

2320	the famous "face" on the man in the moon is believed to have been created by magma bubbling up to the moon's surface, according to new research. the 1,800-mile-wide section of its lunar basin, known as procellarum, was formed from large plumes of molten rock, rather than asteroid strikes, as previously thought. the circles are formed by giant tension cracks in the moon's crust as it cooled, producing sharp angles and creating a "plumbing system" for magma to move to the surface.

2357	north korean leader kim jong il passed away from a massive heart attack at the age of 69. his body was laid in state in a glass coffin, and top officials, including his son and successor kim jong un visited him to pay their respects. a 11-day mourning period was also observed throughout the country, with flags at half-mast, as the nation prepared for a state funeral. the transition of power in north korea raised concerns in the international community, as kim jong un needed to consolidate his power and authority.
2358	a car driven by an apparently drunk driver lost control, crashed through the living room and kitchen, and partially collapsed the roof of an indianapolis home, causing $175,000 worth of damage. the occupants within the home were a young family with two daughters, aged 4 and 6, who were fortunately uninjured. the driver and passenger were also unharmed and underwent alcohol tests following the incident.
2359	at 17, sonali mukherjee led an ambitious life, but that changed when three male students started harassing her. they threatened her but she didn't yield to their advances. after an acid attack, mukherjee lost her eyesight, hearing, and her ability to eat, walk, and talk. her father sold their family's land and savings to fund her extensive surgeries, but her attackers were freed after only two years in jail. mukherjee, now 27, has fought for justice as she undergoes extensive reconstructive surgery. the acid attack law in india in 2013 increased punishments to 10 years to life in prison and a fine, but mukherjee's case remains unaddressed by the court.
2360	in july 2012, 12 people were killed in a colorado movie theater during a special midnight screening of batman film, "the dark night rises." a man dressed head-to-toe in protective gear opened fire with an ar-15 rifle, a 12-gauge shotgun, and a .40-caliber pistol before surrendering to police within seven minutes. the suspect, 25-year-old james holmes, faces 166 charges and has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity. the motive behind his attack is not yet clear, but holmes is said to be an intelligent person with a history of academic success.
2361	a spanish photographer documented the lives of 18-year-old triplets jaime, alejandro, and álvaro who are all diagnosed with autism. the brothers have a deep bond, despite the challenges posed by the complex neurological disorder. although they have difficulty communicating and socializing, they enjoy playing games and interacting with others with autism at local recreational facilities. the photographs were intended to showcase the brothers' daily lives in hopes of fostering greater support for families with autistic children.
2362	a man from new zealand, daniel gray, built an impressive igloo in canada with his girlfriend, kathleen starrie, using hundreds of frozen milk cartons to construct the igloo. the idea for the igloo construction was dreamt up by kathleen's mother, brigid. the igloo was built while temperatures in edmonton plummeted to minus 25 f. the project took five days and around 150 hours of labor. the igloo was created by carefully frozen milk cartons, which were then stacked in a spherical shape using snow and water, creating what looks like a traditional igloo.
2363	iran has activated a heavy-water production plant to produce plutonium for nuclear weapons, according to reports, while international inspectors have been banned from examining the site. satellite images showed clouds of steam emerging from the site, which has been guarded for 18 months. negotiations between western countries and iran continued in kazakhstan regarding iran's nuclear program.

2367	the grand inga project, a massive hydroelectric project in the democratic republic of the congo (drc), aims to harness the power of the congo river and provide renewable energy to over 500 million people. it comprises five phases, with the first stage, inga 3, expected to generate 4,800 megawatts. the project seeks funds from private and public sources, including development banks, multilaterals, and commercial and national development banks. south africa has agreed to purchase half of the power generated. despite potential benefits, opponents argue that the project can benefit energy-rich countries more and should instead focus on cheaper, more efficient power sources, such as decentralized energy solutions, prioritizing grid and off-grid planning to distribute power to both rural and urban areas.
2368	in an interview with bbc breakfast, transport secretary and local councils minister brandon lewis admitted that he was confused about recycling rules and did not know what to put in his green waste bin, even though he is responsible for the rules for english and welsh local authorities. minister lewis suggested that keeping things simple would help people recycle better.
2369	uk environment secretary owen paterson expressed dissatisfaction with wind farms, calling them a "complete scam" and a factor causing "huge unhappiness" across the nation. to counter this, the government introduced new measures allowing local residents to block turbine development in their villages, as well as increasing the discounts offered to communities approving wind farms. conservatives have taken a tougher stand on wind farms recently and plan to strengthen the local veto over these projects. though paterson's remarks risk a furious reaction from liberal democrats pushing for more renewable power projects, public opinion has shown a preference for wind turbines over fracking sites.
2370	nick clegg suggests that wealthy pensioners, with assets of over £1 million, should lose access to universal benefits like free bus passes. age-related payments may be protected for the duration of the parliament but could be curbed later on. the proposed plan is expected to be included in the liberal democratic manifesto for the next general elections in 2015. some senior members of the party are looking to implement these changes sooner. work and pensions secretary, iain duncan smith, also supports this idea to help shave £10 billion from the welfare budget.

2374	carl djerassi, creator of the contraceptive pill, believes that the next 20 years will see dramatic changes in reproductive options, with advancements like freezing eggs in their 20s and using ivf to bypass the biological clock. technologies like storing ovarian tissue, harvesting ovarian stem cells, and creating eggs from skin or bone marrow stem cells are all potentially available in the next two decades, enabling future women greater control over family planning and biological abilities. while advancements in reproduction offer new possibilities and empowerment, they could also raise ethical and religious concerns.

2377	research suggests that relatively healthy adolescents and young adults are at a higher risk of serious complications from the h1n1 flu, similar to the 1918 influenza pandemic. h1n1 vaccines should be administered to children, as they are the most likely to benefit from its protection. the studies indicate that young people are at risk of bad complications of h1n1 and the 2009 flu season may bring even more of these cases.
2378	british woman kitty mansfield is the uk's first professional snuggler, offering a service where adults can cuddle with her. her clients can watch tv or listen to music while cuddling up on the sofa or in her bed, sometimes staying the weekend. mansfield has been a snuggler for over 10 years, feeling comfortable around people and has found a non-sexual way to make a living. her snuggling clients pay £45 an hour.

2380	dinosaurs breathed through their noses to smell their surroundings and cool their brains, according to experts, who used a computer model to show that air moved through the nasal passages of cretaceous pachycephalosaurids or 'pachy' dinosaurs. the nasal passages of extinct creatures resemble those of modern-day animals such as ostriches and alligators, supporting this claim. the research was based on discovery of perfectly preserved soft tissues within the nasal cavities of remnants of pachycephalosaurids and shed light on pachycephalosaurus' unique skull features.
2381	a series of incredible photos captured a hungry bird almost dropping its dinner but successfully catching it again in mid-air. the carp was snatched from the water before almost escaping the bird's beak as they both soared through the air near el dorado lake in long beach, california. the struggle was captured by photographer andrew lee, who spotted the scene near his california home.

2387	a powerful earthquake struck off the northeast coast of japan, causing building rattling in tokyo and triggering a small tsunami. the earthquake had a 7.3-magnitude, significantly lower than the 9.0-magnitude in 2011, but still caused minor injuries. the 2011 disaster occurred near fukushima, which had damaging consequences for japan's energy infrastructure and the environment. following the 2011 meltdowns, fish near fukushima remained significantly radioactive, suggesting elevated contamination may still be leaching into surrounding waters.

2390	people may have undiagnosed or "silent" heart attacks, which can cause up to 60% of all heart attacks in the united states annually. the risk factors for silent heart attacks are the same as for regular heart attacks and include smoking, diabetes, stress, and family history. experts recommend seeking emergency medical attention if experiencing chest pain or other heart-related symptoms to prevent undetected heart attacks. current research focuses on the diagnosis and treatment of silent heart attacks, but further studies are needed to establish effective treatment.
2391	in 1945, during the closing months of world war ii, unknown american soldier captured breathtaking images of his fellow soldiers, moments in between battles, and the beautiful landscapes of europe. 31 undeveloped rolls of film captured during the war were recently discovered and developed by freelance photographer and old film fanatic levi bettweiser. bettweiser spent months carefully processing the films, which had been water-damaged. the images offer a unique glimpse into the life of soldiers during wwii, offering a visual diary of the men's experiences, landscapes, and everyday moments.

2393	the term 'terror babies' refers to children born in the us to illegal immigrants. they acquire us citizenship and may later return to their home countries as adults potentially intending to attack the us. this is a scary idea, but there is no evidence supporting its existence. the idea's popularity is likely due to the fears of some people and politicians that illegal immigrants are unfairly taking advantage of constitutional provisions. while the concept of 'terror babies' is not realistic, it represents a dangerous trend in misrepresenting immigration issues. critics should base their arguments on facts rather than fear-mongering.

2395	some of the world's unusual cultural traditions recognized by the unesco (united nations educational, scientific and cultural organization) include: 1. kırkpınar oil wrestling festival in turkey 2. potato fries from belgium 3. farmer's dance of china's korean ethnic group 4. human towers of spain, also known as "castells" 5. oxcart painting and decorating tradition in costa rica 6. joking relationships in niger 7. kırkpınar oil wrestling festival in turkey 8. whistled language of la gomera island in the canary islands 9. mongolian knuckle-bone shooting tradition these traditions are included in unesco's intangible cultural heritage list to ensure the protection of important and worldwide heritages and to raise awareness of their significance.

2401	a new study found that children with an autism spectrum disorder spent twice as much time playing video games as children without such disabilities. researchers also discovered that children with the disorder or adhd are at a higher risk of gaming addiction, with addictive gaming potentially being driven by inattention. the study shows a link between the number of hours a child spends playing video games daily and inattention, with inattention having a greater influence among children with autism.
2402	in this memoir, matt cain, a former culture editor at channel 4 news, recounts his struggles with a life-threatening condition where he would repeatedly faints and experiences heart arrhythmias. for 30 years, he received several misdiagnoses, leading to a life filled with anxiety, dependency on beta-blockers, and being unable to participate in various activities. the diagnosis came after a "tilt table test" which was administered at the national hospital for neurology in london. the test led to the discovery of autonomically mediated syncope with asystole. after being fitted with a pacemaker and overcoming his fear, cain was no longer dependent on medication, resulting in improved energy and memory. he has since dedicated himself to his passion of writing novels and published his debut romantic comedy, "shot through the heart," in april 2022.
2403	five people, who had been in contact with a woman who died from a rare and multi-drug resistant strain of tuberculosis in queensland, tested positive for a latent version of the disease after being screened. thirty individuals were tested, and of these, 30 have already been tested by the cairns tb control unit. out of these 30 individuals, five tested positive for the latent form.
2404	criminal organizations in china have developed the ability to create near-perfect fake bi-metallic coins, prompting concerns that the £2 coin could be vulnerable to a new wave of forgeries. this alarm comes after a shipment of fake euro coins, worth £390,000, was seized in naples, italy, revealing that chinese forgers are now mass-producing bi-metallic coins. while the uk has seen a surge in fake £1 coins, £2 coins have remained almost untouched due to the difficulty of connecting the inner and outer pieces of the coin together.

2416	both brazil and indonesia aim to protect their tropical rainforests, which hold a vast array of biodiversity. many millions of species inhabit these ecosystems, however, quantifying precise information is difficult due to unidentified lifeforms. tropical rainforests are estimated to host at least two-thirds of earth's terrestrial species, and research indicates a correlation between the forest and various human benefits. over time, these ecosystems have survived and fostered uninterrupted evolution. discovering new species is a continuous event, and these forests provide a source of valuable resources and medicines.

2428	love letters exchanged between then-president warren g. harding and his mistress carrie fulton phillips were recently made public by the library of congress after being kept private for 50 years. the letters, which contain explicit and bawdy content, offer a glimpse into harding's unremarkable tenure, which started in 1921 and lasted until his death in office in 1923. harding was married to his wife, florence, who is also known for her capability as a business manager and political wife. the affair spanned fifteen years before harding became president and continued while he was a u.s. senator and lieutenant governor of ohio.

2431	the impossible bike, a new folding electric bike, can be folded and stored in a bag for easy transport. it reaches a speed of 12.5 mph and runs for 45 minutes on a single charge with ten 2,900mah batteries. weighing at around 85 kg, the bike is built for riders of up to 13 stone. it has no pedals, but its design is specifically created to help distribute weight across the frame, ensuring a more even distribution of weight. this folding bike has raised over £123,000 ($218,850) via a kickstarter campaign for its production with plans for international shipment by august 2015.

2434	australian homeowners may dream of owning their own castle, but the reality of how expensive a residence will be when factoring in a mortgage is like a nightmare, according to michelle hutchison, money expert with finder.com.au. their research found that australians with mortgages below $500,000 will end up paying over one million australian dollars by the time their mortgage is paid off. this is due to interest and house price growth in popular cities like sydney, melbourne, and perth. the solution, hutchison suggested, is to review home loans each year, haggle, and pay a little extra every month.

2438	novelist julian barnes claims that writers are under increasing pressure to include explicit sex scenes in their books. he warns that overly graphic sex scenes can lead to being 'laughed at by future generations' and suggests that bad sex writing involves being too pornographic, facetious, or overly earnest. writers may feel inhibited by the fear of their readers thinking they are writing from personal experience. barnes asserts that the comedy approach many writers take can lead to bad sex writing and suggests examining a wider range of suitable names for body parts and better visual imagery for the reader.

2440	a retired marketing director, john hay, has transformed a rare green telephone box in barningham, county durham, into a war museum that could be the world's smallest. hay decided to create the museum after finishing a portrait of his late grandfather, who fought in world war i, and filled the phone box with first world war memorabilia, including newspapers from 1914, a tin helmet, maps of the early battles, and a copy of the village flyer disguised as a trench magazine. hay has received positive feedback for his creation and hopes it will promote the sacrifices of soldiers during the war.

2461	during the second world war, general sir miles 'bimbo' dempsey, an important wartime general, recorded top secret meetings in his engagements' diary. however, dempsey mysteriously 'cleared' the pages covering the week of the d-day landings by scribbling a line through them. dempsey marked the days after the invasion by noting 'd+1', 'd+2', and other variations. dempsey retired from the army in 1957 and passed away in 1969. the dempsey family plans to release an archive of documents and photographs, including the black book, to highlight the career and achievements of this forgotten figure in the lead-up to the 70th anniversary of d-day.

2498	goldfish have the ability to distinguish between classical music by johann sebastian bach and igor stravinsky, according to a study by japanese researchers. the fish were trained through trial and error to bite a red bead in response to one piece and not the other. though the fish showed some individual preferences, they did recognize differences between the two pieces. these findings challenge the perception that goldfish are relatively simple creatures with low levels of intelligence.
